Rating: 10/10

Released in 2005, Day of Defeat: Source is a masterpiece of tactical, team-based combat, offering players an incredibly immersive World War II experience. Powered by the Source engine, the game manages to blend historical authenticity with thrilling action, all while delivering highly strategic, competitive gameplay. Even years after its release, it still holds up as one of the best multiplayer shooters out there. Hereâ€™s why Day of Defeat: Source earns a perfect 10/10 rating.

Why Day of Defeat: Source Is a Must-Play
ğŸ’¥ Authentic WWII Combat
Day of Defeat: Source stands out by offering a truly authentic World War II experience without sacrificing fun gameplay. The game features historical maps that take players across iconic battlegrounds in Europe, such as the Normandy beaches and the streets of Stalingrad. The sound design, including gunfire, explosions, and ambient battle noises, creates an incredibly immersive atmosphere that makes you feel like you're truly on the frontlines.

ğŸ”« Varied and Balanced Classes
The game offers a wide range of playable classes, each with its own strengths and weaknesses. From the rifleman to the machine gunner and the sniper, each role adds depth and tactical complexity to the game. The classes are perfectly balanced, ensuring no single class is overpowered, and teamwork is essential for success. Whether you prefer to lead the charge or provide supporting fire, there's a class for everyone.

ğŸ® Strategic, Team-Oriented Gameplay
At the heart of Day of Defeat: Source is its team-based objective gameplay. Unlike many fast-paced shooters, success isnâ€™t determined by your individual skill, but rather by how well you work with your teammates. Objectives such as capturing points or defending strategic locations encourage coordinated team efforts, making every match feel dynamic and rewarding. This focus on teamwork sets the game apart from others in the genre.

âš”ï¸ Smooth and Engaging Combat
The combat mechanics in Day of Defeat: Source are smooth and engaging, with a focus on accuracy, strategy, and timing. The gameâ€™s shooting mechanics are satisfying, and the different weapon types require careful control, whether itâ€™s the bolt-action rifles or the automatic submachine guns. The Source engine brings this all to life with excellent physics, realistic recoil, and fluid animations, creating a satisfying shooting experience.

ğŸŒ Classic Maps and Modding Community
Maps such as Avalanche, Dawnville, and Kalt remain fan favorites for their brilliant design, balance, and flow. These maps are also mod-friendly, encouraging players to create custom content, expanding the gameâ€™s replay value. The active community has contributed to the longevity of Day of Defeat: Source, with fan-made maps, mods, and servers providing new ways to enjoy the game even years after its release.

What Makes It a 10/10
Day of Defeat: Source doesnâ€™t just rely on nostalgia; it holds up as a compelling and timeless shooter. The blend of historical accuracy, strategic depth, and intense teamwork creates a gaming experience that is both challenging and rewarding. While its visual style might feel dated by todayâ€™s standards, the focus on gameplay mechanics and team collaboration makes it feel as fresh and exciting as when it first released. Itâ€™s the kind of game that stands the test of time, offering unmatched fun and depth.

If youâ€™re looking for a WWII shooter thatâ€™s all about tactics and teamwork, Day of Defeat: Source is a must-play. Though it is just an off-brand Quake and obscure Valve title with only a handful of real people playing, Deathmatch Classic is addictive and as basic as an arena shooter can be. Start each match with weak weapons, run around the map to find better weapons, and kill your opponents with said weapons. 

Collect power-ups like armor, health kits, temporary high damage/invulnerability orbs, and sometimes a bio suit for swimming thru lava briefly. You can also telefrag if you get the timing right. Just don't get fragged yourself. That's all to the gameplay loop.

No UAVs online, no care packages, no level prestige, and not a single microtransaction in sight. Just every man for himself living (and dying repeatedly) in the moment. | There are no characters that get naked!

Other than that, pretty good game, underrated as hell. | 6/10

ĞĞ»Ğµ Ğ²ÑĞµ Ğ¶ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¸, Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ²ÑÑ– Ğ¼Ñ–Ğ½ÑƒÑĞ¸, Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ” ÑĞ²Ğ¾Ñ— Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸: Ñ‚Ñ– Ğ¶ Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ²Ñ– Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ¹ Ğ·Ğ±Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ°ÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ñ€Ñ–Ğ·Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ½Ñ–Ñ‚Ñ‚Ñ, Ğ° Ñ–Ğ´ĞµÑ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ»ÑĞ½ÑƒÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ½Ğ° ÑĞ²Ñ–Ñ‚ Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ° Ğ²Ñ–Ğ¹ÑÑŒĞºĞ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ´Ñ–Ğ¹ÑĞ½Ğ¾ Ñ†Ñ–ĞºĞ°Ğ²Ğ°. ĞŸÑ€Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ñ‚Ñ€ĞµĞ±Ğ° Ğ±ÑƒÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ³Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¼ Ğ´Ğ¾ Ğ½ĞµÑ€Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ±ÑƒĞ²Ğ°Ğ½Ğ½Ñ. | Half-Life: Opposing Force is the third game in the series and could be considered a full blown sequel to it or simply an add-on. Opposing Force was a short and sweet game just like its counterpart Blue Shift and was a new character as well to play as. On this game you were playing as the Hazardous Environment Combat Unit soldiers who were sent to scrub the facility clean and cover up everything.

It was quite cool playing as this faction and getting to see the perspective from there eyes. Similarly to the other games you aim was to escape as well and help take as many men as you could. There was an introduction of some new weapons and new puzzles to tackle plus boss fights. 

The one thing i didn't like about Opposing Force was that the character wasn't given a proper story or ending to it. He only appeared in this game alone and so far there has been no new content with him at all. His character hasn't been worked on anymore neither has he been given a sequel to play through which is a shame.

I would recommend playing through the game and seeing the perspective of another character who's on the enemies side. Its interesting to see his transition from enemy to survivor and watch as he tries to redeem himself. | This game is a mixed bag for me and that's why I'm not recommending it.

I enjoyed the game about 50% of the time and didn't enjoy it the other 50%.

Basically, this game pisses me too often to recommend it. Kinda like Half Life 1. There are parts where I'm having fun, but it often only takes a few minutes for me to be annoyed by the next thing to face. It's constantly like that for the whole game.

The main issue for me really is that most of the strong enemies are just not fun to fight. Their AI is not particularly good and they're just annoying to deal with. If I compare the enemies' AI to the enemies' AI in Halo 1 for example, Halo has amazing AI and it's fun to play against it. That's the main reason why the Halo campaigns are so replayable. That's also why playing through Opposition Force and Half-Life 1 is kinda painful for me.

Also, often, the weapons that are strong and or very powerful have limited amounts of ammo, so you have to use cheap tricks like saving/loading multiple times or making an enemy place itself at the edge of a wall so it stays there and tries to shoot towards you, but fails to because their projectiles just hit the wall and can't reach you. Once again, if I compare what I just described to Halo 1... In Halo, generally, that is not something that will happen. For one, there is a checkpoint system that works pretty well and you'll usually have the tools you need to deal with enemies. But the main thing really is that Halo 1 is fun to play while Half-Life Opposing Force is annoying about 50% of the time.

More thoughts :

Why is the game designed in a way where we have to crouch jump (and so often)? 

A lot of unavoidable damage when doing the platforming parts. Same thing for ladders.

First 90 minutes not great. I often have to check a walkthrough because I either don't know what to do or how to solve a specific puzzle.

Game is not getting that much better after?

More unavoidable damage (this time from using the movable platform).

Overall, I didn't like the first half that much, but I enjoyed the 2nd half more.

My playthrough is often interrupted when I have to check a walkthrough because IDK what I'm supposed to do next.

Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† (4/5)

â€œBack to Black Mesa, this time with a new perspective.â€ Half-Life: Blue Shift takes players back to the iconic Black Mesa Research Facility, placing you in the boots of Barney Calhoun, a humble security guard caught in the chaos of the resonance cascade. While itâ€™s a shorter and simpler experience compared to the main game, Blue Shift offers a fresh perspective on the events of Half-Life and remains a solid expansion for fans of the series.

Story and Setting
In Blue Shift, you play as Barney Calhoun, a security guard whoâ€™s just trying to get through his shift when disaster strikes. As Black Mesa descends into chaos, your goal is survival and escape.

The story adds new layers to the Half-Life universe, showing what life was like for the "everyman" during the alien invasion. While it doesnâ€™t reach the narrative depth of Half-Life or Opposing Force, it provides a grounded, relatable perspective. Fans of the series will enjoy revisiting Black Mesa and spotting connections to Gordon Freemanâ€™s journey.

Gameplay
The gameplay in Blue Shift sticks closely to the formula of the original Half-Life. Youâ€™ll navigate familiar environments, fight alien creatures and military forces, and solve puzzles to progress.

Where Blue Shift differs is in its simplicity. The campaign is shorter, the puzzles are more straightforward, and there are fewer weapons and enemy types compared to other Half-Life titles. While this makes the game more approachable, some players may find it lacking in variety.

One notable addition is the High-Definition Pack, which updates the character and weapon models for Blue Shift and the original Half-Life. Itâ€™s a nice bonus that gives the game a fresh coat of paint for players revisiting the series.

Graphics and Performance
As with the original Half-Life, the visuals in Blue Shift have aged, but the iconic art direction and atmospheric level design still hold up. The High-Definition Pack significantly improves the look of the game, making it the definitive way to experience Blue Shift.

Performance is rock-solid on modern systems, and the gameâ€™s compact design ensures it runs smoothly even on older hardware.

Length and Replayability
Blue Shift is a much shorter experience than Half-Life, with a campaign that can be completed in about 3-5 hours. While its brevity makes it less substantial than other expansions like Opposing Force, itâ€™s still a satisfying journey for fans looking for more time in Black Mesa. However, the lack of new weapons, mechanics, or enemies may limit its replay value.

Final Thoughts
Half-Life: Blue Shift is a worthwhile expansion that offers a nostalgic return to Black Mesa with a unique perspective. While it doesnâ€™t innovate or expand on the Half-Life formula as much as other entries, itâ€™s still an enjoyable experience for fans of the series.

Pros:

Offers a fresh perspective on the events of Half-Life
Solid gameplay that stays true to the original
High-Definition Pack is a great addition
Short and accessible for newcomers
Cons:

Lacks new mechanics, weapons, or enemies
Short campaign with limited replay value
Simplistic compared to Opposing Force
If youâ€™re a fan of Half-Life and want another reason to explore Black Mesa, Blue Shift is a great addition to your library. It may be shorter and less complex, but itâ€™s a fun trip back to one of gamingâ€™s most iconic settings.

A monumental game in my gaming career, Half-Life 2 was that defining experience that made me realise I was in for something next level. For the first time i picked it up on The Orange Box in 2008, and from the moment I booted it up, I knew I was in for a wild ride. It wasnâ€™t just a gameâ€”it was an event. The environments were absolutely massive, the atmosphere was unreal, and the soundtrack? Edgy as hell. Every moment felt like a cinematic journey.

In Half-Life 2, you play as Gordon Freeman, arguably one of the most reluctant action heroes in gaming. You awaken from stasis, burdened with the trauma of the previous game, and are immediately thrust into action as the figurehead of an uprising. This isnâ€™t a simple revolutionâ€”itâ€™s a battle against a multiversal alien threat, shrouded in dystopian themes and orchestrated by secretive organizations manipulating events behind the scenes.

Set in a world dominated by the Combine, an alien regime that combines interdimensional authoritarianism with advanced technology, you must navigate a planet under their control. Armed with little more than a crowbar and your signature nonverbalism, Gordon becomes the key figure in the resistance. As you progress, you'll engage in intense combat, solve puzzles, explore diverse environments, and uncover the unsettling truth that nothing in this world is as it seems.

And letâ€™s talk about The G-Manâ€”a mysterious, interdimensional CIA glowman who pops up like a bad dream and probably controls the entire charade like a cosmic puppeteer. Is he good? Is he bad? Is he just playing the long game? Who knows, but heâ€™s definitely got his hand in everything, watching Gordon like a hawk, pulling strings like an invisible god. 

Youâ€™d think itâ€™s just a sci-fi conspiracy, but after a while, you start questioning if anyone really knows what the hell is going on. Does G-Man even have a purpose, or is he just a cosmic observer who gets his kicks out of watching a man with a crowbar take on the end of the world?

The gameâ€™s narrative feels like a giant puzzle, and each step forward opens up even more questions, all while youâ€™re tearing through enemy lines, trying to get answers. And the best part? Itâ€™s not all about combatâ€”there are puzzles to solve, mysteries to uncover, and a sense of isolation that keeps you on edge, constantly wondering who or what will show up next. The pacing is incredible, making you feel like youâ€™re a tiny piece of something far larger, with consequences that span across dimensions.

ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè¿™ä¸ªæ»‘æ¢¯ä¸èƒ½ä¸Šå»ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªè··è··æ¿æ˜¯å¯ä»¥ç©çš„ï¼ŒåŸæ¥è¿™é‡Œä¹Ÿæœ‰å°å·§æ€ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œçš„ç”µçº¿æ˜¯è§†è§‰å¼•å¯¼ç‰©ï¼Œæ€æ ·ä¿æŒä¸€ä¸ªä¼‘é—²å’Œç´§å¼ çš„å¹³è¡¡ï¼Œèƒ½åœ¨æ¸¸æˆé‡Œäº²è‡ªä¸Šæ‰‹è·Ÿçœ‹GDCæˆ–è€…å·¥å…·ç®±æ˜¯å®Œå…¨ä¸ä¸€æ ·çš„ä½“éªŒï¼Œæˆ‘ä¼šè´ªå©ªåœ°å¸Œæœ›æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªæˆ‘å–œæ¬¢çš„æ¸¸æˆéƒ½æ·»åŠ å¼€å‘è€…è¯„è®ºã€‚ | "Half-Life 2" is one of the most influential and groundbreaking first-person shooters ever made. Released in 2004 by Valve, it redefined what players could expect from a video game in terms of both storytelling and gameplay. The gameâ€™s narrative is immersive, unfolding without traditional cutscenes, which allows the player to feel like they are truly part of the story. The protagonist, Gordon Freeman, is a silent hero who navigates through a dystopian world filled with alien invaders and oppressive human forces. This unique approach to storytelling pulls the player into the gameâ€™s world, making every action feel meaningful.

The physics engine in "Half-Life 2" was revolutionary for its time. The way objects interact with the environment feels natural and intuitive, and it became a major part of the gameplay. From solving puzzles using physics to creatively using the environment as a weapon, it was an innovation that influenced many games that followed. The gravity gun, which allows players to manipulate objects in real-time, is still one of the most memorable and fun weapons in gaming history.

The level design in "Half-Life 2" is another standout feature. The game introduces players to varied environments, from the dark, industrial city of City 17 to the eerie, remote marshlands. Each location feels carefully crafted, with attention to detail that makes the world feel alive. The pacing is also masterful, alternating between moments of intense combat and slower, atmospheric sequences that allow the player to soak in the environment and story.

The AI in "Half-Life 2" was also ahead of its time. Enemies behave intelligently, using cover, working together, and reacting to the playerâ€™s actions in a way that makes combat more dynamic and challenging. The enemy variety, from the terrifying Combine soldiers to the creepy headcrabs, keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging. The interactions with NPCs and the world around you help build a sense of tension and immersion, keeping you on edge throughout the experience.

The game's soundtrack, composed by Kelly Bailey, perfectly complements the atmosphere, using subtle but effective music to enhance both the action and the quieter moments. The sound design is top-notch, with ambient sounds adding to the immersion, whether you're in a busy city street or exploring a deserted warehouse.

Ultimately, "Half-Life 2" is a masterpiece that still holds up to this day. Its innovative gameplay, storytelling, and technical achievements make it a game that set a new standard for the industry. Itâ€™s a game thatâ€™s not just fun to play, but one thatâ€™s easy to appreciate for the way it shaped the future of video games. Even though itâ€™s been years since its release, "Half-Life 2" remains a classic that continues to inspire both players and developers alike.

Half-Life: Deathmatch: Source is a multiplayer first-person shooter developed by Valve. It is a remake of the classic Half-Life deathmatch mode, utilizing the Source engine. The game combines the fast-paced action of traditional deathmatch with updated graphics and more fluid movement mechanics. While it successfully brings new life to the original concept, some mechanical issues and a niche player base prevent it from being as popular as its predecessors.

What Works Well?
ğŸ® Classic Deathmatch Gameplay
The core of Half-Life: Deathmatch is its tight, fast-paced combat. It stays true to the original deathmatch mode, offering classic weapons, high-speed action, and simple, enjoyable mechanics. The formula remains as fun today as it was when first introduced.

ğŸŒ† Updated Graphics with Source Engine
The move to the Source engine has significantly improved the visuals compared to the original. The lighting, textures, and models are much sharper, breathing new life into the iconic Half-Life universe. The environments feel more immersive, and physics interactions are more dynamic.

ğŸ”« Familiar Weapon Set
Players have access to a variety of classic weapons from the Half-Life series, including the crowbar, shotgun, and crossbow, all of which perform as expected. Each weapon has its own strategic value, and they all function well within the confines of the deathmatch setting.

ğŸ› ï¸ Modding Support and Custom Servers
As with other Source engine games, Deathmatch: Source allows for a robust modding community. Players can easily find custom servers and user-created content, from new maps to modified gameplay modes, keeping the experience fresh.

What Could Be Better?
âŒ Limited Popularity and Player Base
Despite its solid foundation, Half-Life: Deathmatch: Source suffers from a relatively small player base. As newer games in the genre continue to dominate, it can be difficult to find active matches, especially in more niche servers.

âŒ Physics Can Feel Clunky
While the Source engine improved many aspects of the game, some of the physicsâ€”especially in terms of movementâ€”can feel a little awkward compared to modern shooters. The transition to 3D space feels a bit more restrictive than anticipated, particularly when compared to the fluidity of more modern games.

âŒ No Significant Gameplay Innovation
While the updated graphics and better physics are great, Deathmatch: Source doesn't introduce any major changes to the original formula. It feels more like a polished port rather than a revolutionary step forward for the genre. Players expecting something drastically new may be disappointed.

âŒ Lack of Meaningful Progression
Like many classic deathmatch games, thereâ€™s a lack of meaningful progression or any form of unlockable content. While this keeps the focus on pure skill-based play, some players may miss the more modern systems that reward long-term engagement.

Conclusion
Half-Life: Deathmatch: Source is a solid multiplayer shooter for fans of the classic Half-Life experience. Its updated visuals and iconic weapons deliver the fun, high-speed action that fans love, but its small player base and lack of major innovation hold it back from achieving greater popularity. If youâ€™re looking for nostalgic deathmatch action or enjoy modding, itâ€™s a great choice, but donâ€™t expect a revolutionary experience.

Counter-Strike: Source (CS: Source) is the definitive version of one of the most iconic tactical shooters ever created. Built on the Source engine, it brought stunning graphics, refined mechanics, and an immersive experience that kept players engaged for years. It improved upon its predecessor, Counter-Strike 1.6, and laid the foundation for future games in the series, including Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. Here's why CS: Source remains a perfect 10/10 for fans of competitive gaming.

Why Itâ€™s a Must-Play
ğŸ”« Precise Gunplay
At the core of CS: Source is its tight and rewarding gun mechanics. Every weapon in the game feels unique, with its own recoil patterns and handling characteristics. This precision-driven combat is one of the key factors that makes CS: Source such a compelling competitive experience. From the M4A4's controlled spray to the AWP's one-shot kills, every engagement requires skill and accuracy.

ğŸŒ Map Design & Tactical Depth
The iconic maps like Dust 2, Inferno, and Nuke are where the game shines brightest. Each map is meticulously designed to offer a balance of tactical positions, choke points, and strategic opportunities. Whether you're defending bomb sites or pushing through tight corridors, the map design fosters deep teamwork and careful planning.

ğŸ’¥ Gameplay Mechanics
CS: Source features smooth, fluid movement, making it easy to peek around corners, hold angles, and strafe while shooting. The buy system gives players the freedom to choose their preferred weapons and gear, while round-based gameplay forces teams to be efficient with their resources and execute well-planned strategies.

ğŸ® Vibrant Community & Modding Support
The modding community for CS: Source has been incredibly active, creating a wealth of custom content from maps to skins to even entirely new game modes. This extends the life of the game by offering nearly endless ways to enjoy the experience. The server browser lets players dive into unique community-run servers, making every session feel fresh and exciting.

ğŸ¨ Improved Visuals
Powered by the Source engine, CS: Source delivered a massive graphical leap from its predecessors, offering realistic lighting, better textures, and advanced physics. These improvements gave the game a more immersive and polished feel, while the physics engine introduced interactive objects and destructible environments, adding a layer of depth to gameplay.

What Makes It a 10/10
CS: Source isnâ€™t just a game; itâ€™s a tactical masterpiece thatâ€™s stood the test of time. Its emphasis on team coordination, strategy, and individual skill is unmatched. Whether playing with friends or random players, the experience fosters a strong sense of community and competition, making each match feel meaningful. The team-based objectives â€“ like bomb planting/defusal â€“ combined with tight, tactical combat is a dynamic experience that few shooters can replicate.

The longevity of CS: Source is a testament to how well it was designed. While newer titles in the series (like Counter-Strike: Global Offensive) have taken inspiration from it, the smoothness of the gameplay, iconic maps, and endless customization options keep it relevant in the competitive FPS scene.

If youâ€™re a fan of shooters and havenâ€™t experienced CS: Source, youâ€™re missing out on one of the most influential and well-rounded tactical shooters ever made. Itâ€™s a game that offers both depth and accessibility, making it suitable for casual players, yet still offering enough challenge for the competitive elite. CS: Source is a timeless classicâ€”pure, competitive, and still as enjoyable today as it was when it first released. | The switch to the Source engine brought improved graphics and physics, but the gameplay changed slightly. Half-Life: Source, released in 2004 by Valve, is an enhanced version of the original 1998 masterpiece, running on the Source engine. While it aimed to improve the visuals, physics, and water effects, it failed to live up to expectations, making it a divisive version among fans.

Despite still delivering the legendary Half-Life experience, this remaster feels more like a rushed port than a true upgrade.

What Works Well?
ğŸ§ª Same Brilliant Gameplay as Half-Life
At its core, Half-Life: Source is still Half-Lifeâ€”one of the most influential FPS games ever made. The engaging story, immersive atmosphere, and smart enemy AI remain intact, making this version playable and enjoyable.

ğŸŒŠ Improved Water Effects and Physics
The transition to the Source engine brings better physics (thanks to Havok) and improved water reflections, which make certain areas look more modern compared to the 1998 original.

ğŸ–¥ï¸ Smoother Performance and Native Support
Half-Life: Source runs natively on modern systems, avoiding the compatibility issues that can arise with the original GoldSrc version. Higher resolutions and widescreen support are also a plus.

The Problems with Half-Life: Source
âŒ Barely Any Real Graphical Upgrade
Despite running on Source, most textures, models, and lighting effects remain unchanged from 1998. This makes it feel less like a true remaster and more like a basic port with minimal effort.

âŒ Buggy AI and Broken Scripted Sequences
Some of Half-Lifeâ€™s iconic scripted moments donâ€™t work properly in Half-Life: Source, breaking immersion. Enemies and NPCs sometimes behave worse than in the original, which is unacceptable for an "improved" version.

âŒ No High-Definition (HD) Model Pack
Unlike Half-Lifeâ€™s official 1999 update, which introduced better character and weapon models, Half-Life: Source lacks these HD assetsâ€”making it feel graphically inferior to an older update of the game.

âŒ Black Mesa Exists
If you want to experience Half-Life with Source engine upgrades, Black Mesa (a fan-made, Valve-approved remake) is a far superior alternative with fully reworked graphics, animations, and improved gameplay mechanics.

Conclusion
Half-Life: Source is not a bad way to play Half-Life, but it's also not the best. If you want the original experience, the GoldSrc version is more authentic. If you want a true Source engine remake, Black Mesa is the better choice.

There are few games that manage to transcend their medium, leaving a lasting impact on the players who experience them. Vampire: The Masquerade â€“ Bloodlines is one of those rare gemsâ€”an immersive, darkly compelling RPG that takes you deep into a world of nightmarish intrigue, complex morality, and unforgettable characters. Released in 2004, it may have been ahead of its time, but it has since become a beloved classic, and for good reason. This is a game that not only captures the spirit of its source material but builds a world so rich, so nuanced, that it feels alive.

A World of Shadows and Secrets
From the moment you step into the shoes of a freshly turned vampire, Bloodlines introduces you to a world that is both beautifully sinister and intricately detailed. Set in modern-day Los Angeles, the game weaves a dark tale of political intrigue, personal conflict, and supernatural terror. The rich lore of the Vampire: The Masquerade tabletop RPG is brought to life in an almost seamless way, with each faction of vampiresâ€”whether it's the stoic Ventrue, the cunning Malkavians, or the fiery Brujahâ€”adding layers of complexity to the story. This is a world where nothing is ever simple, and where every decision you make carries weight.

The setting itself, the urban sprawl of LA, is a masterwork of gothic atmosphere. The gameâ€™s locationsâ€”be it the seedy alleyways of Santa Monica or the terrifying depths of the haunted asylumâ€”are meticulously crafted, with a level of detail that makes every corner feel like it holds a secret. Youâ€™re not just moving through a city; youâ€™re navigating a sprawling, living ecosystem of power struggles and hidden threats.

Immersive Role-Playing Like No Other
What truly sets Bloodlines apart from other RPGs is its depth of character interaction and role-playing opportunities. The game is all about choiceâ€”and not just in how you approach combat or quests, but in how you choose to live your life as a vampire. Will you uphold the delicate balance of the Masquerade, hiding your true nature from humanity, or will you embrace your monstrous side and sow chaos? These choices arenâ€™t just for show; they impact the way youâ€™re treated by the various factions, your relationships with other characters, and even the gameâ€™s ending. There are no easy answers here, and thatâ€™s what makes it so compelling.

The character creation system is robust, allowing you to craft a vampire that fits your playstyle. You can invest in a variety of abilities, from brutal physical combat to stealthy persuasion and hacking skills. The power of your clan also plays a significant role in how you approach different challenges, and the supernatural abilities you gain as a vampire offer a variety of ways to approach problems. Whether you want to manipulate minds, become a fearsome force in combat, or sneak past enemies unnoticed, Bloodlines gives you the freedom to build your vampire exactly how you envision them.

A Story That Binds You
But itâ€™s not just the gameplay that shinesâ€”itâ€™s the narrative. Bloodlines offers a gripping, multi-layered story that is filled with moral ambiguity, unforgettable characters, and moments of genuine emotional weight. Whether you're trying to navigate the political machinations of the vampire factions or diving into a personal quest that challenges your own morals, the plot is constantly shifting and evolving. The main story is full of twists and turns, but itâ€™s the side storiesâ€”the personal journeys of the NPCsâ€”that really elevate the game. These characters are deeply written and full of life, each with their own motivations, quirks, and tragic backstories.

The voice acting is phenomenal, bringing every character to life with nuances and emotions that make them feel real. Whether youâ€™re talking to a wise old vampire or a desperate fledgling, the dialogue is always engaging and never feels forced. The writing, sharp and often darkly humorous, helps bring out the personality of every character you encounter, from the charming yet treacherous LaCroix to the lovable, eccentric hacker, Jeanette.

Combat and Gameplay Mechanics
The combat system in Bloodlines is a bit divisive, but it offers a unique approach to RPG combat. While the shooting mechanics can feel clunky at times, the gameâ€™s strength lies in its flexibility. You can choose to avoid combat altogether, relying on your social skills to navigate tense situations or solve problems through dialogue and subterfuge. But when the fighting does come, the visceral action makes you feel the power of being a vampire, whether youâ€™re tearing through enemies with claws or using dark blood magic to overwhelm your foes.

The game also offers a range of side quests that are surprisingly rich in content, giving you more than just a diversion from the main story. Whether youâ€™re helping a fellow vampire find their lost item or delving into a creepy mystery, these quests help flesh out the world and deepen your immersion.

A Timeless Classic
Vampire: The Masquerade â€“ Bloodlines is a game that continues to stand the test of time. Despite its technical issues at launchâ€”many of which were patched over the yearsâ€”the story, world-building, and complex characters remain as captivating as ever. This is a game that rewards patience, allowing you to sink hours into its rich narrative and immersive world. Itâ€™s a rare gem that doesn't just entertain, but challenges you, makes you think, and makes you feel the weight of every choice.

In a gaming landscape often dominated by shallow experiences, Bloodlines is a deep, meaningful RPG that still feels like a living, breathing world full of possibilities. Itâ€™s a game that hooks you with its dark allure and doesnâ€™t let go. If you havenâ€™t experienced Vampire: The Masquerade â€“ Bloodlines yet, you owe it to yourself to dive into this haunting, unforgettable adventure.

After I bought it I had it lying around for quite a while, after I finished it for the first time, I immediatly started a second run. The story is great, the voice acting is great, the dialogue is great, the atmosphere is great... Only the combat requires some getting used to and you can definitely not ignore combat especially towards the later half of the game. Overall this game is a timeless piece of art, and once you meet it on it's own terms you'll fall in love with it too. 
(still definitely get the unoffical patch though) | Trust me and download the unofficial patch before starting a save, it could save you hours of gameplay being lost like me.

Combat is pretty not good but everything else is pretty very very good.

Game Name: Deus Ex: Game of the Year Edition
Reviews:
Finally played this classic and man oh man It does live up to it's reputation.
I just loved the grim and dark, but also immersive atmosphere, from the first mission onward it's like you are really living in this world. The storyline itself is great and captivating but Deus Ex also does a perfect job at telling it's story through the levels you traverse, the graphics also play a great role at doing just that, they may be simple but they make the most of them, creating stunning and instantly believeable locations. The levels are so varied and have so many ways you can approach a goal, it's crazy. The OST is also one of the best I've heard in a videogame period. Only negative thing I could say is that, obviously, the game's old as hell. So, it does need some help to run on modern systems. Also,[spoiler]the ending to the game feels somewhat abrupt, the game has immense buildup and it all concludes in a logical way, it's just that the endings are like 20 seconds.[/spoiler]But overall, fantastic game. 9,5/10 | I played the entire game (took about 27 hours with all endings) using the Revision Mod as a launcher. (I turned off all the extra stuff) Absolutely amazing game. Soundtrack is legendary, skill system makes sense and is balanced, guns are cool, explosives and stealth are fun, and story line is engaging. Would recommend to anyone. Just remember to always choose the GEP Gun | I have 700 hours on my old CD of Deus Ex. When it released, a role-playing shooter was a novel concept. Even today it's still ahead of modern games in some ways. Deus Ex is the ideal blend of RPG and shooter. Good story, good skills, good guns. It's got it all.

This is a game so good that people ignore the bad graphics. This is a game so good that even with terrible voice acting, the writing is remembered and quoted to this day. 
This is Game of the Year 2000. This is Deus Ex. | Masterpiece of a first person RPG, one of the best games ever made. Lots of freedom in how you can approach pretty much any situation. You can go through missions however you want with all the different tools, skills, augmentations, and environmental setpieces available, and it just works. Absolutely incredible visuals and music that create an unforgettable atmosphere. Story is fantastic too with how detailed it is and how it explores various things like freedom, the consolidation and corruption of power, and trust. It's a one-of-a-kind experience. | I was 2 months old when this game came out. 25 years later, I tried it out because I had the sequels on my backlog in my library. Now I wish that I was older when this game came out, it was revolutionary. I am writing this review just when I arrived in the last mission and even tho the controls aged pretty badly and you have to run a community patch to make this game playable, it was one of the best video game experiences that I ever had. They just dont make games like this anymore.

This game isn't as good as the first keep that in mind going into it.
So many absolutely amazing and great things/ideas in this game. 
Some very well executed are in this game.

But Eidos really ruined it with a focus on the xbox over PC.
Removal of uwindows.u from the game, alot of the engine changes from regular unreal 2.
This after market licensed lighting system is really strange after decompiling the game's packages. 
It breaks all reflective and reflective transparent surfaces in the game.
Its pretty cool how they can do some things with effectively cones of light like the spinning cone of light to do the fan at the start of the game. But not as cool as it would have been without it.

Most of the multiplayer code is still in the engine for deathmatch and team deathmach.... but they didn't include it for some reason. 

The comments in the unreal script paint a strange story as well. 

It started off way better, but at some point probably when the colors changed from blue to purple and they decided xbox first was the priority.  The devs stopped seeming as happy and the game quality dropped.

Sometimes you need to let the people making the game, make the game and not meddle with development. | Invisible war is not a bad game , infact i'd argue it was a good game for 2003 standards however   due to the fact that it was an inferior sequel to  Deus ex 1  at release it hasn't aged  well and feels like a chore to complete unlike Deus ex 1(Revision) which is still fun to play  . | Do not buy this on Steam!! No matter what fixes I had tried nothing ever worked. In fact, things only got worse, until it got to the point where the game just wouldn't open at all. Buy this on GOG, or emulate it on xemu, or just play it on an OG Xbox. | ĞĞµĞ¿Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ…Ğ¾, Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾ ÑƒÑ€ĞµĞ·Ğ°Ğ½Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ² ÑÑ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ½ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ğ¸ Ñ Ğ¿ĞµÑ€Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¹ Ñ‡Ğ°ÑÑ‚ÑŒÑ. Ğ˜Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ»Ğ¾ ĞºĞ¾Ğ½ĞµÑ‡Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¼ĞµĞ½ĞµĞµ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÑĞ½Ğ¾, Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° ÑĞ¼ĞµÑˆĞ°Ğ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ñ… Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ·Ñ‹Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ² Ğ²ÑÑ‘ Ğ¶Ğµ ĞºĞ°Ğº Ğ¿Ğ¾ Ğ¼Ğ½Ğµ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ·Ğ°ÑĞ»ÑƒĞ¶Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°. | This game runs great on Linux, I am using the cachyos version of proton. I have an nvidia rtx 4070 ti, 5800x3d and this game runs 1600x1200 without a hitch, not a single crash yet.

I actually love this game, and havent played it since release. i actually played this game before the first one, so my memories of this game are maybe more fond. But so far enjoying the story and characters a lot.

I had high hopes that this would be better then X3 Reunion. However while it has some neat new things like boarding partys and new ships and new story lines. It has a number of game breaking bugs and other random bugs as well.

Things i liked:
being able to buy and train marines to board enemy ships and take them over.
new ships for all races
bigger universe
9 different story line missions
better wing control
better settings for MK3 traders

Things that i hated:
the path finding AI is somehow worse in this game then the last, i cant count the number of times i lost ships or even my own ship going through a gate.
the Xenon M7........why lord give them an M7. O and it can show up in random space on patrols.
out of sector combat is even more screwy then before (see Xenon M7 one shoting M2s)
MK3 traders are even more like to die to random things (see Xenon M7)
a couple story line missions are riddled with game breaking bugs
random bugs having to due with things like npcs talking on coms, half the time i had no idea what was going on because of this

Over all while i had fun i could have had a lot more fun if the bugs were fixed.
Can not recommend. | X3 is one of those games where you need to spend about 20 hours or more just learning how everything works.  Controls are kinda all over the place, stuff can be pretty janky at times, and overall it's just a pretty old game which can give it that outdated feeling.

BUT... I have yet to find another game that lets me live out my fantasy of establishing a space weed/arms dealing empire across the galaxy in this much detail.

Great game, but there is definitely a very steep learning curve which will deter a lot of people. | Stupid AI - seriously 3 hours trying to build up and then i park in the middle of no where and while i am away nothing hits me, then i walk into the room 30mins latter and out of no where a ship keeps ramming me till i am dead.

and because i did not save all progress lost.

talk about stupid ai. 

i really love this game always have but you would of thought this simple close collision would of been fixed by now, seen everyone comment on it.

[h1]Podsumowanie:[/h1]

[h1]Bonus dla czytajÄ…cych do koÅ„ca - gry podobne do Spore:[/h1]
1. The Eternal Cylinder - taka faza potwora x No Man's Sky. Uciekamy przed wielkim walcem, ktÃ³ry jest ciÄ…gniÄ™ty przez tajemniczego potwora i w miÄ™dzyczasie rozwijamy swojego stworka, ewoluujemy i prÃ³bujemy przetrwaÄ‡ w tym surrealistycznym Å›wiecie.

2. Adapt - gra, ktÃ³ra prÃ³buje byÄ‡ jak faza potwora, ale skupia siÄ™ tylko na tym wiÄ™c moÅ¼e wyjÅ›Ä‡ coÅ› dobrego.

3. Elysian Eclilse - gra inspiruje siÄ™ Spore i ma byÄ‡ czymÅ› na wzÃ³r duchowego nastÄ™pcy Spore, teÅ¼ ma mieÄ‡ piÄ™Ä‡ faz, ale z bardziej rozwiniÄ™tymi mechanikami i gameplayem. JuÅ¼ raz sÅ‚yszaÅ‚em takie obietnice wiÄ™c poÅ¼yjemy, zobaczymy. | Spore is the best game i have ever played, pretty good graphics for 2008. If you are stuck in a loop of repetive games, spore is the game for you. AND each playthrough is never the same.

While this game has great nostagia and is super fun, the controls are so bad that I can<t in good conscience tell modern gamers to buy it. | Crash-tastic! 

My memory of this game, of playing it off a CD, is that you could read an entire comic book waiting for a new level to load. Unfortunately that's the part of the game that has been preserved here. Bugs galore, including having actions edge off screen and characters 'dropping' through buildings making them unmovable or un-engagable. What was fun about this game originally was the campy concept and bright colors. It doesn't look right now. The bright colors and comic book dashes and dots with this early animation style doesn't scream page-turning immersive world. It's like a cheap, superficial game you'd get on a cellphone. 

The missions can be painfully simplistic and there isn't a sense of team building or world building. Your reward is largely your own imagination as you earn enough to unlock 'sets' of abilities or skills. If you're someone who wants the nostalgia either from the original release or from the really, really old comics, this might scratch the itch. If you have even slightly high standards informed by modern games, you'll be disappointed. 

The idea that something this simplistic came out in the same era as the Halo games or even the early Civilization games is a little shocking to contemplate. The people who designed it loved Patriot City and some of the 1980's kind of super villain tropes. They had fun with this, clearly, I just don't think it aged well and given the depth of both missions and conceptual design of other early 2000's games I remain shocked it was ever reviewed and ranked so highly. 

I guess get it if it's on sale or you're really, really curious about what people did when they weren't playing Quake back in the day.

Game Name: The Elder Scrolls IV: OblivionÂ® Game of the Year Edition
Reviews:
If you're new to this title:
Oblivion isn't a game that you play. Oblivion is a game that you conquer.
Yes, the graphics and mechanics haven't aged well. Yes, the dialogue is often hilariously unhinged. And yes, the game is ripe with bugs and quest breaking sequences that induce a paranoid amount of saving. But its' defects can also be broken in your favor. THAT realization is when the game grips you:
What can you get away with? What cheese tactics, what exploits, or what innocuous and obscure thing (like picking up and dropping a paintbrush from your inventory... this is not a joke) can you leverage to your adventureâ€” and how far can you leverage it? And there's so much to be adventured: every nook and cranny or every dungeon, achieve and ace every quest, grind every attribute and skill to max, collect every unique item, and then, after a 100+ hours... lament that it's over.

Which brings us to those who are returning to this title:
You know as well as I that this game has near to no replay value. Everything Oblivion has to offer can be experienced in a single playthrough, and the narrative has little to no variation (nor any substantial dialogue or narrative choices for those hopping for more RP in their RPG like the CRPGs that predated it).

It can be a hell of a ride, but with a story you can only fully revel in once, as a fresh player.
Otherwise you're only left to recall the insatiable desire to see and do everything until the memory of your previous experience is restored, which quickly dulls the experience.
However, on a personal note, I will add: that one thing I recalled was that this was one of the few games that truly made me feel as though I were fighting an endless army of demons; running, jumping, and cutting through one Oblivion gate after another...
And I felt it still, even years after its' initial release.
May it make you feel such heartiness as well. | its a nightmare to make this game stable. but its SUPER modable so you can alter it in any way you want like a sandbox. i recommend your learn the modding tools they are easy and you can make a lot of fun stuff for roleplay etc. and despite the goofiness it can be an engaging story, deep lore and great questlines.
if you're unconfortable with the modding and fixing and all that nonsese, and you own skyrim special edition i suggest you buy it just so you can get skyblivion this year (LATE 2025).
its a remake of oblivion made by modders in the skyrim se engine (with unique updated assets/worldmap/EVERYTHING) and the full game will be required to isntall it | This is the best Elder Scrolls game to date, and the best value for your money on Steam in the category of first-person action RPGs. It is a sandbox environment that starts you out on the island that the main city is in, in the center of the map. Each city has a different architectural theme, and a house that you can purchase if you have enough gold and meet the other criteria. The interface is far better than both its predecessor, Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind, and its successor, Elder Scrolls IV: Skyrim. The character design is also superior to both, as they did away with character classes in Skyrim. The game world is more beautiful if you don't follow the main quest past delivering the item to the monk at the piory, because if you close the first oblivion gate then oblivion gates start popping up all over the map. There is plenty to explore without the main quest. | I should have played this ages ago. Much to my regret.
Sure, it's "old" now- but this version functions very well. 
The forerunner for many games we enjoy today. | Loved this elder scrolls, great main story, cool ending, the world is pretty okay but aged exceptionally well for a 2006 release. NPC's are sometimes pretty odd but certainly an iteration on their continuous polishing & improvement of their approach in the RPG genre, which is portrayed in Skyrim. A recommended playthrough, especially for the main story!

Saving the world? That's boring. Playing an evil lord and parodying the fantasy genre is much more fun.

In Overlord 2, you will try out the role of the new Dark Lord, with whom you will set out to plunder the land and spread evil. Mainly with the help of your chatty and tireless goblin minions.

From the cold glacial cave, your heavy steps will lead you through snowy gorges and along the way you will sow destruction and death around you. Then comes the tropical land of the annoying marijuana elves and their annoying dances. We will also go to the underworld to the dark land of the old, already defeated dark lord. And finally, we will go to massacre the land of our archenemy - the Roman Empire led by Emperor Solarius.
The game takes place in relatively large levels, which are visually very variable and offer constant enjoyment. Although it is a more or less linear experience, it at least gives a sense of freedom.

Overlord II is a successful sequel to the first game. Although there could be at least one new goblin class and more frequent saves. [b] 55% [/b] | PÃ©ssimo!!! I still hold onto hope that a new one will be released one day. | This game is really fun, but I can't recommend it because the Battle Rock DLC was never released for PC, and without that DLC you can't max out your character.

I doubt that will ever change, but if it does I'll update my review. | Overlord 1 & Raising Hell DLC is absolutely better, which is a shame.

You could tell the Devs just didn't get to finish Overlord 2, especially at the end siege. Overlord 1 & Raising Hell DLC lasted me over 40+ hours, yet Overlord 2 wasn't even 20 hours.

Worth a single play through, but absolutely not something I see myself playing again.

Odd, Overlord Dark Legend came out the exact same day & year, yet scored better overall compared to Overlord 2 - will have to try that someday.

Remember when games were fun and didn't feel like a second job? I pull overlord out of archives every few years just to remind myself what gaming use to be. Is it perfect, no, does it run 100% stable, most of the time, does it have top of the line graphics, nope, is it fun, absolutely. | It sucks that this game was discontinued after the second game in the series because this game is funny as hell  but saddly sense EA own Codemasters they killed this franchise off too early another franchise ruined by EA No More Sheepies No More Minions but at least the game got ported to PC in a Complete version unlike OVerlord 2 Which is annoyingly missing its DLC T_T | very good game, highly recommend, minions are the best | Weltklasse das Game und LÃ¤uft auch auf Windows 11. Ich kenne es noch von der PS3 und da war es schon Geil. Ich kann es nur Empfehlen der Gerne mal den BÃ¶sen spielen mÃ¶chte mit  Dunklem Humor und Coolen SprÃ¼chen zum Totlachen. Sehr Bedien freundlich mit Maus und Controller. Ein Tolles Game | If you like the Pickmin Series and have a darker sense of humor, then this game is perfect for you.  A few mild RPG elements to round off the fantasy setting and a little more combat helps set this apart.  There are some audio problems and janky controls, but I never found them to be to annoying.

Muchos mods, pero con algunos mods es dificil pq tienes q jugar con una sola mano
 | The game also comes with a DLC, which includes the following items:

1. A Toxic Community: Mistakes are rarely forgiven. Unless youâ€™re playing with friends, be prepared to face harsh criticism, often from younger players. The gameâ€™s multiplayer is largely populated by school-aged players who donâ€™t hold back.


2. Disruptive Adults: Itâ€™s not just the kids causing chaosâ€”some adults blast music through their microphones, assuming everyone else shares their taste. Spoiler: they donâ€™t.


3. Frequent AFKs: Teamwork can fall apart when a teammate goes inactive, whether theyâ€™re brewing tea, taking a smoke break, or simply wandering off mid-game. And yes, it often happens right after youâ€™ve generously used your first aid kit on them.


4. Team Abandonment: Lone wolves running off to the far corners of the map, only to be overwhelmed by infected, are a common sight. Theyâ€™re quick to flood the chat with colorful language before rage-quitting the game.


5. Difficulty Disputes: Some players join games on "Expert" difficulty only to demand a downgrade. If their request is denied, they might sabotage the team before leaving the server entirely.


6. Vote Kicks: Occasionally, youâ€™ll encounter players who inexplicably start a vote to kick you from the game. When you ask why? Crickets.



The Verdict: Despite the chaotic community, Left 4 Dead 2 remains a phenomenal experience. The graphics are a significant step up from the first game, the mechanics feel more polished, and thereâ€™s a greater variety of weapons and infected to enjoy. However, surviving the online experience without a calming remedy might be just as challenging as surviving the zombie apocalypse itself. | ĞšÑ€ÑƒÑ‚Ğ°Ñ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ´Ğ»Ñ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñ‹ Ñ Ğ´Ñ€ÑƒĞ·ÑŒÑĞ¼Ğ¸ (ĞºĞ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ² ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°ÑÑ‚)! Ğ’ Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ‰ĞµĞ¼, Ğ²ĞµÑĞµĞ»Ğ¾, Ñ€ĞµĞºĞ¾Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ğ´ÑƒÑ. | [h1]å†™äº†800å­—çš„æ¨èæ–‡ï¼Œæ‰‹æ¬ ç‚¹äº†ä¸€ä¸‹"å¦"å…¨æ²¡äº†ã€‚ä¸è¯´äº†è¡€å‹é«˜äº†,å¤´æ™•ã€‚[/h1]æ€»ä¹‹å°±æ˜¯ã€Šå…³äºä¸€ä¸ªèŒæ–°GMODç©ä¹…äº†æ— èŠç›´æ¥å»ç©L4D1å¤šäººå› å¤ªèœåå¤è¢«åƒµå°¸è™è€Œè¢«é˜Ÿå‹æŠ›å¼ƒä¼¤å¿ƒè‡ªè´£å¸è½½æ¸¸æˆè¿‡åŠå¹´å¥½å¥‡è¿›L4D2çŸ¥é“ç©å•äººç†Ÿæ‚‰å®˜å›¾åŠç©æ³•è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­å‘ç°äº†èƒ½æ‰“MODç»“æœä¸€å‘ä¸å¯æ”¶æ‹¾åœ°æœå„ç§è¿›é˜¶æ”»ç•¥æ•™ç¨‹æå‡è‡ªå·±æ¸¸æˆä½“éªŒå’Œèƒ½åŠ›åŠªåŠ›ä¸å‘é˜Ÿå‹å¯ä»ç„¶å¾ˆèœä½†æ˜¯å¾ˆæ„Ÿè°¢å¸¦èŒæ–°å…¥å‘çš„æœ‹å‹ä»¬ä»¥åŠåˆ›æ„å·¥åŠçš„å¤§ä½¬ä»¬ç»™è¿™æ¸¸æˆç¬¬äºŒæ¬¡ç”Ÿå‘½çš„äº‹ã€‹ | Left 4 Dead 2 (L4D2), released by Valve in 2009, is the gold standard for cooperative zombie shooters. Featuring intense survival gameplay, smart AI, and an incredible atmosphere, L4D2 delivers an unmatched multiplayer experience. With its fast-paced action, diverse weapons, and unpredictable enemy encounters, this game remains one of the most thrilling and replayable co-op shooters ever made.

Gameplay â€“ Pure, Adrenaline-Fueled Action
L4D2 is all about co-op survival. You and three teammates must fight through hordes of the undead, navigating through various maps and completing objectives to reach safety. The key to survival? Teamwork, strategy, and adaptability.

The gunplay is tight and satisfying, with a wide selection of weapons including assault rifles, shotguns, SMGs, sniper rifles, and melee weapons like axes, katanas, and even frying pans! Every encounter feels dynamic, thanks to the AI Director, which adjusts the difficulty based on your teamâ€™s performance, ensuring no two playthroughs are ever the same.

Special Infected â€“ Enemies That Keep You on Edge
Beyond the standard zombie horde, L4D2 introduces Special Infected that force players to work together:

Tank â€“ A massive brute that can throw debris and crush survivors.
Witch â€“ A terrifying enemy that, if startled, can instantly incapacitate a survivor.
Smoker â€“ Uses a long tongue to drag players away from their team.
Hunter â€“ A fast, agile infected that pounces on survivors and pins them down.
Boomer â€“ Explodes in a shower of bile, attracting a massive horde.
Charger â€“ Charges through groups, slamming a survivor into the ground.
Spitter â€“ Creates pools of acid that deal heavy damage.
Each Special Infected forces different team strategies, making communication and positioning absolutely crucial.

Campaigns & Maps â€“ A Horror Movie Experience
L4D2 features multiple campaigns, each set in diverse, apocalyptic locations across the southern U.S.:

Dead Center â€“ A chaotic mall escape reminiscent of classic zombie films.
The Parish â€“ A tense race across New Orleans to reach an evacuation zone.
Swamp Fever â€“ A creepy, foggy swamp filled with infected dangers.
Hard Rain â€“ A unique campaign featuring a devastating hurricane that changes the environment.
Dark Carnival â€“ A fan-favorite, featuring a deadly amusement park with a thrilling rollercoaster finale.
Each campaign feels like a mini zombie movie, packed with cinematic set pieces, interactive environments, and intense finales.

Multiplayer & Game Modes â€“ Endless Replayability
L4D2 offers several game modes that keep the action fresh:

Campaign Mode â€“ Classic co-op survival through story-driven levels.
Versus Mode â€“ One team plays as survivors, while the other controls the Special Infected.
Survival Mode â€“ See how long you can last against endless waves of zombies.
Scavenge Mode â€“ A competitive mode where teams race to collect fuel cans while being hunted.
Mutation Mode â€“ Weekly game modifiers that add fun twists to gameplay.
Thanks to modding support and the Steam Workshop, the community has also created hundreds of custom maps, weapons, and campaigns, making L4D2â€™s replayability practically infinite.

Graphics & Sound â€“ Immersive and Timeless
Even years after release, L4D2â€™s atmospheric lighting, detailed environments, and gruesome effects hold up well. Zombies react realistically to gunfire, and the sound design is masterful, with eerie background noises, terrifying growls from Special Infected, and intense musical cues that heighten the suspense.

The voice acting and character interactions bring the survivors to life, making them memorable and adding humor to the chaos.

Why Left 4 Dead 2 is a Must-Play
L4D2 is the perfect blend of action, horror, and co-op gameplay. Whether youâ€™re playing with friends or AI teammates, the intense combat, unpredictable enemy encounters, and endless replayability make every match a thrilling adventure.

ğŸ”¹ Final Rating: 10/10
Left 4 Dead 2 is a masterpiece of cooperative gaming. If you love zombies, action, and teamwork, this is an absolute must-play that still delivers endless fun and excitement after more than a decade.

Game Name: Borderlands Game of the Year Enhanced
Reviews:
Terrible remaster that adds few QoL fixes and nothing else.

Pros:

- You automatically collect the ammo
- There's an in-game map
- You can use modern resolutions

Cons: 

- No bugs were fixed:  Enemies still fall through the map, pathfinding 100 % broken for AI etc.
- New bugs added: Moxxi Underdome music disappears whenever it feels like it, never addressed. 
- You STILL need to edit .ini file to remove mouse acceleration. Some QoL changes that are possible to change from. ini, crash the game
- There's a memory leak that was never fixed, no matter how much community tried to raise the issue
- Randy Pitchford is still in charge
- Borderlands 4, despite all the half-assed stuff in the remaster is advertised in the main menu like a mobile game pop-up and is the only thing that 100 % works in this case. 

Gunplay is decent but don't ever buy this at full price. I paid 3 euros and while it was and is for a nostalgic factor, it's the only price the remaster deserves. | Borderlands Game of the Year Enhanced Edition,
I've been enjoying the game a lot, mostly Co-op / Multiplayer!

The Game's overall atmosphere is beautiful, Invetory System is more clear, active minimap, decenet amount of loot, auto ammo/health pickup, Golden chest and much more!
More people You'll bring with Y'a, more Fun You'll have in this game, a lot of things to do together!

-----
There is plenty issues with this Version as well,
- Once You've been in 1 Session for long, it starts becoming laggy mess - At some point You are most likely to Re-start Your game, load up Your save and continue.
- In Co-op / Multiplayer there been issues with the Minimap as well, sometimes it's just doesn't load in For Co-op / Multiplayer player(s) - Stays black in few maps.
- Game randomly likes to put Custom Waypoints everytime and everywhere. 
- Mission waypoints might be bugged for other player(s) in Your game sessions - Luckly fine for Host.
- Few smaller things as well. | A great action rpg.It is difficult early on but once you start doing side quests/optional missions it becomes fairly easy. You have to continuously change your inventory as you keep getting bigger and better guns.Graphics are ok as it is 15 years old game and I donâ€™t see any better graphics even in enhanced edition.Final boss was barely any challenge. Shooting feels like lagging and not much fun. I have played borderlands 1 2 3 and this one is my favourite of them all.Remember itâ€™s a rpg game mixed with first person shooter so you may not like it if you are only looking for pure first person shooters like doom or wolfenstein. I will give it 8/10. | Highly addictive gameplay and best in class game that feels great to play even in 2025 and I have played the other two and somehow this feels better and more stable. | The age of the game was a slight issue, the multiplayer was too hard to play with the lag and there was a lot of clipping. Still a fun looter shooter FPS that was worth the time invested, although I feel like I had my fill and don't need to play anymore.

Game Name: STAR WARSâ„¢: The Force Unleashedâ„¢ II
Reviews: Great game, botched PC port. Expect lots of crashes and having to download FPS unlocking patches. | The Force Unleashed games are peak Star Wars and will ALWAYS be better than the Fallen Order / Jedi Survivor, despite how badly they are intentionally neglected to prop up the new trash. Sadly this game has garbage optimisation on Steam and should be banned from sale. It is locked at 30fps, screen tears horribly and on-screen prompts fail to scale properly so they're tiny to read. Totally unacceptable. Refund. Stay away. | While the Force Unleashed 1 would have been a great stand alone title its follow up not only leave much to be desired in terms of length it also falls into the "to never be completed" era of star wars along with the original battlefront 3.  The story is painfully short, the boss fights minimum and the game overall feels like a its the middle of a story that once again is never going to be finished.  The PC port is also missing the DLC endor mission that the 360 & PS3 had access to so its also an incomplete package.  I also had issues getting the game to run on Windows 10 and it was impossible for me to run on windows 11. | GOAT game, I always liked it more than the first game, beautiful environments and fun physics. crashes on windows every 20 min, runs fine on steam deck w/ cutscene issues.  I never cared much for star wars outside of TFU games, I find the movies too plain and childish, afraid to ever be too dark or violent. however these games hold up really well | A great sequel to the first game! The story is interesting, the game play somewhat challenging but not overly difficult, and the music is fantastic. This game captures that authentic Star Wars feel perfectly! Even though some parts of the plot are a bit weak, the overarching story is fun to play through, and the final boss battle is well worth it. Give this game a shot!

Portal 2 is one of the best puzzle games ever created. It combines logical thinking, physics-based mechanics, and an engaging story. The game takes place in Aperture Science, a mysterious and dangerous laboratory filled with test chambers. The player controls Chell, a silent protagonist who must escape using the Portal Gun. This device allows players to create two linked portals on surfaces, making it possible to teleport and solve puzzles.

One of the most impressive aspects of Portal 2 is its level design. Each test chamber introduces new mechanics, forcing players to think creatively. The game starts with simple puzzles but gradually becomes more complex. Elements like light bridges, propulsion gel, and lasers add depth to the challenges. The difficulty curve is perfect, making the game enjoyable for both beginners and experienced players.

Portal 2 also stands out with its story and humor. The main antagonist, GLaDOS, is a sarcastic and witty AI who constantly insults and manipulates the player. Wheatley, a clumsy and funny robot, adds another layer of comedy. Their dialogues make the game more entertaining and memorable. Despite its humor, the story also explores themes of control, identity, and artificial intelligence.

Another great feature of Portal 2 is its cooperative mode. Unlike the single-player campaign, co-op requires teamwork and communication. Players control two robots, Atlas and P-Body, solving puzzles that require coordination. This mode enhances the experience, making it even more enjoyable when played with a friend.

Overall, Portal

Ğ”Ğ»Ñ Ñ‚ĞµÑ… Ğ¶Ğµ, ĞºÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ‚ ĞµÑ‰Ğµ Ğ¿ĞµÑ€Ğ²ÑƒÑ Ğ²ÑÑ‚Ñ€ĞµÑ‡Ñƒ Ğ“ĞµÑ€Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒÑ‚Ğ° Ğ¸ Ğ¤Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒÑ‚ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ° Ğ¸ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¶ĞµÑ‚ Ğ±ĞµĞ· Ğ·Ğ°Ğ¿Ğ¸Ğ½ĞºĞ¸ Ğ´ĞµÑÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ· Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ²Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¸Ğ¼Ñ Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ»ÑŒÑ„Ğ³Ğ°Ğ°Ñ€Ğ´ÑĞºĞ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¿ĞµÑ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ° Ğ­Ğ¼Ğ³Ñ‹Ñ€Ğ° Ğ²Ğ°Ñ€ Ğ­Ğ¼Ñ€ĞµĞ¹ÑĞ°, Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ½ĞµÑ‚ ÑĞ°Ğ¼Ñ‹Ğ¼ Ğ½Ğ°ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ÑÑ‰Ğ¸Ğ¼ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ°Ñ€ĞºĞ¾Ğ¼. | "The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings" is a critically acclaimed RPG that builds upon the strong foundation laid by its predecessor, offering a deeper, more refined experience. Released in 2011 by CD Projekt Red, the game is set in a dark and gritty world full of political intrigue, moral ambiguity, and complex characters. It follows Geralt of Rivia, a skilled monster hunter, as he becomes entangled in a conspiracy involving the assassination of kings and the fate of the entire continent. The gameâ€™s story is rich and engaging, with choices that truly matter, allowing players to shape the narrative in meaningful ways.

One of the most striking features of "The Witcher 2" is its branching storyline. The game offers multiple paths depending on the choices players make, particularly during key moments. This results in different quests, character interactions, and even entire endings. The world feels alive and reactive, and the playerâ€™s decisions carry weight, making each playthrough potentially unique. This level of player agency is one of the gameâ€™s greatest strengths, as it provides a deep sense of involvement in the unfolding drama.

The combat in "The Witcher 2" is fast-paced and strategic. Unlike many RPGs that rely heavily on simple hack-and-slash mechanics, this game requires players to think tactically. Geralt uses a combination of swords, magic, and alchemy to defeat his enemies, and mastering each of these elements is key to surviving tougher battles. The game also features challenging boss fights that demand careful planning and quick reflexes. While it can be difficult at times, the combat feels rewarding, and successfully defeating a tough opponent provides a real sense of accomplishment.

The world-building in "The Witcher 2" is exceptional. The gameâ€™s settings are varied, from war-torn battlefields to lush forests, crumbling castles, and bustling cities. Each area feels unique, with its own culture, history, and lore. The attention to detail is remarkable, and the game does an excellent job of immersing players in its world. The character design is similarly impressive, with a cast of memorable individuals that are morally complex and believable. The gameâ€™s voice acting, writing, and character development all contribute to making the world feel lived-in and full of depth.

Another standout aspect of "The Witcher 2" is its mature and morally gray storytelling. The game doesnâ€™t offer simple good-versus-evil narratives; instead, it explores themes of power, betrayal, and the consequences of one's actions. Many of the choices players face are morally ambiguous, and thereâ€™s no clear "right" or "wrong" answer. This makes the game feel more grounded in reality, where actions often have unintended consequences, and characters are rarely just one-dimensional.

While the gameâ€™s graphics were impressive for its time, itâ€™s the overall atmosphere and attention to detail that truly stand out. The soundtrack enhances the experience, with a score that captures the tone of the game perfectly, whether itâ€™s a haunting melody during a quiet moment or a fast-paced theme during combat.

"The Witcher 2" is a game that appeals to players who enjoy a more mature and complex narrative. Its story, world-building, and choice-driven gameplay make it one of the best RPGs of its generation. Itâ€™s a game that rewards exploration and thoughtful decision-making, and it challenges players to consider the deeper consequences of their actions. With its engaging combat, morally complex characters, and immersive world, "The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings" remains a standout title in the RPG genre.

Son derece keyifli, hikayesi sÃ¼rÃ¼kleyici, grafikleri bugÃ¼nden bakÄ±nca bile etkileyici bir yapÄ±m. OynayÄ±n, oynatÄ±n. | [b][h1]The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings[/h1][/b]
[hr][/hr]
[h2]+[/h2]

[b][i][h1]Graphics[/h1][/i]
The game has stood the test of time and still looks great almost 14 years later

[i][h1]Original books references[/h1][/i]
The game has many references to events from the books and some interesting characters that the CD gave new life to by adding them to the game and I like so much

[i][h1]Story[/h1][/i]
I really liked the story, it was very interesting and intriguing for me

[i][h1]2 times[/h1][/i]
2 times. You have to finish the game 2 times to see whole content. In the game, at the end of Act 1, you will have to make a choice that will affect the further story. Because of this choice, we have a two completely different Act 2. I mean completely different locations, characters, quests, etc. How many games like this do you know?

[i][h1]Characters[/h1][/i]
Geralt, Triss, Dandelion, Zoltan, Roche, Iorweth.. They are cool

[i][h1]Side quests[/h1][/i]
Here you will see a lot of good side quests in the game and I don't remember of a single bad one. I'm serious here. I really don't remember a single bad side quest in the game[/b]
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Â±[/h2]

[b][i][h1]Music[/h1][/i]
The ambient is beautiful, I really liked it very much. About OST.. There is not much OST in The Witcher 2. And among this small number there is a really good OST but there is very little of it and hearing the same OST every time in the same location throughout the entire act is a bit disappointing[/b]
[hr][/hr]
[h2]-[/h2]

[b][i][h1]NPCs[/h1][/i]
They are not alive. They do not have their own daily routine as it was in The Witcher 1. They either sleep or stand in the same place and do the same animation

[i][h1]Broken economy[/h1][/i]
The traders here are richest people in the world because they sell things for some unrealistic prices, but you sell them for pennies, and it doesn't matter if it's trash or one of the best armor in the game. You really have to grind(kill monsters and sell them for nothing) if you WANT to buy recipes and craft armor set that appears on higher difficulty in each act. I only lasted for two acts. Not for me

[i][h1]Combat System[/h1][/i]
Absolutely broken. Set traps for a few seconds [i]during[/i] combat? Traps that Geralt should set before combat? Yes. Enemies block your attacks without block animation? Yes. Enemies ignore your attacks and continue their attack animation and kill you? Yes. CD in one of the updates disabled health regen during Quen, thinking that it was better? YES. Bad QTE? Yes. Bombs and knives are OP? Yes. I wouldn't say that these problems greatly affect the gameplay and perception of the game, but the fact that they exist is annoying. The combat system in The Witcher 1 was much better

[i][h1]Tons of cut content[/h1][/i]
Typical CD Projekt[/b]
[hr][/hr]
[b][h2]9/10[/h2] | Most people said that TW3: Wild Hunt is more enjoyable if you've played the first two games first. After doing so, that most certainly isn't the case. These felt kind of like a waste of time overall, I'd say you're good just playing the third if you're unsure of where to start. 

The main reason I went back and played the first two Witcher games was because I started a playthrough of TW3 and felt like I was so behind on the lore and characters of the universe. I kept encountering characters that the journal said Geralt had met in previous adventures until finally I decided to cut my losses 50+ hrs in and complete the first two games first before returning. 

But both stories in the first games are fairly inconsequential. TW1 is definitely unnecessary, only giving you a glimpse of who Geralt and a few of his closest friends are while pursuing a criminal organization. TW2 shows the political state of the kingdoms just before the third game, and some brief flashbacks into Geralt's forgotten past before his amnesia, but that's it. 

None of the characters I'd thought were in the first games like Ciri, Yennefer, Keira Metz, Sigismund Dijkstra, the two people burning at the stake in a certain city that the journal says Geralt knew, etc, are even in them. Okay, maybe one of the people burning at the stake is at least in TW2 but they were just a merchant near the end of the game with one line of dialogue, at least in my playthrough. They had no role in the story at all. I'm left to assume most of the story I thought I missed out on is in the books, not the earlier games.

So I gained nothing from playing this. On top of that the games were kind of boring. Dialogue was decent but even compared to the first game TW2 was disappointing. TW1 impressed me more in some ways. 

The quests felt more involved in TW1, where simply following what we were being directed to do in the journal could lead to screwing ourselves over. I often had to think, and pay attention to what someone said earlier for a clue on how to properly move forward. Nearly every time I made progress during a quest, I could chat with a character I knew who would have new dialogue for me, unlike TW2. Sometimes we could talk to a character other than the one on our objectives for a better outcome. Here everything is just straightforward, follow the next objective, no thinking required. 

Romances in TW1 felt more rewarding and the opportunities were much more numerous. I didn't even pursue them and ran into quite a few. It felt like a mini-game of its own since there were romance cards to collect. Looting also felt more important, whereas in TW2 we just get a bunch of crafting items/herbs I never even used. Most of it I just sold since I had so much with no use for it. And not being able to select the loot individually felt dumbed-down. Potions felt ineffective in TW2 and having to predict when I might need them was annoying since we could only consume them while meditating, so luckily they could be largely ignored on "Normal" difficulty. 

I could describe a bunch of other things that TW1 did better, but also some things in TW2 just weren't as much of a step forward as I'd expected. There weren't many choices I made in the game that I felt made a difference later down the line. The game failed to introduce a sufficient number of interesting characters throughout the story; there are very few worth remembering. Contracts were also very scarce and simplistic. The monster variety was severely lacking, mostly just Nekkers, Endregas, Harpies, and occasional Rotfiends. Gear still felt minimalistic in that it wasn't impressive-looking and there wasn't much to be found in the entire game. The variety in areas the game takes you to isn't there either, it's just 3 different locations all of which are boring: a swamp outpost, a muddy camp, and some old ruins. The game basically all happens in settlements, like the first game.

Also TW2 is a short game, only 36 hours and I took my sweet time + read all the journal/character/location/monster entries.  It's really only better than the TW1 in graphics and combat, and the TW1 wasn't a great game either. 

Both of these are like a 7/10 for me. Enjoyable enough to make it through one full playthrough, but I've no desire to ever play them again. Hopefully TW3 actually lives up to the hype, and I'll at least have some characters appear in it which will help make the time spent here worthwhile when I import my save to it.
