ç½‘ä¸Šæ²¡ä»€ä¹ˆæ”»ç•¥ï¼Œä½ å”¯ä¸€çš„å…¨é¢æ”»ç•¥å°±æ˜¯WIKIï¼Œä½†æ˜¯å®˜ç½‘æ²¡æœ‰ä¸­æ–‡ç¿»è¯‘ï¼Œåªèƒ½é ä½ æµè§ˆå™¨è‡ªå¸¦çš„ç½‘é¡µç¿»è¯‘ï¼Œå¦‚æœä½ çš„ç½‘é€Ÿä¸å¿«ï¼Œé‚£è¿™å¯èƒ½æ˜¯ä¸€ç§æŠ˜ç£¨ã€‚
å¦‚æœä½ æ—¶é—´ä¸å……è£•ï¼Œé‚£ä½ ä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½ä¼šè·Ÿè¿™ä¸ªæ¸¸æˆæ— ç¼˜ï¼Œå°±åƒå‰é¢è¯´çš„ï¼Œå¦‚æœè¿™ä¸ªæ¸¸æˆç©è¿›å»äº†ï¼Œé‚£çœŸçš„ä¼šä¸Šç˜¾ï¼ | I tried really hard to like this game(as you can see from my playtime), but I wouldn't say that pretty much any of it was particularly fun. I tried to stick it out because I know a couple of friends that swear by it, but as of the time of writing this I would describe my time with the game as an abusive relationship I was always hoping would get better.

I spent hours improving my character, building wealth and equipment and skills, trying to learn and get better at the game, and all I have to show for it is frustration and misery. Even after almost 4 dozen hours playing the game the only thing I can reliably accomplish is fighting the enemies in the starting zone.

Lemme give you an example to explain my frustration with this game:
So I decided I wanted to be a hybrid melee caster, kind've lean into a paladin-esque build. So I go to the magic place where you can gain the ability to cast magic: At the cost of maximum health and stamina, permanently. Okay, I'll just trade a little bit for a little mana, since I won't be using a lot. Then I do a cross country adventure to learn the ability to bless my weapon with holy lightning- sweet! Costs 12 mana. But uh.. Sleeping reduces your maximum mana by up to half. Sleeping by the way, is the most reliable way to recover from losing maximum health/stamina from consuming those resources, so as a melee character you tend to need to sleep. A lot. So my 20 mana is always 10. Not enough to cast the spell- but even if it were, the spell can only be cast if I have another buff which costs me ~8 mana. So any amount of sleep makes me unable to cast my spell without using consumables to get my mana back. Oh, and if you happen to die(Which you will, a lot) that reduces your maximum health/stamina down to ~25% until you sleep or use consumables. I spent 40 minutes farming consumables to try and actually use my abilities, and burned through them in 5 minutes to a series of deaths and being dropped in worse locations after those deaths and was left with nothing to show for that nearly hour of gameplay. Skill issue? Absolutely. That said I've had these spells for over 10 hours of gameplay and I've used them less than ten times because I NEVER have mana. Now sure, I could go DOUBLE my mana and then be able to use my skills one time for every time I fully heal but those skills aren't powerful enough to justify MORE permanent loss of health and stamina.

My only option at this point is to go back to the starting zone where I can confidently win fights and grind money for hours to upgrade my gear and buy new skills OR go spend two hours running around avoiding fighting anything so I can use one of the cheese strats to build up money until I have everything I want but based on my experience so far even if I had the best armor and all the skills I'd probably still lose all my gear to a "your stuff got stolen lol" death event the first time I dared to fight anything that isn't a bandit with a machete. I'm at the point where I have no expectation of enjoyment, and only expect the game to abuse me every time I try to push outside my comfort zone, and I'd rather just play a game that doesn't skill check me every few minutes and then punish me by making me weaker, burning my consumables, half the time dropping me somewhere harder than the place that just killed me, and OCCASIONALLY taking my valuables and hiding them somewhere I need to google and then fight through when I fail one of those skill checks. | The formula that this game follows tricks you when you step into it, it seems to be a vast expansive world where a different adventure and story is behind every door, or mountain. But in my 80 hours of playing this I have found myself sorely disappointed in this game due to its vast shallowness. Every quest is the exact same, every humanoid enemy is the same, and all the monsters or animals are exceedingly annoying. When i first played i was excited to play a game with souls-like combat, and survival mechanics but as I played on i realized that these two were done moronically bad. The combat gets more and more annoying when you realize that every enemy is essentially at least a mini boss if you're in the right area, taking far too much health to form any type of pattern recognition for their attacks, leaving you dead. But no not even the sweet release of death can be granted to you, you are teleported on a giant map with multiple debuffs, and a realization of all the load screens you're gonna have to go through before you fight the a boss again is waaaay to long if you want to play this game at a good pace and continue working a full time job. This game loves wasting your time which i would love if i wasn't doing the same thing over and over again with little difference even when i progress. 

I shall say though that I had some things i did love about the game, the maps was well done, by not having a character marker it escalated the feel of the adventure and your knowledge of the map. And mixed with loot being abundant and in EVERY corner gives you that feeling of paving your own path through the world.

In conclusion outward is a vast but shallow waste of your time, do not buy this game if you have responsibillities, if you don't then this game will be right up your alley. | Jogo muito bom 10/10

A Love Letter to the Ninth Art â€“ A Middle-Aged Player's 100-Hour Journey Through Baldur's Gate 3

As someone nearing forty, with both elderly parents and young children to care for, finding large chunks of time to sit in front of a computer and savor a game is no easy feat. This Spring Festival, I made up my mind to finally taste this cup of coffee that had been brewing for years. With the understanding and support of my wife (for which I am deeply grateful), I managed to carve out a week to indulge in uninterrupted play. After 99 hours and 40 minutes, I completed the game. Sitting in front of the screen late at night, I was left in awe, unable to shake the profound impact it had on me. This journey will undoubtedly remain one of the most unforgettable experiences of my life, a radiant milestone in my personal gaming history.

What Larian has created here is far from an ordinary video game.

As a game, every design element is seamlessly integrated, perfectly balanced. The freedom it offers is almost overwhelmingâ€”you can truly be yourself. The equipment, levels, and stats are meticulously crafted, catering to a broad spectrum of players.

As music, Down by the River drifts with the breeze, becoming a flowing narrative. I Want to Live tears at your soul during moments of decision, and The Power resonates as you grasp the prism in victory. Each theme song fits its scene so perfectly that it transcends the medium, transforming into an interactive symphonic poem that I found myself revisiting and reflecting on long after the game had ended.

As a novel, the content itself is a masterful piece of fantasy literature. The writers clearly possess the skill to craft a best-selling fantasy novel. Themes of justice versus evil, life versus death, and killing versus sparing provoke deep philosophical reflection. If watching a movie in a theater is like spending 2.5 hours appreciating a thought-provoking film, then Baldur's Gate 3 is like spending over 100 hours living a tumultuous, magical life filled with difficult choices and moral dilemmas.

I named my final save file in the camp, where I chatted with everyone before the end, "Do Not Want to Say Farewell." After journeying together, sharing both hardships and triumphs with these friends and comrades, I truly wished we could continue living together. I exhausted every dialogue option in the camp, searching for more interactions, especially with Shadowheart, whose seven or eight hugs still lingered with the warmth of data. I couldnâ€™t bear to say goodbye. Yet, Larian, in their cruel yet merciful way, allowed each companion to move forward with their scarsâ€”some destined to carry the stars on their shoulders, others to return to the mundane life of hearth and home. This, perhaps, is the most tender form of realism: all encounters must eventually be returned to the passage of time.

Thus, my Dungeons & Dragons tale has been sealed in the evening breeze of the Sword Coast. In this lifetime, I will return to experience the lives of Astarion and other characters. Perhaps this is the greatness of CRPGs: they allow us, in the crevices of our real lives, to live countless versions of ourselves we never had the chance to be.

While there are some criticisms and suggestions for improvement regarding BG3, they are minor blemishes on an otherwise flawless gem. Some aspects could indeed be tweaked for player convenience, while others are subjective preferences rather than flaws.

Once youâ€™ve spent 10-15 hours learning the gameâ€™s mechanics and fundamental principles, crossing that threshold, you canâ€™t help but marvel at how Larian managed to create such a masterpiece. If this work remains unrivaled, itâ€™s because it is truly exquisite and deserves to be cherished. If it is ever surpassed, then another jewel will have been added to the annals of gaming history, another gift for us all.

Thank you, Larian. | The replayability of this game is insane, Larian did an amazing job giving us exactly what we wanted and maybe even a little more. This game has taken over my life and I love it so much, lol, and showing no signs of putting it down any time soon! | This is probably going to be one of the best games for the next decade, the voice acting is sublime and the writers seemed to have made deals with the devil in order to make such a good tale. 10/10 | I started playing this game a year and a few months after it was launched and immediately got into character creation which took me over an hour not to mention building my Dream Guardian. Since purchasing it at full price, I was weary to buy a game for 60 bucks, but it has been the best 60 bucks I've spent in a LONG time. 

The whole game itself doesn't hold your hand during the game, but it does help you build up your skills and learn how to play as you go which is great for those who haven't played CRPG turn based game before. I have basically played this nonstop since October to pass time and as you can see with my 527 hours on record, I absolutely LOVE this game. The options for responses and endings are endless. I'm thoroughly blown away with the voice acting and, yes, the mod options. There are many people who hate playing with mods, but to me it adds a lot to the game and enhances my game play experience making me want to play it more. I have done numerous campaigns and as of January 2025, I'm doing my 2nd durge campaign trying to play a somewhat evil character which is hard as I've cried from being evil to pixels haha. 

Overall, I think this game may be the best game I've ever played and I love how Larian and the VA's show their active participation in the community along with Larian giving us FREE updates and gives modders the toolkit. This company could've charged $100 or more for this game with the amount of work and thought put into it along with the (again) FREE updates, but they didn't. They have shown they care more for the player's experience and making a game that out beats other new games and certain *ahem developers AHEM Bethesda* by giving us a game that is completed at release (from what I've been told by other gamers who played this at release). I recommend this game to anyone who wants a rich, fulfilling game that doesn't have any extra catches outside the initial price. | I have played this game for 6 hours (2h on character creator), never played this type of game before.. can say I am impressed and enjoying it a lot.

18 hours in the game: I think that I'm addicted. The stories are surprising and wholesome. I feel like a hero in this game, living for the good of the people.

50 hours: I finally finished act 1. And oh boy did I turn from good to evil with every step I took. I didn't mean to be... How was I supposed to know that pulling the wrong lever, I'll be catapulting a gnome to space. That wasn't my fault.

80 hours: Yes! Give me your gold. All the shiny trinkets you have. Give me your soul and all the power you hold. Give me more... MORE!

100 hours: How dare you look down on me, thinking like you could ever defeat me?! Hit me with all you got, it will never be enough!

120 hours: ... *only screams echo in the darkness* ...

130 hours: *Muahahaha-*
You may call me the blood queen,
but your agenda is also driven by greed.
The battle you lost, your advisors lied.
Your heroes are dead, your city is mine.
No evil as dark or vengeance as red,
have never been seen as I took the kings head.

Espero que SOLASTA II seja muito melhor que esse em tudo e venha com legendas PT-BR. | 9/10.
Solasta feels like playing a good campaign of DnD with your friends, just without the friends and the bad jokes. Or good jokes, depending on your group, I guess.
Yes, the game doesn't look amazing and sometimes controls or the camera can be slightly clunky, but the gameplay is great. The story is nice, the characters interesting, combat is great. Solasta is challenging and tbh the final fight is unnecessarily hard, but other than that the game is/was so enjoyable to me that I'll probably get the DLCs soon and start another run before Solsata II releases.
Definitely recommend!

Game Name: The Bard's Tale IV: Director's Cut
Reviews:
Bards tale in name but not in play.  This is 75 percent puzzle.  Even the fights are puzzles.  I wouldn't recommend unless thats your thing.  Its put together well.  The music is good but there are popping sounds.  Massive fps drops at times, especially around water | Of course this is fun.  A well made RPG that has a different flavor.  Exploration in First person with turn based fighting in encounters you can see and avoid sometimes or charge in to get the first attacks.  Its different than the old Dungeon Crawlers that started the franchise.  It is not like the isometric one either before this sequel.  It is its own game, and I have been enjoying it because it has good voice acting and an alright story with some crafting.   If you like old school or turn based RPGs you will probably like this hybrid.  While it starts out kind of slow, stick with it and as you learn songs it gets more fun as you go.   Pay attention to the surroundings, because hidden secrets are everywhere.  I think its a great sequel.  Just expect something different than the past games.  I like the combat animations and the fight comments are funny as you taunt and use your strategy and figure out how to defeat your enemies.  REMEMBER to save often.  It has a nice save feature that allows you to save anywhere , I am guessing was not original equipment lolz.  Worth the money for the fun It made me have. | Fun game with an old school vibe. I never played the classic games so no opinion on how it stands up as a sequel, but I enjoyed this on it's own. The puzzles are fun and not excessively difficult, though they get pretty repetitive after awhile, so I was very grateful for the puzzle skip option. The graphics are pretty dated, which might be deliberate to keep with the old school feel. Either way I stopped noticing after a couple of hours. Took me about 50 hours being pretty thorough, but there's lots of skippable side quests and it'll go even faster if you use the puzzle skip the whole way through. The music is excellent. I don't love turn-based combat but it's pretty fun once you get the hang of it. I did have a couple of crashes during combat, and got momentarily stuck on the landscape more than a few times, but never encountered any gamebreaking issues. Overall a great game. | Ğ“Ñ€Ğ° Ğ½Ğ° 6/10.

I still want to like this game. It's not that it could have been so much more, it's not that the 4x and combat elements are still too disconnected. It's quite simply that the actual gameplay is not fun. 
The case study that prompted me to write this review:
I'm playing a greedy game where I'm the only civ on my relatively large continent. I pick England and build Strongholds in various strategic locations. I own the whole continent and have lots of tech and buildings but a fairly small army - just enough to strongly defend a single attack point. I begin building ships to explore the world. I finally encounter another civ, then another. The world congress begins almost immediately. One of the civs demands 2000 gold from me. I naturally refuse. They push the issue to congress. I don't have an embassy yet, so I can't do anything about that, but fine. They won't be able to break into my continent. They pillage one of my two harbors. This gives them enough warscore to enforce peace, get the 2000 gold plus another 2400 gold for war reparations. I'm in bankruptcy. I work my way out of it. They demand 2000 gold again and now I can't refuse because my people don't want war.
What is the gameplay here? Pillaging a single district is enough to instantly end a war and enforce demands strong enough to cripple the enemy until you can immediately send more demands and declare war again? The war didn't even last long enough for me to attempt to fight it. I wouldn't mind if they enforced demands after they had landed a force and begun sieging my cities or thoroughly pillaged my entire coastline, but it was one single district. Honestly most games seem to end with one stupid mistake or lucky break, which is already not that fun, but you throw mechanics like that in and it just isn't worth trying anymore. | æ…ç©ã€‚è§£å†³äº†æ–‡æ˜ç³»åˆ—çš„å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†é—®é¢˜ï¼Œå‚è€ƒäº†æ–‡æ˜ç³»åˆ—çš„0é¡¹ä¼˜ç‚¹ã€‚ | I love this game. Unfortunately, I cannot recommend this game to anyone. The game is built on a great idea, features an interesting story, and has quite beautiful environments and biomes. It feels rewarding to build a base and progressively improve your gear. However, the game has an incredible number of bugs that make it feel like a complete waste of time.

Many missions require you to build a base and upgrade your character before even starting the actual task. When you find out, after 1â€“3 hours of preparation, that itâ€™s impossible to activate a scanner or otherwise interact with the mission objectives, youâ€™re left with no choice but to start over. A survival game like this is unplayable with so many game-breaking bugs, and itâ€™s disappointing that the developers havenâ€™t managed to fix these fundamental issues even three years after release. | About 100 hrs in, playing solo, and I am really enjoying the game. It is a fun survival game. 
Min Maxing can be part of the journey if you like, I do. You get to have pets. Like that. It is more about loot management than being a loot goblin. Very Good. The building is pretty good. I have only found a couple of mechanics that seem truly unfair, like wall torches. The wall torch shouldn't be a time bomb for burning down you cabin. They should be a fiber, stone, dirt and sap sconce that if you somehow bump it won't burst everything into flames. That's just dumb. I accidentally backed up onto a bench trying to place a bench and burnt down a cabin. All in all it is fun and I love being able to see the Tech Tree and Talents in the lobby and out of game. I am pretty sure I will keep playing this game for quite a while. | This game is a lot of fun. I am a Gen X mom who plays with my teenager. I love catching the creatures and taming them and then riding them all over. The collaborative game play is really fun because you have to help each other to succeed.
 | i was prepared to die many times before getting the hang of it, and as soon as i started surviving it became so much fun to play. exploring is fun, encountering wildlife is fun, farming is fun, and theres enough tools and skills to obtain that reduce the amount of grinding it takes. some of the bugs and glitches are a bummer to encounter, but i enjoy the game too much to stop because of them. that being said, i think its good to read the reviews of several people to get a good idea if its a game for you. it definitely is the game for me | O jogo Ã© muito mal otimizado, mesmo tendo um pc maquinado o jogo consegue entregar BAIXÃSSIMOS FPS's, eu sinceramente gostei do jogo, da gameplay, oque mata Ã© que o jogo Ã© EXTREMAMENTE mal otimizado, triste.

This is a terrible game. I had a lot of fun playing the first chapter of the game with my brother. My god is this a glitchy game. My favourite part of the game was the song in the first chaper, me and my brother have memorized it. 

On the second chapter we were completely lost. We started finding so many bugs in the game and getting in areas we shouldn't be able to. We started to give up solving the mystery and instead started playing around with the bugs, which was the best part of that chapter. 

The third chapter wasn't memorable. It looked nice though. | Fun! I enjoyed the puzzles!

Enshrouded, as an Early Access title, does some things well and some not so well, but it is all subject to change. We'll see how things go over the next few years. Overall, it's fun enough, and the developers have been very forthcoming with game additions and are also very open and responsive to player feedback. This game does Early Access right.

Pros:
-Gorgeous visuals
-Gorgeous world, procedurally-generated and then lovingly populated with hand-crafted locations
-Incredible, detailed and interesting dungeons to delve through, filled with puzzles and environment hazards
-Beautiful, if inconsistent, armor and weapon designs, which are fun to collect.
-A fairly robust building system, with benefits to decorating and constructing a base that you then populate with craftspeople and villagers
-Simple, but satisfying combat
-A leveling system that revolves around perks instead of stat increases (though you can still boost your stats from the perk tree)
-Dedicated cosmetic slots for your armor, with options to hide both your headgear and your gloves
-Fully cosmetic clothing sets to find behind exploration and bosses
-A food-based buff system, wherein the food you eat increases your stats and stat regeneration
-Lots of lore to discover through characters, locales, obelisks and books throughout the world
-Highly customizable game settings, including the ability to turn off weapon and tool durability or turn on starvation mechanics

Cons:
-The bonuses from armor and weapons are largely pointless, or too small to make much of a difference. Some are even entirely pointless, such as one set that offers a small 10-20% bonus to unarmed damage, with unarmed attacks dealing only 8 damage to enemies (when your mace is doing over 400 per swing, and swings faster than your fists)
-There are tons of weapons, but there are very little differences between weapons of the same class: All one-handed weapons use the same three-swing combo, regardless of what the weapon actually is, and even legendary items don't have anything to differentiate them outside of their raw damage and visuals
-The few weapons with "unique" effects are things like 5% lifesteal, 1 point of health regen, or some bonus critical chance and damage. None of the weapons are build-defining or unique in any meaningful way. For example, the "Dragon Sword", found only one hidden place and tied to a piece of esoteric lore found in your travels, just adds a flat +7 fire damage... Five times in a row. The Dragon Sword is a weapon with nothing going for it except minuscule damage bonuses that don't even interact with your perks.
-Extremely linear item and location progression: New areas are blocked off by "Deadly Shroud," a gas that simply kills you if you haven't leveled up your base enough yet (using the heads of bosses and regional materials). Essentially, your ability to explore the "open world" aspect of the game is heavily restricted by boss progression.
-Heavily reused enemies with very limited attack variety
-The magic system is bland, being exclusively ranged elemental attacks and two healing spells. There is no utility magic to speak of, outside of a single knockback spell
-The perks you gain from leveling are very restrictive in what they affect, very strictly confining their offerings to their respective stat tree (Strength, Intelligence, Dexterity) with very little overlap
-Every quest is a fetch or kill quest with some lore sprinkled around it. "Skyrim quest" is how I would describe them: Talk to a person, go to a place, get a thing, repeat until you run out of quests | I have played for about 800 hrs. The story is interesting, and the game is definitely playable solo. I completed the game, through level 35 as a solo player with out much problem. Some things take longer (i.e. Hollow Halls), but nothing is impossible to complete. The group play is pretty good too, though there are currently performance issue, though not surprising since this in in EA. There is also no in-game chat (text or voice), but I found a group of people, and we were able to overcome it using Discord. Used basic building blocks in-game to write out Discord info.

I absolutely love the building system. Though it could use work with camera control and additional options (round shapes), the building potential is endless. Of my almost 800 hrs of play, at least 600 has been spent building.

I highly recommend this game for anyone who likes survival/building games! | Started playing this on steam deck non oled version and it plays and runs great straight out of the box. This should be verified and not unsupported | çµè«–ã‹ã‚‰ã„ã†ã¨é¢ç™½ã„

This game gets a lot of hate, because people compare it to Origins, but even though it's a sequel, I don't think it should be compared to Origins. Origins is an epic-fantasy-good-vs-evil quest, whereas DA2 is political thriller where everything is a shade of gray. No major characters are 100% good or innocent. 

The writing is great, the characters are compelling (even when they're annoying) and the moral dilemmas are even harder than those of Origins. If you like a good story, play this game (after having played Origins). 

If you like complex combat, epic quests and big world exploration, and don't care about the plot too much, then you can skip this one. The game is not without flaws, but the flaws shouldn't make us overlook everything that's good about it. | Even though you can tell it was rushed and they had to cut a lot of stuff they wanted to put it, this isprobably tied with Origins for best Dragon Age game to me, and definitely up there in my top 5 Bioware games. Hell, I'd even say it's in my top 5 EA games. Combat's a bit simple compared to origins, but it's still better than Inquisition's. And while the graphics aren't the best, it certainly has a unique charm. Also Anders did nothing wrong, 10/10 best romance. | Replayed this after YEARS! When I first played I didn't it as much. I used to think this was the weakest game in the series..... but after playing Veilguard I can definitely say I was too harsh on Dragon Age 2. | Decent Dragon Age (with some downgrades from the original) but an experience unfortunately flawed by many questionable gameplay mechanics.

Although theÂ story doesn't have the same epic scaleÂ as Origin'sÂ since (prologue aside) the whole game is set only in the city of Kirkwall and its surroundings, it is still quite interesting,Â with the characters and the cast probably being the best part of this Chapter.
There are some minor wtf moments towards the end (with the First Enchanter or with Grace, for instance), but nothing particularly game-breaking.
Qunari's plot and the mage vs templars dilemma were great.

I have to say that DA II is way more linear than the first game, and its quests and dialogues are not as complex in comparison so, given how Inquisition and Veilguard were also developed later on, I think it's safe to assume that Origin was the exception rather than the norm. It is still impressive nevertheless especially if you consider that Bioware worked on this only for one year and a half.

And it's worth noticing that this game has probably the best characters' design in the series since they kept most of the elements from Origin but also improved some others (they knocked it out of the park with the Qnari and the Darkspawns).

However, when it comes to gameplay, many poorly designed mechanics unfortunately detract a lot from the overall experience IMHO.
I'm not sure why there is this idea of Dragon Age 2's combat being an improvement over the first game when in fact, nothing could be farther from the truth. (Origin also had the coolest and most satisfying finishers in the business together with the first Dawn of War, Dragon Age 2 does not have any finishing moves).

Don't get me wrong some of the new visual effects are great, with mages that are as op as always and can shield your whole party with barriers and enchant your companions' weapons (lightening effects in particular are amazing now), but when it comes to mere mechanics we are talking about

1) Waves after waves of enemies spawning literally out of nowhere (sometimes in front of you out of thin air, sometimes even behind), which not only denies any possibility of a tactical approach to any fight but also makes the gameplay loop boring because from the prologue to the endgame, you can bet money on it, every combat encounter will be the same.

Another problem is (2) the camera angle because even the highest one now is way closer to the character than it was before (since the game is more action-oriented) and makes navigating with your party through the levels an absolute nightmare, especially in combat when you would want to give more instructions to your companions or kite around (and there are instances when you will be forced to do so, an example would be the boss fight against Corypheus). Also, some places are utterly broken like commands on stairs that do not register most of the time.

Now, once you combine those two elements with the fact that (3) most of the game is set in tight spaces and closed environments, you get the idea of some tragicomic encounters (like the ones in the Hightown's Estates when you kill enough bandits during the night and you can finally clear their base) where you have like 10 enemies spawning around you in a 10mq room for three or four times in a raw.

I also don't think that having a Genlock Alpha with a shield chasing you through a linear level or an Arcane horror (that can potentially kill your whole party with a single AoE spell) at the end of a 2m wide and very long corridor with archers and fire traps, are good examples of game design done right.

On nightmare difficulty, each enemy type gets immunity to one type of damage, either that be cold, fire, spirit damage, and so on (the good news is that you can change weapons in combat at any given moment), and the fact that friendly fire is on adds another interesting challenge.
However, since (4) the default AI for the companions is terrible too,
to the point that your number one priority becomes to change their tactics in the menu ASAP, and because of the reasons above (waves and camera), you are kinda left with the choice to either play a simplified version of the game (without immunities) that can become easily a mindless spam fest, or a challenging but frustrating and badly designed, experience.

There is very little in terms of enemy variety and many reused assets through the 3 acts. I didn't mind that much, but I can see how it could be a problem for some.

Assassins are completely broken.
You can't make potions on the fly but only at home or ordering them from some of the shops, which can be problematic in the DLC "Mark of the Assassin," where you are locked in a different area for a fair amount of time with at least two boss fights. Due to the design of the loot system, there is only a limited number of health potions available (5 IIRC) to loot. 

In general, I had the impression that Dragon Age 2 doesn't reward mechanical skills, reflexes, planning, or even some kind of memorization of the enemy's patterns (that is so fashionable nowadays since we are in the dark souls wannabe era), rather than the whole gameplay (for the reasons above) was just there to annoy me in between the progression of the story more than anything else. | I have this WEIRD bug where I can't romance Varric which is so weird becasue why wouldn't I be able to romance the coolest sexiest most charismatic character in the video game haha! (COWARDS).

EA servers down, again. i bought the game, i "own" the game, but i can't play it. Thanks EA.
serious pop in, broken quests, facial model rigs are still twitchy in loyalty missions, grindy as hell. i'm 40 hours in at 44% and i'm skipping sidequests. | They banked on the game's success and being able to do another trilogy, when unfortunately the game vastly under performed. Andromeda leans heavily into the exploration aspect of Mass Effect 1, which I find to be very divisive among fans, leading to a lot of people finding it extremely boring / tedious. The story seems watered down, the alien races are far less interesting, the companions were dry and the whole experience was just a drag to get through.

I have a slimmer of hope that the next mass effect title will be a return to form, though Andromeda was a huge step down when compared to the original trilogy. | This game is a B+ at worst. 

My actual playtime was ~50 hours. There's lots to love and a little to hate about MEA. First, the modding scene has fixed a lot of bugs, bad textures, the crummy car mechanics, and infinite inventory size unless inventory management is your idea of fun. It's a very inexpensive game on sale, but you make up for that with the time needed modding to polish up the gameplay and graphics. Fair deal! 

The combat presents a reasonable challenge and is entertaining. The game will sometimes punish you for running in guns blazing, which imo is a good thing. The number of weapons/mods and the combination crafting/purchase is dizzying: and here I think they've actually given the player too much choice. There are some hidden gems (sticky grenade bullets!) for those that want to play around with these systems, but it's not required.

I liked about half of my squad mates. They have been described as "discount" versions of the original ME trilogy, and that is mostly fair. Some core squad decisions here are bewildering -- why not swap out a human squad mate like Cora or Liam for a Salarian or ? But you can leave the squad mates you don't care for on the ship, except loyalty missions, with no ill effects. 

In the main mission you are up against the organic Borg. There's no other way to put it, your arch enemies for the game are generic, boring, and hold 0 surprises. They certainly don't carry the weight of the reapers.

RPG choices - AFAIK you don't make a single important choice. There is no renegade / paragon system. The weight and consequences of siding with the Krogan over the Salarians, or the Geth vs the Quarians, or the delicate balance required to gain everyone's support (or romance!) are all gone.

Speaking of romance, you lack great options male or female -- and courtship as far as I can tell is overly straightforward. 

The loyalty missions are excellent -- as are most "high point value" missions related to planetary effectiveness.

The final mission and epilogue is the lamest in the entire ME franchise by far. People angry with ME3's original ending will be FURIOUS with MEA. Lots of focus on the action set scenes, which were very cool, but no RA RA session prior to the mission, no impactful squad selection in mission, no weighty impact for your final decision.

Now a list of dumb game decision:
1. Underutilizing Radio / Vidcons. Way too many missions are "go here and talk to person". Waste of time.
2. No cool new aliens outside of the Angara
3. No intrigue. Ever. There's just no tension.
4. Unsatisfying explanation for the civil war / rebellion -- seems like half the people that arrived in Andromeda (theoretically the best of the best) just went nuts as soon as they landed. 
5. No special post ending scenes for your romance

Ğ’ Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼ ÑĞ»ÑƒÑ‡Ğ°Ğµâ€¦ Ğ½Ñƒ Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¾Ğµ. | Separating it from the series and not going into details, I can say that this is definitely not as bad as everyone says about it. In terms of gameplay, itâ€™s probably the best in the series, with both combat and exploration aspects done at a decent level. But it lacks what makes the original trilogy a great series. This applies to everything in the game: the characters, the world, and the plot. In conclusion, I can only say that this game helped me realize how great the original trilogy is, and how much we should appreciate what we had in our adventures in the Milky Way.
Still, it's not such a bad game; it's just that the original trilogy was on a whole different level.

 | I'd give it a 7/10

I had a lot of fun playing this game on my steamdeck while traveling but I will 100% say this game feels kind of unfinished and poorly balanced. A lot of my enjoyment was derived from trying to figure out how to win on the harder difficulties with each character in spite of the poor balancing. 

It's definitely a neat concept that I havent seen done before and I enjoyed discovering neat combinations of tiles on the map like Village + Vampire Manor = Vampire Town. But I wish there was more of that. There should be dozens and dozens of combinations and interactions, but there's really not. It feels like there's content waiting to be implemented but it just never came. 

It's got some soft "gambling" elements in that you can end runs early to cash in your treasure or you can always go for another loop or attempt a boss in an all-or-nothing kind of way. It's fun but frustrating in a not so great way. | La verdad es que este juego lo llevo jugando desde que salio, sin embargo lo jugaba pirateado en vieja pc, en cuanto mejore con respecto a pc lo primero que compre fue este juego y no eh parado de jugarlo. | Fantastic game and gorgeous visuals, normally not a fan of grindy games, but this feels like you make genuine progress every time you play

Tho one thing linux users should know, make sure compatibility layer uses the latest version of proton!

It wasnâ€™t at all what I expected when I got this game. It is very trade heavy with minimal combat or events. 
The gameplay is very Zen and hectic at the same time. Itâ€™s a mix of town-building and trading sim but is lacking slightly in both, and thereâ€™s way too many things to consider if you want to actively play it, I mean, this thing has about 10 tutorials for its mechanics. Overall if you like Zen games this is a good one otherwise skip it or buy on sale, I already donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll be playing any more of it after finishing Spanish campaign (thereâ€™s 3 more).
Overall score 6/10.
 | nice game | Fun game | c
Kyoto

It's nice having all three games not just remastered, but in one package. It's nice being able to relive one of the best video game RPGs and stories.  It's nice getting the old gang back together.

It's less nice getting to the end and knowing it's over.

It's even less nice knowing that the Bioware that created this no longer exists, and that we'll never get a game or story of this caliber out of Bioware ever again.

æ€»çš„æ¥è¯´æ˜¯å€¼å¾—ä¸€ä¸ªå¥½è¯„çš„ï¼Œå…¥æ‰‹æ¨èå²ä½ï¼Œå¦DLCé£è¯„è¿œä¸å¦‚æœ¬ä½“ï¼Œæ…å…¥ã€‚ | Against the Storm focuses on the best part of a city builder which is the first hours when you are in the building phase.  Against the Storm plays out differently every time because the buildings you start with are always different.   It is a well optimized game, with constant choices of risk vs reward, and enjoyable when you figure out work-arounds for meeting necessary resources, through supply chain management.

What I appreciate about Against the Storm is that there is never is a point where it gets too complicated with too much too deal with at one time.  The equivalent of the "Boss battle" is challenging and rewarding.  Graphic and sound design are excellent.

I've played over 650 hours and still not sick of it, so there must be something to this video game.  

Support these devs.  Eremite Games is a Polish developer consisting of six, and they really have created a real gem of a game, and they have been actively improving and polishing the game for more than a year after the day 1 release. | I genuinely started off liking Against the Storm, but the further you get into the difficulties the more tedious it gets, with additional negative modifiers and additional hoops to jump through to complete the session. Each seal completion really incentivizes you to play the next difficulty to get enough shards to complete the next seal to follow the metaplot, and lower difficulties may not get you the number of seals you need in time - additionally, the further out you go, the higher the minimum difficulty of the embarkment is, pushing the player to embark on those higher difficulty options. Why progress the seals other than metaplot? So you get more resources for the Citadel metaprogression. Which does things like add resources to your starting caravan so you can actually build some production buildings at the start, or adding a production building that let you make many key items - poorly, at high cost, but beneficial for the build chains so you are not fully reliant on RNG to get a building to complete the chain, or even adding bonuses to each race in your settlement like showing you where the first set of fields is where you can build a farm the first time you recruit a Human, so you don't have to spend half the session opening the wrong glades and never getting the constant food production that would provide. 

Except like many modern roguelite hybrids, this metaprogression is poorly balanced, and time consuming, which makes it feel like busywork rather than enjoyable on its own. It makes the higher difficulties less tedious to tackle (especially with some of the more helpful bonuses), but it just feels like an absolute chore to get through. Speaking of chores, they just add more chores without opening meaningful doors and mechanics past Veteran in terms of the difficulty options. The first three difficulties add mechanics each jump - after Veteran comes Viceroy, which is the same thing as Veteran with new forbidden and dangerous glade events to threaten your settlement and that the forest is more hostile by a multiplier of x3 instead of x2, but they don't do anything "new" really, they are just more of what you have seen before on earlier difficulties, and they just cost a ton of resources that you may not have been able to produce unless you have enough bonuses from the metaprogression tree and otherwise they apply so many negative benefits your game may actually end, such as the Stormbird which as far as I can tell by searching across the internet, people have been complaining is poorly balanced even with a good settlement for years. I don't just mean negatively either - the Stormbird applies an infinite storm effect, locking you to a year until you finish it (which you could delay), which is abusable in its own right if you were lucky enough to find it early. The Stormbird is just absurdly out of band in both directions and I cannot understand the intent of including it compared to every other event. I suppose that its very existence changes the logic pattern of whether you should open forbidden glades at all, but the higher difficulties disincentivize the opening of small glades due to hostility modifiers, so that just leaves dangerous glades if you do not want to starve but want to ensure a manageable event. What a forcible winnowing of the meta - it creates a very rote playstyle even though the apparent point of RNG building choice to create more unstable, dynamic push-and-pull gameplay. 

By the way, the tree also has a level attached - as you go through various sessions you get XP, when you level up you unlock new buildings and cornerstones (buffs) to show up in the game. THIS metaprogression mechanic is where the actual doors are opened for new build orders. Except its just as slow as the tree since its a blocker on the tree - without those later buildings and cornerstones, the game is not necessarily giving you the tools to win on higher difficulties. The amount of XP seems really low as well no matter the difficulty and even with completing various achievement challenges, which just exacerbates the issue.

I assume the decision not to bind those buildings and cornerstones to the higher difficulties and instead to a metaprogression level was so that you can use them on the lower difficulties and practice various build chains, but without overwhelming people when they start to play, and because of the complexity of creating a system that could both leave them default on the higher difficulties and then unlock them for use on the lower one once you cleared the higher one. Though perhaps they could have used their training missions for this. In all honesty the buildings beyond the first few levels matter less than the cornerstones, but they both add to how obnoxious the metaprogression system is - even if it is justified ludonarratively. 

In positives, I genuinely like the give and take between blight and production starting with the Veteran difficulty. I enjoy the season model and how each session naturally pushes you to modify your build chain on the fly or attempt to produce enough of your current resources to trade for the things you need to complete the Orders. I enjoy the fact that a session can take no more than one hour or maybe two at the higher speeds and therefore allows a bite-sized city building experience. I genuinely did get 30 hours out of it so I would say I got my money's worth, and I may play some more now and again, but anything that sufficiently annoys me more than it captivates me gets a negative review especially when the causes will not be immediately apparent to the player. | Let me preface this by saying that the game is very well made and I understand why so many people love it. I am not refunding it for any notable flaws.

For me specifically, when I play this type of game I want to dig in and work on one continuous settlement and make it grow over time, eventually getting to a point where I have this massive city that basically runs itself, giving me a primal sense of satisfaction that doesn't need to be felt again for roughly two years. But this game is a rogue-lite with some aspects of a mobile game, where you constantly restart a 'run', so to speak, unlocking stuff to make things more interesting for the next one. And though well-crafted, it's just not the kind of thing I'm looking for in a city-builder. | ä¸å…¶è¯´æ˜¯åŸå¸‚è¥é€ æˆ–è€…åŸºåœ°å»ºè®¾ï¼Œæ›´åƒæ˜¯æœ‰é™èµ„æºç®¡ç†æ¸¸æˆï¼Œä¸ç¬¦åˆæˆ‘çš„å…´è¶£

Most annoying for me was the balancing of weapons. Some are good in early game but weak in late game and vice versa. So you really should spread out your options. | I haven't played the other Wastelands... but after getting back into tactical RPGs like Rogue Trader (loved it) and Baldur's Gate 3 (Awesome return to D&D), Wasteland 3 (mostly) satisfies that nostalgic Old School Fallout vibe/feel/itch. The tactical gameplay is fun and somewhat varied but some of the systems could have been polished and fleshed out more. Also the the variety of encounters could have been a little better since there was not much need for reevaluating strategies once you found one that worked. Also, initially I didn't understand how some of the attributes and skills actually affected gameplay and leveling. Figured it out but the game doesn't do a great job explaining everything. Some of the world and story could have been more open ended (though you can wander ish). Overall it was great though, with some interesting characters and a story that's serviceable enough to keep you mad maxxing across Colorado. An easy "yes" to purchase on sale. | A Masterpiece of Tactical RPG Storytelling

Wasteland 3 is an absolute triumph for fans of tactical RPGs and post-apocalyptic storytelling. From the moment you step into the frozen wastelands of Colorado, youâ€™re drawn into an immersive world filled with tough moral choices, deeply layered characters, and unforgettable encounters.

Gameplay
The combat in Wasteland 3 is a standout feature, blending classic turn-based strategy with modern mechanics. Every decision matters, from positioning your squad to selecting the right mix of abilities and gear. The battles are challenging but rewarding, encouraging creative strategies and clever use of your environment.

Storytelling
The narrative is where Wasteland 3 truly shines. The writing is sharp, witty, and emotionally engaging, with decisions that genuinely impact the world around you. Whether youâ€™re negotiating with strange cults, deciding the fate of a desperate town, or dealing with the consequences of your alliances, the game keeps you constantly invested in its branching storyline.

Atmosphere and World-Building
The frozen post-apocalypse of Colorado is beautifully crafted, with stunning environments and a hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack. Every location feels unique and packed with details that add depth to the world. The quirky characters and dark humor are perfectly balanced with the serious tones of survival and sacrifice.

Customizability
From building your squad to upgrading your base, Wasteland 3 offers a wealth of customization options. You can tailor your team to suit your playstyle, making every playthrough feel unique.

Co-Op
For those looking to share the experience, the co-op mode is a fantastic addition, allowing you to strategize and make tough decisions with a friend.

Conclusion
Wasteland 3 is a must-play for RPG enthusiasts and anyone who loves a game that challenges your mind and tugs at your emotions. InXile Entertainment has delivered a masterpiece that respects the legacy of the Wasteland series while modernizing it for a new generation of gamers. If you're ready for a journey filled with tough choices, tactical depth, and a world that feels alive, Wasteland 3 is the game for you.

i have such a crippling skill issue, that every time i play, that gawdamn radiation kills ALL of my crew, and then i have to like, self destruct the ship (there was no radiation, i killed the crew) | I was expecting a better experience than crew bomber and I got a worse experience .... not worth for the normal price | Inquisitorial Report:

Upon closer inspection of the Space CREW , it has become abundantly clear that this title presents itself as an exceptional tool for honing oneâ€™s tactical acumen in the cold, void-laden expanses of space. In the pursuit of excellence and the eradication of chaos, this simulation demonstrates the highest degree of mechanical efficiency, visual splendor, and a narrative framework worthy of the Emperorâ€™s praise.

The gameâ€™s systems are nothing short of flawless, operating with an unwavering precision akin to the finest Imperial war machines. Each crew member's role is of vital importance, and it is through tight coordination and perfect execution of duties that the player survives. Should you falter, the unforgiving void will claim your soul. Whether managing the ship's engines, weapon systems, or the delicate dance of inter-crew communication, every decision made will shape the fate of your crew. The learning curve is steep, but it is a trial by fire that strengthens the resolve of any who dare to command.

In true Inquisitorial fashion, Space CREW offers a rigorous challenge to all who dare enter its domain. No quarter is given, and every mission could be your last. The complexity of the tasks and the ever-present threat of failure make each victory all the sweeter. Those unprepared will fall swiftly, their lives extinguished in the blink of an eye, but those who persist will be rewarded with the satisfaction of having survived the most brutal trials the universe can offer.

As an Inquisitor, I hereby declare Space CREW a most worthy investment for those seeking a challenging, immersive experience. The mechanics are precise, the visuals are captivating, and the narrative, though understated, adds depth to the experience. The universe is vast, and the dangers are many, but with the proper coordination and strategy, victory is within your grasp. The Emperor would approve.

It makes me sad to see this game has been removed from Steam, it's a really lovely puzzle game!

I've never seen the show, so who knows maybe there were lore issues, but even without the context of the show, it had enough lore to be interesting for complete beginners to the series. 

It's a simple enough timing puzzle, though I love puzzles so take that with a grain of salt if you dislike them xD There were only a few points I had gotten stuck, but even at worst it took a retry to readjust myself to what was happening in the mission (I forgot one of the characters abilities despite using it earlier that same mission, user error!). But it's very fun, and I love watching one of the characters I've already routed go by as I'm plotting the next character.

Really wish I could recommend it but I can't. | As fun as the gameplay is, that's like literally the only compliment i can give it outside of the game looking beautiful, it's a sadistic grindfest that is so unbelievably overwhelming for any player, i have 200 hours and i still have zero clue what im doing because i am being constantly bombarded with new items and systems that by the time i get a grasp on one thing, i have to learn 5 more new things. | I didn't really doing anything in the first 6 hours and ended up with a full inventory of stuff... just stuff. The combat early on seems pointless as you can be surrounded by 20 mobs and take no damage. The graphics in the game are quirky with a ton of lighting issues making the game look awful most of the time. The user interface is horrid with overlays overlaying other overlays upon more overlays... it's a mess visually. Why would I want to get notified of other players failing crafting when I am just starting the game? It's a UX/UI designers nightmare. Early story and quests are meh. If I were to summarize my new experience, I wouldn't say it was "bad", I would say it's "a turn off". | Black Desert Online has one of the best early and mid-game experiences. Progress feels rewarding, the world is vast and fun to explore, and there's a real sense of discovery. However, the late game is a completely different story.

Once you hit the late-game grind, progression slows down dramatically, taking anywhere from 20 to 100 hours just to see any improvement. Season characters are a great addition, but they also remove the early game entirely by handing out free PEN gear, which can feel like skipping one of the best parts of the game.

The biggest issue is how demanding the late game is, both in time and money. The game leans heavily into pay-to-win mechanicsâ€”you can buy Crons, making enhancement much less painful for those willing to spend money. While Black Desert has an incredible combat system and PvP is amazing, there's just not enough meaningful PvP content in the open world.

Overall, Black Desert isnâ€™t a terrible game, but the late-game grind and monetization model make it hard to recommend unless you're ready to sink an absurd amount of time (or money) into it.

The game has great potential. It's almost finished.

But it has one basic bug that makes the whole game unplayable. The bug can be fixed with one line of code and the developer is aware of it. Instead of fixing the bug, they write insolently in a few paragraphs how it's not financially profitable. And that's why they won't fix the simplest basic, always repeatable bug.

Don't buy this game or anything else from this creator. They are  just the most blatant scam. And they say it officially. | The game is abandoned by DEV team since 2023. In fact - the game has good potential but... full of bugs, and unfinished game mechanicks.

First thing, this game is very very addictive, I'd give you that. Once you start a game you will find it very very hard to stop playing. My 227 hours play time should be evidence enough to prove my point. But sadly, among my 227 play time, 99% of it was solo play. I would dearly like to join a clan and play with some other players. But alas, although the game does support clan play, some feature of the game or should I say lack of it, made it very unfriendly for clan play.  

The one thing I hate about this game is that all members within a clan shares everything. And in everything, I mean freaking EVERYTHING. All you can do is to trust in your clan member's ethics and hope they won't rob you blind when you're not in the game. Even the stuff in your so-call personal strongbox can be access by your clan members. So what good is a personal strongbox if everyone can get the stuff you stashed in it. I mean, why put in a personal strongbox in the first place is its utterly useless. At least put in some permission settings for the owner to restrict access to their stuff. 

Another thing is the loot system. I once cleared a tier 2 rift boss when another player came in and took all my loot dropped from the boss. The player was not even a clan member, just another solo player who came in and ninja looted all my stuff. 

All of this BS is making it very hard for anyone to form and invite people into a clan unless all the clan members are also real life friends. No one likes to be betrayed and rob of their hard earn possessions when they are not looking.

But, after mentioning all the bad stuff, I'm still gonna recommend this to others. Genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
Reviews:
fazia tempos que queria ficar cheio de pals, agora da pra colecionar pal, mt bom, pals de varios tamanhos, formas e cores, recomendo apesar dos apesares, bora segurar nossos pals e amalos | Palworld isn't your typical creature-collecting game.  It's a bizarre, beautiful blend of monster taming, base building, and surprisingly intense third-person shooter action.  The core gameplay loop revolves around befriending (and sometimes battling) a huge variety of adorable, yet potentially deadly, Pals. Daedream is my favorite companion pal â€“ its cute looks and powerful abilities are a total game-changer!
 
My base is a testament to the game's robust building options. I've got a castle-like residential area for my Pals, a bustling factory for crafting, a relaxing Japanese hot spring where my Pals can unwind (and, let's be honest, maybe get a little romantic), and a dedicated farming zone to keep resources flowing.  It's a little slice of organized chaos, perfectly reflecting the game's spirit.
 
My combat strategy?  Pure, unadulterated pandemonium! I release my Pals, yell some words of encouragement (mostly incoherently), and hope for the best.  It's less strategy and more controlled chaos, but hey, it works more often than you'd think! 
 
The unpredictable antics of my Pals during combat are constantly hilarious.  I've seen them get stuck in the most ridiculous places, accidentally launch rockets at my own base (oops!), and generally cause more mayhem than a troop of caffeinated monkeys.  It's all part of the charm!
 
While the graphics aren't groundbreaking, and the story is fairly simple, the sheer joy of collecting, training, and battling with these adorable yet deadly creatures makes up for it.  The blend of cuteness and carnage is unique, and the base-building aspect adds a welcome layer of strategic depth.  Palworld isn't perfect â€“ it can be repetitive at times, and the occasional glitch can be frustrating â€“ but the overall experience is incredibly enjoyable.
 
Highly recommended for anyone who enjoys a good dose of cute chaos! | gfæ²¡äº§èƒ½ï¼Œæˆ‘è‡ªç„¶æ¥ç©å¸•é²äº†ï¼Œè¿™ä¸æ˜¯å¾ˆæ­£å¸¸å˜›ï¼ŸæŠ„è¢­çš„ç¡®å­˜åœ¨ï¼Œä¸å¯å¦è®¤ï¼Œä¸”é’‰åœ¨è€»è¾±æŸ±ä¸Šã€‚ä½†æ˜¯å¸•é²ä¹Ÿæœ‰å¾ˆå¤šåœ°æ–¹è¶…è¶Šäº†å®å¯æ¢¦ä¸æ˜¯ä¹ˆï¼Ÿä»–éš¾é“ä¸æ˜¯ä»å–„å¦‚æµå˜›ï¼Ÿä½ è¯´gfè€¿é¬¼æ¼‚æµ®ã€megaåœ°é¾™ç©å®¶è¯Ÿç—…å¤šå°‘å¹´äº†ï¼Ÿæ”¹äº†å˜›ï¼Ÿå‰‘ç›¾dlcç¥å…½å¼ºåº¦è¶…æ ‡ï¼Œåƒæ»¡æå·¨åŒ–å’Œé’›æ™¶åŒ–çº¢åˆ©ï¼Œå‰ä»£ç¥å…½æ²¡äººç©ç¯å¢ƒå˜çš„æ¶è‡­ï¼Œæ”¹äº†å˜›ï¼Ÿå¸•é²å®˜æ–¹åšåˆ°äº†ç©å®¶åæ˜ ä»€ä¹ˆå°±æ”¹ä»€ä¹ˆï¼ˆè€Œä¸”æ˜¯å”®åå“¦ï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™ç‚¹è¶…è¶Šäº†ä¸çŸ¥é“å¤šå°‘æ¸¸æˆå®˜æ–¹äº†ã€‚ | Ğ¯ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ±ÑƒĞ´Ñƒ ÑƒĞ³Ğ»ÑƒĞ±Ğ»ÑÑ‚ÑŒÑÑ Ğ² Ğ¾ÑĞ¾Ğ±ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñ‹, Ñ€Ğ°ÑÑĞºĞ°Ğ·Ñ‹Ğ²Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ ÑÑĞ¶ĞµÑ‚, Ñ Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ‡Ñƒ Ğ°ĞºÑ†ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğµ Ğ½Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼, ĞºĞ°Ğº Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ñ€Ğ°Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ‚Ñ‡Ğ¸ĞºĞ¸ Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ½Ğ¾ÑÑÑ‚ÑÑ Ğº Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğµ.

The fun I got from playing Palworld was mainly from exploring the world, finding and catching new pals and collecting collectibles. But when you enter mid game, which is around level 30 you can't progress by simply exploring anymore. You instead need to farm materials to craft necessary items and farm the same pals you've already caught to gain exp. And this loop of farming and running around can go on for hours.
Me and my friend changed the world settings (higher drops etc) to make it more bearable but even so the game was too boring for me to want to continue. And it's so frustrating because the beginning of the game was so much fun and I wish the developers would've designed the game progression to be like that through out the whole game.
There's more stuff I could criticize the game for but what's written above is the main complaint I have and what made me stop playing.

The expansion includes some broken mechanics such as the Shaman and flying creatures not having enough traps. But overall a fun time! | A solid entry in the series.
The war scenarios are a bit lackluster, but apart from that it has everything you would want.
Campaign, endless, weekly challenge, "scramble" mode, and leaderboards to compete with friends.
Only complaint is that they still haven't figured out a decent lobby browser / matchmaking system. | It's a fun game that doesn't quite feel as polished together as the first two games in the series.  The war scenarios have the potential to be interesting but like the rest of the game it feels like the overall design needed more thought.  Visually it is pleasant enough even if the environments to do somehow feel a bit paper thin.  The two new characters you will play as are pretty lame, especially compared to the previous protagonist. It feels more focused on combat than tower defense, and if that was intentional then they should have spent more time on the feel of the combat to improve it.  A minor point is the graphic design of the menus is bizarrely not very good for some reason.

Enjoying all the different mechanics for the city building and resource management.  The planets with the different materials adds some logistics management too, just enough to keep it fun.  I need more than 9 at some point!

There is no cloud save at the moment, found out the hard way.  :D

Game Lindo, coop local 4 players pra juntar geral, ou online, Ã³timos grÃ¡ficos, boas mÃºsicas, som de ambientaÃ§Ã£o de armas, vÃ¡ a um "pico" e atire vocÃª ouvirÃ¡ ecos, sons de armas e sincronizaÃ§Ã£o com os tiros, movimentaÃ§Ã£o simples, combate estratÃ©gico e progressivo, vÃ¡rias skills desde robÃ´s mechas armadura, dragons cyberpunk neon, roubo de vida, correr igual o flash e por ai vai, esse game Ã© uma obra prima feita por 12 lendas apenas, melhor indie do ano, e nÃ£o tem tantos bugs.

Ainda assim, oferece umas boas duas dezenas de horas de diversÃ£o, especialmente se acompanhado. | I do not endorse this game for there is a major bug where the save file can disappear out of the blue.
Today, 27th Jan, as a I returned from 9 hours of work, I found out that my save was gone.

I cannot endorse a game which provides anxiety or requires me to bypass known issues. All I want to do is hit play and chill; no other gimmicks (i.e. save locally or desync Steam save).

Regardless of how good something is (and this game is good), if it does not serve its purpose (which is a gate-away), then so long. Reading a book is anxiety-free and without workarounds. And, coming to this, I endorse American Gods.

I am upset and requested Steam for a refund. Hopefully they provide it, giving the game-time. | The Ascent is a [i]decent[/i] game that frustratingly falls short of being a [i]great[/i] game. For every aspect it exceeds at, it feels like another is executed poorly or to a sub-par standard. Whilst I came away from the game having had a good experience, I can't help but feel like I expected a little more.

Off the bat, the visuals are probably the most obvious strength of the game. The world is beautifully grim, and dense with detail and character - it's one of those games where you can regularly stop to just enjoy the view. It also runs remarkably well for just how visually complex it is. Truthfully though, as good as it looks in screenshots and videos, I personally found it to be a bit too dazzling, overstimulating and "busy". And whilst the graphics settings are a great way to adjust for performance, they aren't fleshed out enough for tweaking to your visual preferences - I had to go diving into INI files to disable depth of field, film grain and bloom, and opted to lower the game's blurry TAA in favour of video card driven anti-aliasing in NVIDIA Control Panel.

The combat is the other strength of the game. It's obviously played as a top-down shooter, but I feel also draws parallels and similarities to ARPG gameplay. Despite the vastly pulled-back camera, the gunplay feels just as chunky, visceral and satisfying as any of the best shooters do. Shootouts can be tense and punishing, but reward tactical play and effective build & loadout choices. But countless times I found problems in combat with the game's camera - it loves to constantly wrestle control away from you as the player by shifting and panning the camera around at certain vistas or point of interest for artistic effect, but almost ALWAYS at the cost of combat awareness. The amount of times this happens while enemies in range are shooting you from off-screen is infuriating.

There's a lot of interesting lore and worldbuilding in the game, but most of it is relegated to a "codex" log of written entries. These are pretty interesting, and worth a read if you have the downtime... but in reality, that's quite an ask in an action-heavy game. Whilst they make some light attempts to deliver this information through environmental storytelling and a bit of in-game dialogue, for a majority of my playthrough I didn't really feel much of a sense of place or purpose with the game's overarching plot. And whilst it pens itself as an "RPG", that only goes as far as the action aspect of gameplay - don't go in expecting any kind of complex story, branching narratives, or deep character development.

As a continuation of that last point as well, the game also has a LOT of spelling and grammar errors, or subtitles that just don't match the VO audio. It speaks to a wider problem where the game really just generally lacks a lot of polish. It could almost qualify for "eurojank" if it wasn't so visually impressive, and the combat so well-oiled. The UX of some of the menus and gameplay systems/features is woefully inadequate, and trying to generally navigate the game's world with its awful map menu and buggy quest waypoints is sometimes an exercise in frustration. The audio levels feel totally out-of-whack, and it took me hours of playtime to find a balance that felt good. And for a game with cosmetic customisation, it loves to make it [i]impossible[/i] to see what you actually look like - these menus & scenes often being poorly lit and obstructed by environmental objects.

In terms of my overall gameplay experience, I didn't find the game to be all that long and felt somewhat unfulfilled upon completion. I played almost the entire thing on Hard, the highest difficulty, because I was finding it to be a breeze - and for context, I'm not all that incredible at games, I usually just go for normal/default difficulties. The difficult spikes were all over the place and inconsistent though, and for the final game encounter I'd kind of progressed/built my character into a corner and had to drop the difficulty for a remote chance of success. It took me around 28 hours to finish everything in the base game, another 6-8 for the DLC campaign, and then a few spare hours allowed me to leisurely clean up the last of the achievements for 100% completion. I wanted more by the end of it, and in most co-op games I would probably just jump into casual public matchmaking for some variety. But bafflingly enough, the game doesn't HAVE any public matchmaking - your options are solo, or private co-op with a friend.

The Ascent had the foundation to be a legitimately incredible top-down shooter/ARPG experience, and honestly it's still genuinely impressive given the tiny size of the team behind it. If the camera didn't regularly try get in the way of gameplay, if the menus & map/navigation were more well thought out, and if it generally had some of its rougher edges rounded off, it would be a very easy recommendation. There's still definitely a worthwhile game here waiting to be played, but it just requires a bit more patience and forgiveness than some may be willing to give it.

9,5/10 | Took a while for me to really get into it, but once I did, it was fantastic!

Pro's:
-Creativity
-It doesn't really get stale, because there is something new around every corner (a new game mechanic, a new area, a new part of the story)
-The humor
-it's fun to upgrade your restaurant, as well as your equipment. There is a good feeling of progression.
Because of that, things that are tricky at the start of the game, become much more doable, or even easy. And that's really great, because you feel that you've worked for it!
-The characters! Though it wouldn't have hurt if it had been a little bit less of a sausage fest. There are some female characters, but the main cast are male. Still, they were fun, memorable, and fit well into the story.
-The actual fishing! I loved coming across bigger, faster, stronger, more dangerous beasts of the sea, and besting them! It took a bit to really get the hang off, but once I did, it became so satisfying to dive every day and gather everything that I needed for the restaurant! Slowly unlocking and upgrading more dishes because I was able to catch different creatures. 
-Honestly, it just looks very nice! The colors are pleasant, the locations are pretty, the bosses are kinda cool, the character design is varied, I love that Dave is VERY much a plus size! He's just a lovable teddy bear. 


cons:
-There are some game mechanics that could have been left out? Especially at the end there are things that you need to keep up with that become more like a chore than something fun. But in my opinion, it's not terrible. You have the time, and it doesn't take that long, but still. It is a bit much to do everything.
-Dave in the water: Fantastic! Dave working in the restaurant.... incredibly slow. I know it's part of the game, but it is made worse when you have to poor drinks for customers.. Every time I had to pour a beer, or make a cocktail, I would dread it. And I had staff take over as quickly as I could.
-Some parts can be a little confusing at first, but once you get it, or get the hang of it, it's fine. It's mostly that there is a lot, and it can become overwhelming.


Would I recommend this game?
-To anyone that wants a semi-cozy (semi-stressful) gaming experience.
-If you like a roguelike, but would like a different take on it!
-You like fishies but arn't afraid to brutally shoot a harpoon into them (it's just a game. It's harsh but it's also comical. No actual fishies are harmed in you shooting a bunch of pixels. But people can be sensitive to stuff like this, and that's okay! Just keep this in mind before you buy!)
-You're ready to try something new!

So yes, in general I think this is a fantastic game! But it might not be for everyone (no game is) 
You can always watch some game play so you know what is ahead of you. If what you see seems fun, Go for it!!
If you are on the fence, I'd lean towards getting it anyway, because there is so much to this game, I'm sure there will be at least a few things that will positively surprise you if you are willing to put in the time! | Wonderful cute and fun game that has so much content to offer, great music, great visuals and art and tons of fun catching all the fish.

5 bucks for this was so worth it. Some of the puzzles are truly challenging and it will test your ability to problem solve. Really really enjoyed playing this with friends. Would absolutely recommend for a quick cheap late night game that clearly had love and effort put in!!!!!


EDIT: JUST BECAUSE YOU FELT THE PUZZLES WERE TOO HARD, THAT DOES NOT WARRANT A NEGATIVE REVIEW. YOUR INTELLECT SHOULD NOT AFFECT THE DEVELOPERS IMAGE! | I only leave reviews when a game is either really good or really bad - this is one of the best games I've ever played!

I feel many of the negative reviews are unfair. They seem to be split mainly into the 3 camps below,

1) They don't have the intellect to solve these puzzles: These puzzle are not like the puzzles in games like 'The Room' where you need only randomly click things until something happens or where the solution is screaming at you in the face. The puzzles in this game are PROPER puzzles and VERY cleverly designed. You actually have to engage your brain, so expect to be stuck thinking about a puzzle for a while, and you will probably need to write notes to solve some. Reviews that say the puzzles don't follow logical rules or require brute force are talking TOTAL rubbish. I got through all puzzles using logic alone and did not require the optional hints. This game reminds me of the Sherlock Holmes quote "You see, but you do not observe" - all the clues you need are given to you in the form of various letters left around the house and you need to CAREFULLY read each one.

2) They don't have the patience: this is not a game that you can leave your brain at the door after a hard days work. This is a game you play if you're in desperate need of some intellectual stimulation and challenge.

3) It's not a co-op game: this is probably true. I played it solo, but I noticed that much of the time the puzzles need to be completed in a linear order.

I suspect this is a niche game for those who find other puzzle games too simple, and for that reason this game may struggle to gain mass appeal. However I hope this developer does really well and continues to make QUALITY puzzle games like this.

P.S. There IS an inventory option for carrying the puzzle pieces - hit Tab. | This game was an absolute treat. Extremely unique, creative, and polished puzzles that took real thought BUT were fair. Unlike many puzzle games they don't just hand you the answer, but they aren't obscure unsolvable puzzles either. The game is well made and loaded to the brim with puzzles. Sure it's not goofy and cartoony like others in the genre, but if you're up for a real challenge, I can only say I was impressed with each new puzzle we faced. Great job creators!

Also, even though the puzzles were challenging, it was a ton of fun talking them through with a friend in multiplayer. Honestly one of the best entries in the genre and truly rewarding to complete. | Greatly enjoyed this puzzle/escape adventure! This is my first download from 0 Deer Soft and I'm excited to purchase the rest of their collection! | While some of the puzzles were interesting, it doesn't make effective use of the medium or in having two players. Many of the puzzles essentially feel like brute force or logic reduction puzzles, and while presented in a cool way, with some cool things, it just doesn't really feel like it should be a video game.

Also all of the notes people kept leaving one another were very passive-aggressive.

That being said, this game IS WORKING on finding itself. I have watched this game change and evolve a lot. It has it's ups and its downs. It still has many things it can improve on, but it has already gone through great lengths to improve many. That to me is a huge pro. The developers are passionate about this. It shows. Why Nightingale rocks in my book though, is because it brings me back to the days of Star Wars Galaxies, where you had vast maps to explore and look for materials to gather and tinker with. Things I disliked:

But B is made at a different station. Then B actually needs F+R. Oh my god, it is so tedious. This game really disappointed me and I found the more I played it, the more frustrated and bored I got. | This is a beautiful game - it is visually stunning. The gameplay has a perfect balance - you need to farm for resources; but, it is not an endless repetitive grind. This is by far the best game/survival game I may have ever played - best survival game for certain and survival games are my jam. This (I would consider) to be a must buy, a must play, a must experience to partake in.

Really enjoyable exploration and discovery game, with very light survival elements. 
(If you are looking for "hardcore" survival, this may not be the game for you- higher difficulties are indeed more difficult, but the survival elements remain the same, with only your Oxygen, Thirst, and Hunger elements running down faster.)

It's a beautiful world, but it is a bit buggy. You have to enjoy exploiting bugs like falling through terrain and being able to see underneath- and finding things that may have been harder to see up top. (I love finding cracks in invisible walls and seeing if I can get off-map or travel below the world). If you are intolerant of even minor bugs and visual glitches- well. this one ain't for you, because it has     a fair number. Very small dev team (2 people I think?) so they are likely only focusing on game-breaking bugs when they are found.

This is really more of a base-building/exploration/discovery game, not really what I consider "true survival". 

I will say I have enjoyed it far more than I expected to, with almost 107 hours into it at the time of this review. And I expect to put a good number of hours into it after this, to get all achievements, and then start a new game in the DLC world. 

If you are looking for "perfect"- this game may not be for you. If you are looking for an engaging grind fest creating a world from scratch and watching it blossom and grow (and you are tolerant of funny bugs that sometimes can be exploited)- this may be for you, Story isn't a focus, but it is there if you want to discover all of the hidden bases and messages of those who came before but did not survive... story is there, and is pretty good once you start piecing it together.
