The truth is that game is not for everyone. It takes a lot from souls-like games, builds over it with faith system. The RPG system does not involve leveling, just couple perks that can be bought with 'souls' and gear. Combat is more forgiving than in souls titles (mainly because of instant dodge-roll and animation cancel, no damage block). Nontherless it is quite more difficult than ds3, with brutal and unforgiving enemies, bosses and levels.
It is also rewarding because of it's difficulty. Game can be really steep in the begining, but it gets better with every beaten boss (maybe with exception to Jezebel). It is also not very linear, can easily get lost in labyrinth of rooms.

E.g. to improve your [spoiler]  "reason" [/spoiler] skill you have to  combine 8 [spoiler] "Erudition" [/spoiler]  which takes 60 seconds each to combine, and 60 seconds to make, all on timers before they run out... 

- The way cards get added to your field sucks ass and is beyond annoying, just dumping them wherever with no possibility to have a dedicated place for a certain type of card. Let me have all books in one place, all vitality in another etc... being unable to stack cards with different timers is also extremly annoying and creates a mess all the time. 

Overall, a 6/10 which would be probably a 7 or 8 if the quality of life wasn't so miserable at points.

ä½“éªŒå¤ªæœ‰æ„æ€äº†ï¼Œå½“è¿‡è­¦å±€é«˜ç®¡ä¹Ÿå½“è¿‡å…¬å¸æ€»è£ï¼Œç©·æ­»è¿‡å“æ­»è¿‡é†‰ç”Ÿæ¢¦æ­»è¿‡ï¼Œè¿˜è¢«æ‹˜è¿‡ã€‚è¿˜æ‰“ç®—å’Œæ‰€æœ‰è¿½éšè€…åˆ†åˆ«è°ˆä¸€æ¬¡æ‹çˆ±ï¼Œå¬å”¤äº†å¾ˆå¤šä¹±ä¸ƒå…«ç³Ÿçš„å¼‚ç•Œç”Ÿç‰©ï¼Œæ¢ç´¢äº†æ‰€æœ‰èƒ½æ¢ç´¢çš„åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œæœ‰ç©ºæŠŠæ‰€æœ‰æ•™æ´¾éƒ½å»ºä¸€éï¼
æ–‡æœ¬è§‚èµæ€§å¾ˆå¼ºï¼Œéå¸¸æ´›å¼é£å‘³ï¼Œå¥½åƒï¼ | This game is a passionate love affair I keep coming back to.  It's not something I recommend to everyone (honestly I don't think any game is, but this one is more "has a highly specific target audience" than most) - you have to be some combination of a fiddly detail obsessive, wiki-diver, and opaque lore-enjoyer to really get the most out of it.  

Watching the previews will give a decent sense of the actual gameplay, which I would have difficulty describing, but the *feeling* of playing the game can't really be communicated as easily, I think.  Cultist Sim is incredibly atmospheric, and a lot better at creating interesting tension than a few gameplay clips can really convey.  The timer progression is such an integral part of not just the mechanics, but the mood.  Is your current Dream action (20 seconds remaining) going to turn up the card you need to dispel part of the Fascination counter (45 seconds remaining) currently spelling your doom?  etc.  

Also, it pays to actually read the descriptive text on things - it will all sound like pretentious bullshit at first, but there is a kind of shockingly cohesive, deep, and interesting setting and story going on, here, behind all the timer-watching.

My one main criticism is that it is really, really bad at teaching you how to play it.  I'd recommend spending a few minutes on youtube to help get the basics down; there are a lot of aspects of the game that are satisfying to find out in an exploratory manner, but the basics of stuff like, how to recruit and promote Followers are not that.  Thankfully, the fan wiki is also excellent, and basically an essential resource if you get in deep. | [h2] ç‰‡æ‰‹é–“ã§ã‚„ã‚Œã‚‹ã‚ˆã†ã«ç›¤é¢ã‚’æ•´ãˆã‚‹ã¨æƒ³å®šå¤–ã®ãƒŸã‚¹ã§æ­»ã¬ã‚²ãƒ¼ãƒ ï¼ˆ1æ•—ï¼‰ [/h2]

I bought this on sale so its definitely worth it 75-80% off but I'm reminded of how scummy a company Creative Assembly is the longer I play.

They don't sell you complete games, they sell you some of a game then sell you many of the cool features that synergize with your favorite factions separately through DLC... if your favorite faction isn't a DLC in itself that is. Factions like Wood Elves are locked away behind over priced DLC you can only buy from TWW1 and there's now 3 TWW games, and many, many DLCs with bonus lords, heroes and entire factions locked away within them.

I'm playing a Dark Elf campaign and its a lot of fun to be honest. Being a dick head slaver is cool... what's not cool? Some of my best lords and heroes are locked away behind 2 different DLCs. The 'Master' hero who kicks butt and takes slaves, and the 'Supreme Sorcerer' lord, so you can have a powerful spellcaster instead of a typical warrior/captain Dreadlord. One of these DLCs are 18.99... the other is around 7 dollars. That's for ONE faction's complete roster and mechanics. If you want to play with multiple factions in their entirety through the 3 games? God help you, you poor financially milked bastard. | é”¤å®Œäº†ï¼Œæ ¹æœ¬åœä¸ä¸‹æ¥ï¼Œå·²ç»é”¤åˆ°å¤©æ˜åœ°æš—äº†ï¼Œæ ¹æœ¬é”¤ä¸å®Œå•Šï¼Œè¿™æ ¹æœ¬å°±é”¤ä¸å®Œï¼Ÿï¼Ÿï¼ã€‚â€˜ï¼›â€™ | Designed to be as unfun as possible and it doesn't even work anymore | Love this game, it's exactly the kind of turn-based strategy I like. Game is not bad but gameplay just depends purely on person its not real time strategy like any other, its just own kind

Histoire :
Breathedge vous plonge dans lâ€™espace en incarnant un homme ordinaire qui se retrouve perdu aprÃ¨s le crash de son vaisseau spatial, accompagnÃ© dâ€™un poulet immortel. Lâ€™histoire est un mÃ©lange de survie et dâ€™humour absurde, avec des dialogues sarcastiques et des rÃ©fÃ©rences Ã  la pop culture. Lâ€™intrigue Ã©volue progressivement, dÃ©voilant une conspiration plus large et un univers plus riche quâ€™il nâ€™y paraÃ®t au premier abord.

Gameplay :
Le jeu mÃ©lange survie, exploration et craft dans un environnement spatial. Vous devez gÃ©rer votre oxygÃ¨ne, recycler des dÃ©bris pour crÃ©er de nouveaux objets et explorer lâ€™Ã©pave du vaisseau pour progresser. Le gameplay repose sur la collecte de ressources, lâ€™amÃ©lioration de votre Ã©quipement et la dÃ©couverte de nouvelles zones.
Lâ€™humour omniprÃ©sent et les situations absurdes rendent lâ€™expÃ©rience unique, bien que certaines phases de farming puissent devenir rÃ©pÃ©titives Ã  la longue.

Graphismes :
Le style visuel est colorÃ© et soignÃ©, avec un excellent rendu de lâ€™espace et des effets de lumiÃ¨re rÃ©ussis. Les dÃ©cors sont variÃ©s, allant des carcasses de vaisseaux aux stations spatiales abandonnÃ©es, crÃ©ant une ambiance immersive. Lâ€™interface est claire et bien pensÃ©e, facilitant la navigation et la gestion des ressources.

DifficultÃ© :
Le jeu offre un dÃ©fi modÃ©rÃ©, avec une gestion de lâ€™oxygÃ¨ne et des ressources qui peut Ãªtre exigeante au dÃ©but. Une fois les amÃ©liorations dÃ©bloquÃ©es, la survie devient plus facile, et le jeu bascule davantage vers lâ€™exploration et lâ€™humour. Quelques phases de backtracking peuvent sembler un peu longues, mais elles sont compensÃ©es par la dÃ©couverte de nouveaux outils et secrets.

DurÃ©e de vie :
La campagne principale dure entre 10 et 15 heures, avec du contenu supplÃ©mentaire pour ceux qui aiment tout explorer. Le jeu reste linÃ©aire dans sa progression, mais certaines zones facultatives offrent un peu plus de libertÃ© et dâ€™interactions.

Prix (en solde) :
En promotion, Breathedge est souvent disponible pour moins de 10 euros, un excellent rapport qualitÃ©-prix pour les amateurs de jeux de survie originaux et dÃ©calÃ©s.

Conclusion :
Breathedge est un jeu de survie spatiale unique qui mÃªle humour absurde, exploration et gestion de ressources. Son univers dÃ©calÃ© et son style visuel en font une expÃ©rience rafraÃ®chissante, bien que certaines phases puissent devenir un peu rÃ©pÃ©titives. Bought early access. Spent over 465 hours online in this game.

Returned to check in on it and am prompted to spend $45 to regain access.

I thought purchasing early access means you get access early and you keep it at 1.0 release.

Not sure when anyone was warned that early access was ONLY early access, if at all. Big RIP, either way. | this game was good until the devs decided it cost to much money to provide more of the game we loved i guess the cash grab wasnt a good enough rug pull now the game is beyond dead and full of bullshit and the devs have not only  abandoned it  entirely but they claim theres 2 million players platform wide but steam charts says otherwise and if u state this in the community hub they will ban u like they did me  if i could refund this piece of scam shit i would but steam is shitty with refunds i will never install this game again and i have a full team of rly good tems but  the devs cba to do their fucking jobs | Shill and Scam. 
Don't invest in this game in 2025 
They don't care about you or the product, there will be no updates besides some paid cosmetics, 
Crema long abandoned the game and on 1.0 release claimed there will be no new content or monsters. 
Luma and Dark Luma isn't enough to keep this alive. The ESport league for pvp was already dropped too. | Bought and played early acces, return to the game after a while.. now i need to pay 44,99 ?? i smell SCAMMAZ | A well-balanced game, with depth akin to Pokemon, but with more consistency as far as battle style goes (double battles all the way). The worldbuilding and quality of characters is amazing, much better than Pokemon imo. They've simplified the type system from Pokemon (combined ground and rock, bug and grass) and made a few shifts to it that keep it interesting. Though, I still think of Crystal as basically Steel type. 

I really don't think it needed to be an MMO. I feel like they'll sunset it soon, as they're moving on to different games but it'd be great if the main core of the game was still playable years down the road.

Es ist sehr wichtig, sich im Klaren zu sein, was [i]Sable[/i] ist - und was es nicht ist. [i]Sable[/i] ist eine ruhige, nachdenkliche und entschleunigende Reise. Es fÃ¼hlt sich eher wie eine achtsame Meditation an als wie ein typisches Videospiel.

Gleich vorweg: Ganz ohne Probleme ist das Erlebnis leider nicht. Wie so oft bei Indie Titeln fehlt es an der technischen Optimierung. Hin und wieder kann es zu plÃ¶tzlichen FPS EinbrÃ¼chen kommen, die sich aber meist schnell wieder stabilisieren. Das auffÃ¤lligste Problem ist allerdings der Gleiter: Er verhÃ¤lt sich oft etwas unerwartet und kann fÃ¼r Frustration sorgen. Aber schlussendlich minderten diese Probleme meinen SpielspaÃŸ nicht, denn alles andere hat mich schlichtweg in seinen Bann gezogen.

Das Gameplay besteht aus unterschiedlich herausfordernden UmgebungsrÃ¤tseln, simplen Fetch-Quests und freier Erkundung zu FuÃŸ oder mit dem eigenen Gleiter. Ein Kampfsystem gibt es nicht. Und obwohl das eventuell dÃ¼rftig klingt, gelingt [i]Sable[/i] in meinen Augen etwas Einzigartiges. Die von Moebius Comics inspirierte Architektur und matte Farblandschaft, untermalt von einem groÃŸartigen Soundtrack von [i]Japanese Breakfast[/i], erschaffen eine auÃŸergewÃ¶hnliche AtmosphÃ¤re, die mich nostalgisch werden lieÃŸ an eine Zeit und einen Ort, die es nie gab.

Die Landschaften, Tempel und Niederlassungen dieser kuriosen Welt laden zur Erkundung ein und bieten genug Abwechslung, um der EintÃ¶nigkeit zu entgehen. Immer wieder sieht man in der Ferne ein mysteriÃ¶ses GebÃ¤ude oder befremdliche Artefakte, die es zu erkunden gilt.  Das Hauptziel des Spiels besitzt keine unmittelbare Dringlichkeit. [i]Sable[/i] lÃ¤sst sich Zeit, und der Spieler sollte dies genauso tun. Es geht um den Weg, um die SchÃ¶nheit des Moments, um das Erforschen und meditative Betrachten der Welt und ihrer Einwohner - und letzten Endes um das Finden seiner Selbst. | This is a beautiful and great exploration indie game, however the immersion get's really hampered by constant stuttering and a lot of consistent bugs that kept occurring, I will say that it's worth it to try but be aware it's not a very polished experience. | muito lindo, amei o fato de nao ter uma histÃ³ria linear, explorei cada cantinho possivel do mundo antes de finalizar. adorei a atmosfera e o storytelling no mundo. tem uns bugs chatinhos mas vale a pena. | D'abord les bons points : Le jeu est trÃ¨s beau, la direction artistique est originale, et la musique d'intro aprÃ¨s la premiÃ¨re partie "didacticiel" donne clairement des frissons. Mais voila, mÃªme si j'ai envie d'aimer ce jeu, je n'y arrive pas. Je trouve qu'il lui manque trop de choses, le contenu est trop lÃ©ger, l'exploration qui est le coeur du gameplay perd rapidement son sens aprÃ¨s les premiÃ¨res heures lorsque l'on se rend compte qu'on explore au final pour rien. Le lore est bien trop peu abouti, le systÃ¨me de personnalisation de l'aÃ©rocycle ne sert Ã  rien, et la fin semble bÃ¢clÃ©e. La derniÃ¨re mise Ã  jour ajoutant un systÃ¨me de pÃªche Ã  la ligne est mÃ©diocre, bref, le jeu donne envie d'Ãªtre aimÃ© mais n'y parvient finalement pas. C'Ã©tait une bonne petite expÃ©rience avec des bons moments, mais j'ai apprÃ©ciÃ© ce jeu comme on apprÃ©cie le dessin d'un enfant. Il est original, touchant, mais fondamentalement, il n'est pas exceptionnel. | This game is pure art. The best game I've ever played.
It's glitchy, has performance issues, and the gameplay is simplistic, but none of that matters due to how well this game conveys emotions and communicates its theme. It's a genuine experience to play through. If you have a powerful enough computer to beat the worst of the performance bugs and a controller (would not recommend on mouse) it's a must-play, simple as.

Game Name: Mutant Year Zero: Road to Eden
Reviews:
Great game!!! XCOM is my all time favorite and when I saw it was comparable, took the plunge and have not been disappointed.  I own the RPG and the miniatures game as well.  LOVE the genre, story and characters with all the personality you could ask for!!! | I enjoyed this game very much. Some what linear in its story but the story and tactical fights is what makes it good. Style is similar to the newer XCOM games (not the one from the 90s) and is not as complex as the Jagged Alliance series. 

Although simple, it does get a bit hard for only 3 characters at a time. Gear is expensive and you dont ever heal by resting. (you actually have to use medkits) The special skillsets is where one applies strategy for the tactical fights.

Its a good game and found myself coming back from work ready to play each night. A good and long rpg that will keep you busy for quite a while.
It's interesting to see how the character you create will grow their own personality and relationships with the other characters.
A little downside, some of the dialogues feel weird or make no sense at times. | Wildermyth is a simply amazing game. The gameplay is fun and really easy to pick up, allowing you a much lighter & quicker character building experience without needing the deep time sink that many games do (though I also enjoy that). The procedural story generation system can occasionally lead to some oddities but all in all makes for a very fun and replayable experience! 

I also love the concept of adventures spanning multiple generations, and characters becoming too old to fight. it adds an element of scale and realism to the adventures that I really appreciate. A great game for Strategy & RPG Newcomers or vets looking for a deep and replayable experience! | I love this game.

Don't let the art style keep you from trying it. It took me a while to warm up to it, but i think it actually suits the game very well.

The writing style also has it's own rhythm, and it might not be everyone's cup of tea, but it creates an unique atmosphere for the game. It can get poetic and it can definitely require your full attention. You need to be prepared to read, if you want to enjoy this game to the fullest. | ç©æ³•å‰§æƒ…éšæœºæ€§å„æ–¹é¢å‘å±•éå¸¸å‡è¡¡çš„æ¸¸æˆã€‚ä¸€å¼€å§‹å…¥å‘æ˜¯è¢«å‰§æƒ…å’Œéšæœºæ€§å¸å¼•ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯å‡ ä¸ªå‰§æƒ…æˆ˜å½¹çš„ä¸»çº¿å‰§æƒ…ä¹Ÿå†™çš„å¾ˆå¥½ï¼ŒæŠŠå‰§æƒ…éƒ½å¤§æ¦‚è¿‡ä¸€éååˆå¼€å§‹å¯¹æˆ˜æ——ç©æ³•ä¸Šå¤´ï¼ŒåŸºæœ¬ä¸Šæ¯ä¸€å±€éƒ½èƒ½å‘ç°ä¸€ç§æ–°çš„å¥½ç”¨çš„æ­é…ï¼Œè€Œä¸”è‹±é›„é—´çš„æŠ€èƒ½æ­é…ä¹Ÿéå¸¸æœ‰å¼€å‘ç©ºé—´ï¼Œå†åŠ ä¸Šå˜èº«å’ŒèŒä¸šæŠ€èƒ½çš„æ­é… ...å¯ç©æ€§éå¸¸é«˜ï¼è€Œä¸”å¾ˆå¤šçœ‹ä¸Šå»ä¸€èˆ¬çš„æŠ€èƒ½æ­é…å…¶å®ƒæŠ€èƒ½åä¼šå˜å¾—å¼‚å¸¸å¥½ç”¨ï¼Œæ€»ä½“æ¥è¯´ä¸‰ç§èŒä¸šç¡®å®å„æœ‰ä¼˜ç¼ºç‚¹ï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰æ˜æ˜¾çš„ä¼˜åŠ£ä¹‹åˆ†ï¼Œå‡è¡¡æ€§ä¸é”™ã€‚éš¾åº¦å¯é€‰ï¼Œé»˜è®¤éš¾åº¦å¯¹å…¥é—¨ç©å®¶å·²å¾ˆå‹å¥½ã€‚ç»¼åˆæ¥è®²ååˆ†æ¨èï¼ | o combate tÃ¡tico Ã© simples, mas bom. Genres: Adventure, Casual, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Strategy, Free To Play
Reviews: No Reviews

Not the most creative or deep deckbuilder out there but still a fun, heartfelt (and quite silly) take on the wacky SteamWorld universe. 
Perfect for the Steam Deck, you can pick it up and put it down without missing a beat. You don't even need to use headphones, dialogue is not voiced (well, it kinda is but all you hear is mechanical gibberish), and music/sound effects add little to the experience.

There were a few mechanics I didn't care for (like your inactive party members falling behind on XP/levels) and enemy variety is somewhat lacking but it's still a very solid 20+ hour turn-based experience with an ok story and balanced difficulty. If you're looking for a casual game to play on-the-go, pick it up on sale and have at it. | Every chapter feels the same (slow and grindy) characters and plot are boring and the bosses are just not fun or unique. I kept waiting for it to evolve into something better up until the very end, and it really didn't. It's the lowest point of the SteamWorld saga. If you really want to play a card game or deck builder I would go for Balatro or Slay the Spire. | This is an ok-ish game with some horrible UI/UX design decisions, it is so clunky, I can't believe this got past the whole team and all the playtesting (that being said the game is at 87% positive so obviously it doesn't bother that many people). 

The fact that there are no tooltips is just a plain stupid design decision in my opinion, especially for the for status effect icons - the first time an enemy used the counter ability against me I missed what they said as they played it and then an icon for two crossed swords appeared under the character and I had no idea what that meant. Also, if you want to inspect an enemy character to see their stats about them you can't just click on them...no you have to go into a menu, then click a button, then an arrow pops up that you then use to point at the enemy you want to inspect - absolutely wild design decision, who actually thought of that? So this critical information is behind menus and multiple clicks. Also, the fact that right click is to go back in menus rather than inspect something seems weird to me. Want to use an item during combat, well prepare to go through menus. It just seemed quite meh and shockingly clunky. | Very good strategy game with great soundtrack and story | Da franquia SteamWolrd esse Ã© facilmente o mais fraco... a exploraÃ§Ã£o Ã© basicamente ficar grudado no canto dos mapas, o combate Ã© super raso e desinteressante, a histÃ³ria tÃ¡ ali sÃ³ pra tapar buraco e tem uma quantidade desnecessÃ¡ria de diÃ¡logo mal escrito e a mÃºsica Ã© esquecÃ­vel, o Ãºnico ponto positivo Ã© o design dos personagens que sÃ£o bem interessantes, difÃ­cil acreditar que foi lanÃ§ado depois de Dig 2 e Heist

Genres: Adventure, Casual, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Early Access
Reviews:
This was just was I was looking for.  I signed in and immediately was drawn in by all the cute graphics and missions, building, and crafting to accomplish.  I've been spending 6 hours plus a day on it and time is flying and it is bringing me relaxing and happiness. | Swords 'n Magic and Stuff is an exceptionally deep and complex game presented through an invitingly adorable art style.

My brother and I were looking for a solid co-op campaign game with online multiplayer and this hits the spot perfectly.

Hidden secrets, RPG leveling mechanics, and interesting lore. This game has surprised me consistently and I'm thoroughly impressed with what the development team has created.

The demo is limited, but it provides a fantastic glimpse into the early game. Think the simplicity of Skyrim, mixed with the open world exploration of Wobbly Life. | I got this game on launch, played for a bit and put it down due to life getting busy.

Recently picked it back up again and man I am hooked, questing is fun, crafting and gathering is enjoyable, there's plenty of variety in weapons and builds (currently running a shield/mage staff combo that is very fun) and housing! The housing system has to be one of my favorites and I know I can always return to my little cottage on the island.


Not tried out multiplayer yet, but I think it will be a lot of fun when I do. I highly recommend this game.

Steam Deck support is also top notch!

/!\ Perfect fit for the Deck. "GOLD" on ProtonDB
https://www.protondb.com/app/813230 | It's probably just not for me. It's undeniable that it is a [i]well[/i]-made game, but Animal Well failed to make me want to continue into "Layer 2". While there is a sense of wonder and curiosity present from the start, any wanderlust that I had wore off by the end of "Layer 1". Traveling throughout the map became tedious and the thought of traversing it all again for a collect-a-thon did not appeal to me. The game is too obtuse to create any story related drive for me to do so, and the mechanics, while creative, are not fun enough.

I felt no motivation to continue sticking my yo-yo in damp and dark places.

. | This game has immense replayability simply because the core gameplay loop of smashing rats to bits never gets old. 

It starts a little slow, I'd say just keep pushing yourself because the higher difficulties is where the real fun is at.

For such a simple premise there is a surprising amount of depth with both the character builds and the levels. Learning the secrets and getting the books is all part of learning the game, and it's an area which i think really brings people together because carrying the books or completing the puzzles has to be a group effort. 

The devs also keep adding more maps for free which is fantastic. 

Highly recommend, even if you have no interest in warhammer. I played it alone,  but I can see how much fun it would be with more people. Good humor, nice story, quite difficult, but overall, very good. I enjoyed all of it.

Let's make one thing clear. Arkham Horror: Mother's Embrace is not the digital version of the famous board game, nor was it much beloved card game.

Arkham Horror: Mother's Embrace is more in spirit with JRPG than TTRPG. Was the game good? No, it is not as good as it should have been, but it could be way worst than what we got.

What you love/hate about Arkham Horror is here. The colorful character roster, the Sanity check, the Mythos penalties and so on. The graphic is decent, the soundtrack is fine, and surprisingly, the dialogues are fully voiced.

So would i recommend Arkham Horror: Mother's Embrace? It's depend how much you love Arkham Horror as a franchise. If you do, yeah, go ahead. Not like there is other option. If not, you would not miss anything. | This game sucks. The game won't let me change enemy targets, keeps forcing me to select the enemy the game wants me to select.  This game is a major fail. | If you like the Arkham Horror Games (especially Mansions of Madness): Take a look, you might like this game! Otherwise: Don't bother, there are better options.

That being said: I liked it. Primarily because I like the Arkham Horror Franchise and its characters. | It's fun if you enjoy the source material.
No Reviews

I wanted to like this game, but it is very lackluster, grindy, and repetitive. thank the lord its achievements were easy to accomplish so I may never touch this game again.

BTW the resurrection Idol needed to complete the potion achievement is in a chest on chapter 2 level 1.

Just feels like a straight downgrade from games from 20 years ago but I have a problem putting my finger on why exactly.  Maybe it's the graphics that feel too blocky. Maybe it's the overabundance of crappy hero equipment that devalues the joy of getting a stat improvement.  Maybe it's needing to invest level upgrades into just having more troops.  Maybe it's the arbitrary caps on how many troops can be in a stack.  Maybe it's the magic system with "mana" that is too bifurcated, obtuse and weak feeling.  

Either way I loved playing games like this for hundreds of hours, but this one I'm putting down with less than 10, something is wrong here, or many somethings. | ĞŸĞ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ñ Ğ»Ğ°Ğ¹Ğº Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ·Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¿Ñ‹Ñ‚ĞºÑƒ Ğ² ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ½Ñƒ Ğ“ĞµÑ€Ğ¾ĞµĞ². There are some useless, and some totally OP spells - and it doesnt usually depend on their cost. A good starting point can be to introduce the "Dispel" spell or anything like it to deal with crowd control. 
As updates are coming regularly, we might expect some improvements one day, but for now I cannot recommend this game

This is hard for me because I absolutely love this game. I think the game play is great albeit not the most balanced but still very fun to me. I cannot recommend because the developers stopped caring quite a while ago now. 

Things I loved about the game:
- Map and having to get recipes/items
- Having to stock up on ingredients
- Those ingredients took real space in the storage and were visible. 
- Multiple levels to the INN
- Time it took from ordering to receiving the item
- Art style and tone of the game

Things I very much do not like about the game:
- Devs abandoned it
- Dishes and mugs broke WAY too quickly
- Game was a buggy mess especially with staff
- Animals increased the buggy mess of it
- It was always the same crossroads and there was no randomness to it
- The perks tree was poorly designed imo, and should have shuffled
- Not enough control over staff including giving training or possibly removing bad traits
- The crafting was all under the same plot and everything, I would have loved if you could have expanded to different plots where some grow food or make plates or candles or whatever and then have those items shipped back. 

All in all I have put a fair amount of time into this game. Even though it is a buggy mess I can't play other tavern games because the things I love in this game simply don't exist in those games. I really wish the game were better and fully finished. I wish someone could pick up the concept and make the exact same game but significantly more competently. If the sale is really good, I guess pick it up if you want to check it out. It really isn't worth it because the issues will never be fixed. Which is a real shame and why I cannot recommend the game. | Ã‡erezlik bir oyun olmuÅŸ, Orta Ã§aÄŸda ufak bir han iÅŸletip ister sandbox isterse ufak hikayesini oynayarak takÄ±labilirsiniz. | This game had the potential to be a lot of fun, but there are just too many bugs.

A lot of things to upgrade and craft
The style is detailed
Hard but somewhat fair
You get drawbacks from dying but in a fair way (you have to craft a potion to get rid of the drawbacks which in itself takes some time to gather - Hint: you only need ONE potion to get rid of multiple drawbacks from dying).
Sounds are great

Negatives
Some things that you craft are so tied into other things you craft that need the same stuff, there is no way to pin a recipe, which makes it tiresome.
Even though tools and weapons are made of TITANIUM they break like glass (should last easily 10x longer in my opinoin)
The inventory space doesnâ€™t justify the amount of different things you can collect.
You have to scroll through a list in the different workbenches which becomes more of a hustle the more you upgrade. Besides that, things that you can craft is not sorted on top, you have to scroll through things you canâ€™t craft in order to see what you can craft. And every workbench has at least 50 different things to craft. This should be sorted into different tier instead of just a long laundry list.
The game feels like a flash-game because of input-lag of some sort. Besides that the game also prefers keyboard-input more than mouse input. For example - when crafting things you only craft one at a time, if you spam RMB it waits for the greyed-out button to become â€œinteractableâ€ again. But when you spam â€˜Eâ€™ (by default) you can easily spam that. However you donâ€™t know how much youâ€™ve crafted until you let go because it takes half a second for it to update how much you craft. When fighting animation sometimes do no damage or it doesnâ€™t register, it takes time for the damage to update. That is also for things you pick up after kills (â€˜Qâ€™) the prompt stays even though the item is gone.

Conclusion
The game is interesting and maybe better to play with a friend. Playing it alone is not recommended because you have to build, fight, gather, mine, craft tools and weapons that breaks constantly, fend off enemies when your base is getting attacked, gather offerings when it prompts you to do so (if you fail within the limited time you will lose progress)

If you can stand the input lag and have a friend with you it could be fun. That I could recommend. There is tons to upgrade and explore which keeps this interesting. In my 17 hours of gameplay I have just scratched the surface.

4/10 - singleplayer
6/10 - Co-op

Shadow of War is arguably the best Lord of the Rings game ever made if you want to feel like a god-like, unstoppable, bad ass, half ranger, half wraith, mind controlling, head chopping killing machine that also commands armies to conquer giant settlements all over middle earth. This game plays so unbelievably smooth and pushes the unique nemesis system to its brink. Visually stunning, a more than serviceable story, insanely satisfying and flashy combat similar to that of the Arkham games (I would say perfected freeflow combat) and faithful to Tolkein loreT, this game is a GEM and is another example of taking what made the first one so amazing and dialing that up to whole nother level. Its a shame that there is no news of another badass adventure in Middle Earth coming from Monolith Soft with the Nemesis system as any LOTR fan would undoubtedly be excited for that. Can be a little overwhelming at the start with how much power this game gives you at your fingertips but if you stick with it, it can get hard to put down. | ë°œí—¤ì„ìœ¼ë¡œ ì˜¤ì‹­ì‹œì˜¤. | I love Valheim, it is a great game up to the plains biome. The main appeal is that it is a hard but not a frustrating game. The newest biomes, Mistlands and Ashlands have changed that. The main focus of those biomes seems to be frustration. 
Mistlands is hard to traverse, there is sheer cliffs everywhere. The devs somewhat had to admit that by adding a potion that makes jumping easier. And in the Ashlands enemies spawn at constant rates, you never have the feeling that you accomplish something. In addition, it is hard to navigate with the ship. There is a massive ring of stones around the Ashlands, so you literarily must ship out of the biome, go to the lateral point and then back in. You cannot go horizontally with the ship. And I don't understand why that is. You must use a massive ship that is slow and tedious to manouver and then you must move around places where the ship can barely fit. So, in essence the main focus to make a survival game that is not frustrating was thrown out and the main mechanics of the new biomes is to make core mechanics like moving around and exploration more tedious.

The Longing is a delightfully lonely experience, with your only company being a quiet timid creature simply named "The Shade." 
The moment you finish the intro, a timer appears at the top of the screen, counting down 400 real time days. Time passes even when the game is closed, or your device is powered off. 
From there, it's just you, a sprawling cave system, and a lonely little shadow who just wants to find some sort of comfort in their solitary life.

Pros: 
-Lovely hand drawn scenery
-Incredibly simple, yet pleasing, controls.
-Occasional comments from the Shade that just make you want to give the lil fella a hug
-A massive 'detox' from the widespread high adrenaline, constant input games that have become commonplace.
-Hidden treasures that appeal to those with a goblin hoarding instinct

Cons(?):
-I found the music to annoying, but you can toggle it (as well as atmospheric lighting and sound effects) very easily
-It can be occasionally frustrating just how incredibly slow the Shade walks, especially when you travel across a vast tunnel, only to find you've already been there, it's a dead end, and you must walk all the way back. (But as long as you save the "memory" of signifigant places like your home, you can simply click the location and wait for the lil fella to automatically walk the distance)
-The lack of explanation before beginning a time consuming task makes it so you never know if the time spend (whether it be minutes, hours, or even days) will be worth waiting for. (On the flip side, it makes it that much more rewarding when you *do* discover something special)

Conclusion:
If you're one to pursue high adrenaline, stress inducing games with fast paced gameplay, this is not the game for you.
Then again, perhaps it's just the game you need to re-discover the art of slowing things down, finding joy in the simple things, and empathize with the lonely. | 400 Ğ´Ğ½ĞµĞ¹ ÑˆĞ°Ñ€Ğ¾Ñ‘Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ¼ÑÑ Ğ¿Ğ¾ Ğ¿ĞµÑ‰ĞµÑ€Ğ°Ğ¼ Ğ² Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¸ÑĞºĞ°Ñ… ĞºĞ¾Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ°. Ğ ĞµĞºĞ¾Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ğ´ÑƒÑ.

7/10. | There's fun to be had here but it's weighed down by a build system that is almost entirely RNG-based.

You collect gold, plus mana in each of several categories (obtained by your students studying that subject). When you get enough of a category you can draw a card for an item or new room of that category - you're presented with three options and pick one. These options are entirely RNG-based.

What that means is that you may go into a map thinking you want to try an Arcane and Nature school and then just never draw the requisite cards to get it going. Or, you may know you need more dormitories for your students but the game just never gives you the card. You can't really plan the school out because you really have no idea what the game is going to let you build with the bizarre luck-of-the-draw system.

On the plus side, there's a lot of charm in the graphics and the game does a great job with the "feel" of magic. The classrooms are cool and your kids can get items like devil's horns, staves, regalia, etc. It really does feel like a magic school.

It's just such an odd choice from the developers to make the build system completely based on dice rolls. | I love this game, the main campaign is perfect, there is some replay ability, if you like experimenting, I do. Definitely recommend, my only gripe is that I selfishly want more.

See students join different factions and maybe that gives you influence during encounters because your student runs a specific department for that faction. There used to be a time when a game would be released in it's 1.0 foundational state, and it was fundamentally considered [i]complete[/i]. It meant that all the gameplay and story elements were in place, and any ancillary content could be added in at a future date. 
This could include extra story elements, items, dungeons, expansions, patches, and DLC etc.

Apparently, not anymore.

I waited for years to see Last Epoch exit early access and finally hit that glorious 1.0 release.
I even waited another year for the game to have all the creases ironed out.

So, I purchased the game, and was having a decent time. 
...that is, until the main quest storyline just 'stopped'.
Now to be clear, I don't mean it [i]concluded[/i]. I mean, it just 'stops' half-way through the story, and then you're left to go do mindless end-game farming. 
I genuinely thought my game was bugged and that the main quest wasn't showing. But a bit of research had me find out that the devs didn't think to complete the most basic element of a game - the story, before a 1.0 launch.

And what's worse, is that people just defend this type of practise?

Imagine if I sold you a book, but left the back half completely blank, and I told you "I'll write the rest some time in the future. Not really sure when though"
Not a sequel, but I'll finish the first book at some indeterminate time in the future.
Nebulous much?

Or imagine you sit down at a restaurant, and the waiter brings you only half of your meal, and says "We only made the first half - even though you paid for all of it. We'll eventually cook you the second half, at some point. Just not today. But you can have dessert! We have loads of dessert!"
Ludicrous. And yet, that's the standard that is being accepted more and more nowadays.

Sure, Last Epoch has some great elements to it. Genuinely.
Character building is cool. Loot filters in the game are top-notch. Visuals can be great.
But presentation means little when the foundational product is incomplete - [b]at full price[/b].

Ridiculous. 
Truthfully, I feel cheated. And looking at the 2025 road-map, where story content will be added 'some time later', I realise I should've just waited until the far off future when the game price will have likely dropped. 
Cheaper price for an 'actual' finished product.

This just feels like a lazy rush-to-market strategy, and I'd refund if I could, however it took me way more than the allotted refund time to know that the story would just 'cut off'. Which seems scummy.

Also, apparently even one of the game devs thinks you're being too unreasonable in expecting a 1.0 full release of a game to be, y'know, [i]'fully completed'[/i]. As he said that the 1.0 distinction of the game is "Fairly Arbitrary".
I call major bs on that one. 
You don't get to redefine what "Full Release" means, just to account for your lack of complete content. 

Furthermore, the endgame content, while nice in theory, honestly just boils down to this:

- Click a big floaty island in space.
- Now click on a smaller floaty island in space and fight a bunch of enemies.
- Do 10-20 more of these smaller floaty islands - with the same grinding of enemies.
- Now you've unlocked a boss fight.
- Fight said boss
- Click another big floaty island in space and repeat.

It's boring, and in no way a good placeholder for a completed and memorable story.

If the game was completed, I would've looked back on the game and thought "Yeah wow. That was a nice experience. Not [i]the best I've ever played[/i], but nice. And that's worth a recommend."

As it stands, I think you should stay away from the game for another year (or possibly two) - as of this review date, and reassess the state of the game at that time.

Until then, don't perpetuate crappy business standards - or they'll become normalised and you'll be the only one paying for it. | ç¦»çº¿æ¨¡å¼è¦è”ç½‘ç©ï¼Œè”æœºä½“éªŒæå·®ï¼Œæœªå…¥æ‰‹çš„å»ºè®®å…ˆçœ‹çœ‹è§†é¢‘å’Œè¯„æµ‹è§‚æœ›ã€‚ | The game isn't fun. This is a combination of skills that feel unimpactful, low monster density, overall slow game pace, low difficulty, and an endgame that encourages you to just rush through to the objective as fast as you can rather than kill anything, among other reasons.

Most of the praise around this game will be about "potential" rather than what's actually there. If you've played or followed this game since the beta you should know that the developers have done absolutely nothing to demonstrate they can ever deliver on this potential. What's actually implemented is very bare-bones, often buggy, and not fun/interesting. Will the game be good eventually? Maybe, but unlikely. And should you spend money on a game that isn't good right now? Absolutely not.

Game Name: Sacred Fire: A Role Playing Game
Reviews:
Wow. This game achieved what a lot of visual novels can't. Giving you a sense of agency and decision over the story while feeling challenging in a way that moves the story forward.
I've seen 3 "endings" (the final act is not out yet) and I'm hooked. :) I can't wait to see the rest and start new playthroughs. I love how the game gives you tools to tell it what your character wants and feels towards NPCs so that the story weaves itself accordingly.
Incredibly smart narrative design and story-telling.

10/10 | This is honestly incredible and I'm glad I gave this project money. I want to see more of this and more games like this. If we can have more scenery and subtle animations, I think it would even improve the experience. I completed chapter one and then unfortunately had to go to bed, but I'm excited to get to the next chapter and to see what's to come next.

I do want to say, I wish there were more hair styles to choose from. | I have played this game through multiple times and it is one of my favorite story/choice based games. The setting is unique and it has a great visual art style. Its clear that the dev has put love and care into the game which is what the gaming industry needs. Well worth the price as I have put over 60 hours into it with no regrets.

Genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
Reviews:
A mix of Dark Messiah's combat and Arx's world building and interactivity.
Maps can feel a little convoluted at times and a bit empty, but overall a good time. | Impressive for a single indie guy to produce. It reminds me of old school crawlers like Daggerfall. Good job. Here is hoping there are a LOT of new areas in the release,and maybe some DLC later on. Good Luck,nice work.
 | It's fun. A modern Arx Fatalis-like. A sim game where you don't do anything well to start with. 

It has a dark souls/bioshock corpse run system for reasons entirely unclear to me. When you die you'll respawn at the last shrine you rested at if the shrine is in the same area. If there is no shrine or you haven't found one then you just have to load a save... 

Dear devs: Why did you do this? You do realize you implemented a save/load system right? Dark souls does the bloodstain thing because of its 'hardcore' constant saving design. When you die you can just reload in this like any normal game. You have innovated a way to make a normal saving system somehow worse. Ultimately it doesn't matter because you can just manually save/load, but it's still baffling. Probably left over from a much earlier design. | I had fun with it. Wish there was a little more content, as it was for me, only good for 13.5hrs. | First off, I played the demo.

I loved it, even with it flaws I found.

Tho many of those flaws was already fix, after I bought the game and played the current content. (Which is alot bigger and better then the old content of the demo).
The demo only has 1 map, the current game has 2 vast maps, with around 4x mini dungeon within these maps. It had puzzles, secrets and other problem solving, done is a very fun way.

I would discribe this game as a if Elder scrolls Daggerfall & Arx fatalis had a baby. =)

A quick sum of what I loved:
The magic system
The cooking system
The repair system
The wolrd/lore was intressting enough for me wanting to know more.
The core exploration feeling/need, even if most is underground in caves/castles/forts.
The enemies was intressting as well, even tho from what I could understand. The enemies "wastelanders", are just "normal" humans. But I always saw them as goblins/orcs. Might be the "curse" of the wasteland maby?

Beyond that, all enemies was fun to find and fight. Tho I mainly played the game as a pure caster build.
Which I can say few things I didnt like:

Player knowledge about the system itself, can sometimes be a bit poor sometimes. Some is understandable, it gives you a chance to learn by doing.

But with a rpg with limited skill points/attribute points, I am kind of player who plan out a build from lvl 1. So I want to know the core of what each skill/attribute do and do not.
Attributes for me as a mage was easy to understand, but for me it was the skills that created a little unnecessary confusion.

As the three magic skills is: Divine, Aura and Cosmic, but noting in their description mentions much needed info. As for all these three skills, if reached skill 10 your character will start regen mana on its own. That regen will only grow stronger the close to max of 20. Likewise if you have 2x max magic skills the regen will be even stronger. 

Likewise, spells will also change into more powerfull versions the higher your skill is in that school. (Tho it is not fully not implemented yet with all spells) As I belive not all spells are ofc in the game yet.

I could add more of what I liked and disliked, but I find this be a good enough "review" for the moment at least ^^

runs well on steamdeck with ge-proton.

this game is basically wing commander privateer remake in the best way possible.

 | I jumped into this after like a 100 hour FreeSpace series binge and after remapping the controls I instantly felt home. I have not played the original first game yet so that is why I think it is not as horrible as the reviews make it out to be but there are definitely some weak points. Here are my points below in no particular order.

What I liked: 

- difficulty without all the aim assist was decent enough when it comes to pure 1v1 dogfights
- unique visual style
- amazing soundtrack
- cool main character
- runs well
- nice mini games in the bar, I spent quite a few hours with just playing pool and dice poker
- flipping off enemies and trash talking through comms
- you can have your own station
- companions

What I disliked:

- the star systems are too big to the point they do not make sense, you can skip travel but even with that I felt it was tedious to go through several systems
- barely anything to do, missions seem varied at first but there are a lot of repeat offenders with barely anything different yet being labelled as something else
- nothing visually unique about the star systems, like if you played Freelancer and saw a mostly red background you knew you were in Bretoina, there is none of that here, the last system you go to is exactly like the first one you start in
- your own station is heavily underutilized, the game does not really go out of its way to tell you this is even a thing
- enemies sort of scale with you defeating the sense of progression, I was able to farm credits for end game gear in the starting system and meet end game enemies
-companions have some side missions but there is not much point and most of them are useless if you call them to help you
- main story felt like it just ended randomly without properly resolving the root of the conflict
- absolutely abysmal way for missions to trigger into their next phase, I could do 10 system jumps without triggering anything, sometimes I got it after just going near a station
- the fastest ships are exclusive to the enemies

I did not even notice I wrote a wall of text, oh well, it is ok to play through once, it is really sad that the developer was literally bullied out of game making. | Great Game, Almost as good as the first Game Rebel Galaxy (witch i still play), But I do miss being able to hire a 
 Wingman in the Bar.

Lo bueno, la historia, es divertida y emotiva en ciertos momentos, la voz del detective es como escuchar a SpiderNoir o la peli Sin City. Los puzzles son variados.
Lo no tan bueno, que sino fuese por la accion de mostrar los objetos interactuables hay algunos que serian imposible de detectar, y ciertos puzzles son muy confusos sino se presta atencion a ciertos dialogos.
Vale la pena jugarlo a todos los que amen este genero. 7/10 | Pour moi, c'est un trÃ¨s bon point & click. Visuellement, il est trÃ¨s beau, l'humour marche bien, l'histoire est bien, mais un peu court. | Bravo-Bravissimo!!! It's a beautiful game with a wonderful art and some funny story! I very-very-very like it. I really enjoyed it. Thank you very much! | Very funny and sweet game :)

Game Name: Alaloth: Champions of The Four Kingdoms
Reviews:
"Beautiful but Flawed non Co-op: A D&D-Inspired Journey"

Alaloth boasts stunning visuals with incredibly detailed and animated models, truly capturing the essence of a classic tabletop RPG. The combat system is engaging and rewarding, and the developers consistently deliver updates and new content, showing a commendable level of passion.

However, the map travel can feel somewhat tedious, although it's consistent with the genre. My biggest disappointment lies in the "Shared/Split Screen Co-op" tagged. Instead of cooperative play, it's a PvP mode, which is significantly different from what was initially implied or suggested. This is a major letdown for those who were expecting a cooperative experience.

Overall: Alaloth has a lot to offer with its captivating visuals and engaging combat. However, the misleading information regarding the "co-op" mode, which is actually a PvP mode, significantly detracts from the overall experience, especially for those who were drawn to the game specifically for that feature.

Pros:

Stunning visuals and detailed character models
Engaging combat system
Dedicated developers with regular updates
Strong D&D-inspired atmosphere
Cons:

Tedious map travel
"Co-op" mode is actually a PvP mode, not cooperative play
Misleading advertising regarding "co-op" as a feature

Recommendation:

If you're looking for a visually impressive and combat-focused RPG with a strong D&D vibe, Alaloth might still be worth a look. However, be aware that the "co-op" mode is actually PvP, and proceed with caution if you were expecting a cooperative rpg experience. | Great game, I'm loving every minute playing it.

Pros:
- Engaging combat mechanics: weak and strong attacks, dodge, parry/block and up to six special abilities and/or spells. More than enough to keep it interesting
- Big world to explore with every location being unique and handrafted
- Lots of different and unique loot
- Locations have perfect size. You can usually complete any dungeon (Fighting Area) in 5-10 mins and then decide to go to another one or to play with your kids.

Con:
- Early game is hard. You need gear, more levels and possibly companions to comfortably clear dungeons. Later it gets easier. | Pues me estÃ¡ pareciendo un juegazo, como los de antes, sin ayudas...solo en un mundo cruel, despiadado e injusto. 

El combate es gloria, por fin salir airoso tiene tanta importancia tus estadÃ­sticas como tÃº habilidad, un 10 aquÃ­.

Los grÃ¡ficos , no son top, pero cumplen sobradamente, pero artÃ­sticamente estÃ¡n genial, que en estos juegos importa esto mÃ¡s. 

Lo recomiendo a todo amante de los juegos de fÃºtbol. | I like the idea of the game but I don't like the game.

Combat is really floaty, I don't feel much like I'm really interacting with the enemies. They did try to put in a compelling combat system but it makes no sense when the enemy AI is so basic. The enemies literally just swarm you and swing the same attack as soon as they can. It feels like a game from 30 years ago in that regard.

The KB + M controls are horrendous.

Cities are dull and lifeless. 

The game is purposefully archaic which sucks what little fun there was away. | It's OK/Good. 

Inspired by a few of my favourites and a cool art style. The only problem really is that the stamina system is very arbitrary and doesn't really work well as a balancing feature. It takes away from the combat if anything and makes it a little unsatisfying (especially early game). The durability system also falls into this camp too but I think it works for the style of campaign. 

On the other hand the combat is generally satisfying (stamina aside) story seems cool, world maps and arenas are cool, enemy design is cool (again a downside of the stamina system  here is that I don't appreciate the enemies as much because you're fighting the stamina system half the time, rather than focusing on enemies). Game runs well, isn't cluttered on MnK and seems to be receiving updates and content patches which is cool. 

Hoping it gets better as I go along and I'd suggest giving it a try.
fun

DeathTrash is a quintessential "Forever Early Access" title. The store page and product description may suggest that a final release or version of this game is in development, with an expected release of "sometime". I believe the store page, as of this review, suggests 2025 as a release date.

I bought this title very shortly after its entrance to Early Access, under recommendations of a critic who generally matches my interests.

I have spent the intervening three and a half years with a license to a build that has undergone few, if any notable changes. It has been a foundational memory in my purchasing habits since, and I now rarely engage with early access titles.

I had a total of about five hours of unique content on my first playthrough, which was about the amount of content I saw two years later, in 2023. I am increasingly concerned with Crafting Legends' ability to ship this product. As a small team of two individuals, I question whether a product of this size and ambition was ever reasonable within the projected timeframes and budget.

I do not recommend Death Trash as an Early Access product. I do not think what is currently available is worth twenty dollars, and I am not confident that the price, nor content will change. Should this product see a final build, I will return to the game to edit and re-write my review. | Not quite Abandonware, but even after 4 years it's not leaving Early Access any time soon. All updates are small & cosmetic. Frequent stretches of radio silence. There's a great core to this game, and it would be an easy recommend if it were finished...or updating on time...or offered for under $9.00. But they're still asking $20 (unless it's on sale, at which point it's "only" $16) for an unfinished and almost-abandoned game. True disappointment. | This game could be really, really great. It is a shame that because the team is so small, the amount of work is just too staggering to complete in a reasonable amount of time before people inevitably begin to move on. And for that to happen to a game like this, a game with THIS much potential....really sucks. | It is essentially abandonware at this point. They seem to push an update (without new content) after Steam marks them over a year without updating in EA. This game is turning into another example of "Reasons to Avoid EA games." | It's not a long game. It's in early access, and development has been quite slow, but the quality of what it is is very good.

I love the fighting mechanics. It's very well executed and requires some skill to get good at it, and it's very satisfying once you pull it off successfully.
The story and the worldbuilding is excellent. I'm guessing this is why it takes so long time.

It has so much potential. Even though it's unfinished, I think it's worth getting into it now, but know you should know what you're getting into.
It also works great on the steam deck.

Ğ’ÑĞµĞ¼ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°, ÑƒĞ´Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ¸ Ğ¸ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¹ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñ‹! ^_^[/i] | Ğ¿Ğ¾ Ñ„Ğ°ĞºÑ‚Ñƒ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ´Ğ»Ñ Ğ´ĞµÑ‚ĞµĞ¹ Ğ½Ğ¾ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¼ Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ³Ğ´Ğµ Ğ²ÑĞµ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ²ĞµÑ€ÑÑÑ‚ Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¼Ñƒ Ñ‡ĞµĞ»Ğ¾Ğ²ĞµĞºÑƒ Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´ ĞºĞ¾Ğ½ĞµÑ† Ğ¾Ğ½ Ğ¾ĞºĞ°Ğ·Ñ‹Ğ²Ğ°ĞµÑ‚ÑÑ Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ´Ğ°Ñ‚ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ¼ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ absolute cimena | ä¼˜åŒ–æ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰çš„ï¼Œå¤‡å—è¾±éª‚æ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰æ‚”æ”¹çš„ï¼Œå¤–æŒ‚æ˜¯ä¸€å¤§å †çš„ï¼Œåˆ›æ–°æ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰çš„ï¼Œè¢«æŠ„äº†æ˜¯ä¸ç®¡çš„ï¼ŒçœŸæƒ³ä¸åˆ°è¿™æ¸¸æˆæ˜¯æ€ä¹ˆæ´»ä¸‹æ¥çš„ | [b]Among Us took the gaming world by storm, proving that sometimes, the simplest games create the most unforgettable moments. Whether you're completing tasks like a diligent crewmate or plotting deception as an imposter, this game is all about strategy, teamwork, and betrayal.

The gameplay is easy to understand but leads to intense, hilarious, and sometimes frustrating interactions. One moment, you're quietly fixing wires, and the next, you're passionately defending yourself in an emergency meeting after being falsely accused. The mix of deduction and deception makes every round unpredictable and fun.

What makes Among Us special is the social experience. It thrives on communication (and miscommunication), whether you're playing with friends or random players. The joy of convincing others to vote someone off, only to realize they were innocent, creates endless entertainment.

Visually, it's simple and colorful, with cute character designs that contrast the brutal reality of getting ejected into space. The sound design, from the satisfying task completion beeps to the ominous kill animations, adds to the tension.

While Among Us is at its best with a group of friends, public lobbies can be hit-or-miss, depending on how people play. The game has also evolved with new roles, maps, and customization options, keeping things fresh for long-time players.

In conclusion, Among Us is a fantastic party game that blends strategy and chaos in the best way possible. Itâ€™s proof that great multiplayer experiences donâ€™t need complex mechanicsâ€”just a solid concept and the right group of people. If you love games that test friendships and create hilarious memories, this oneâ€™s a must-play![/b] |

Swift progression, minimal backtracking, compelling upgrades, delightful movement mechanics and gameplay, enticing story. Then it falls victim to all the metroidvania sins like obscure or confusing paths, tons of backtracking, poorly placed save points, and fractional upgrades. When it's rolling along well, it's a true joy, but then there are big blockages to really enjoying the meat and potatoes of the game which is busting out of ventilation shafts and tearing people to shreds before eating them. The game teases you with a few glimpses where you think maybe there could be some post-[spoiler]escape[/spoiler] segments, leads you right up to that moment, and then thanks you for playing. I wish I could recommend this because it's truly unique and fun when it works, but it locks bursts of tentacle rending behind stale and frustrating chokepoints. | this game is great at full price but now it's only 5.99 on Steam and worth every penny. | ĞšĞ»Ğ°ÑÑĞ½Ğ°Ñ ÑˆÑ‚ÑƒĞºĞ°.

Game Name: Druidstone: The Secret of the Menhir Forest
Reviews:
Fun "little" game with surprisingly complex battles. Highly recommended if you are fan of isometric RPGs and Turn based. | ĞÑ‚Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ‡Ğ½Ğ°Ñ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°. Ğ¡Ğ¿Ğ¾ĞºĞ¾Ğ¹Ğ½Ğ°Ñ, ĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ¸Ğ²Ğ°Ñ, Ğ±ĞµĞ· Ğ»Ğ¸ÑˆĞ½Ğ¸Ñ… ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ½Ğ¾ÑÑ‚ĞµĞ¹...ÑĞ°Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğµ Ñ‚Ğ¾, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ‹ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑĞ»Ğµ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ‚Ñ‹ Ğ¿ĞµÑ€ĞµĞ´ ÑĞ½Ğ¾Ğ¼ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¿Ğ°Ñ€Ñƒ Ñ‡Ğ°ÑĞ¸ĞºĞ¾Ğ². | The game is honestly just...not that good? 
I'll preface this by saying I jumped right in at hard difficulty. It's not really challenging, just tedious. 
The story is...nonexistant. Your little mage tonberry ripoff does the ironic metahumor thing that ruins the entire experience. We get it, you're the developer's favorite character. but your ironic 4th wall quips are just not funny. 

They couldn't really figure out how to make levels more challenging so they just have infinitely spawning enemies. 
The game mechanics are questionable and not fully thought out. Here's some examples:

-Your melee guy doesn't get much in terms of armor, meanwhile you can level him up to give allies next to him +1 armor pretty early on. Effectively your support and mage become better at taking hits than the tank itself. For a good while. 
-You have an ability called Guard that will attack anyone getting in range, but this ability requires enemies to be next to the melee guy even if he equips a Halberd. that allows him to attack two squares away. Zero cohesion between skills in this card based system. 
-If you put bows on your support you're throttling yourself since bows have incredibly low damage. The default bow is better than the first bow upgrade because of the armor pen, and you won't see another ranged weapon for a while. Meanwhile every successful mission unlocks a bunch of useless melee weapons. Why would you make your support do damage? because most of her support abilities don't cost resources anyway. And she is far too squishy without the armor upgrade to be in melee. So effectively the game shoehorns how you play the support, and they deliberately make sure you do almost no damage with her if you play how they intend you to play.
-There's a reason why most games of this type are hex based. Square grid layout makes it annoying to spot when enemies are next to you on corners. Going from 6 to 9 possible squares of attacks, attacks of opportunity, on corners, is visually harder to spot and frankly looks janky and terrible
-Speaking of attacks of opportunity: I get that you guys copied the base mechanic from DnD, but you do realize monsters are supposed to only attack *once* per turn right? Watching my guy get clapped because he dared to move around the centipede twice in one turn was hilarious. Unless you have that special disengage skill, your characters become effectively rooted in place.  And because of the 9 possible squares of attacks, the skill is actually way less useful so you need a few of those just to get away from enemies. 

I'd say what the game *actually* is about is clever teleport swap tricks with the mage. Everything else just kinda feels like it enables that. And that by itself is not really fun.

EDIT:
After finishing the game, I'd also like to say it's too short. I have 60 hours played because I left it on overnight a few times. Overall about 35 hours worth of content, spanning across 35 missions, a few of which are straight up non-combat puzzles. You unlock a 4th character fairly late into the game to boot. It doesn't really feel like your characters actually full realize their roles until they'lre about level 6 or 7, at which point the game is kinda close to being done. There's no way to respec either, even after finishing the game. The final boss fight is also...incredibly unfun with the mechanics.

Probably will do a replay on a highr difficulty.

This game is completely linear, no sidetracks, only some smaller collectibles to upgrade your gear. Honestly, JUST PLAY IT (on a discount)

PS To add insult to injury THQ Nordic added NG+ achievements, but not NG+. Like, why? ğŸ¤¦â€â™‚ï¸ | Chronos: Before the Ashes is an action RPG that serves as a prequel to Remnant: From the Ashes. It offers a unique aging mechanic where your character ages one year every time they die, impacting their stats & abilities. While this mechanic is interesting, the game itself is a fairly standard action RPG with some noticeable flaws.

You play as a young warrior on a quest to save their homeland from an ancient evil. The story is fairly straightforward & serves primarily as a setup for the gameplay. The world is divided into several distinct realms, each with its own visual style & enemy types.

The combat is a mix of melee & magic, with a focus on timing & dodging. As you age, your character's stats change, affecting their combat style. For example, younger characters are faster & more agile, while older characters are stronger but slower. This mechanic adds an interesting layer to the combat, forcing you to adapt your playstyle as you progress.

However, Chronos: Before the Ashes suffers from several issues. The level design is often linear & uninspired, lacking the intricate level design of many other action RPGs. The enemy variety is also limited, & many of the encounters feel repetitive.

The aging mechanic, while unique, is not fully realized. While it does affect your stats, it doesn't have a significant impact on the story or character interactions. It feels like a missed opportunity to create a more compelling narrative & gameplay experience.

**Pros:**

*   Unique aging mechanic! ğŸ‘´
*   Decent combat system with a mix of melee & magic! âš”ï¸
*   Varied realms with distinct visual styles! ğŸï¸

**Cons:**

*   Linear & uninspired level design! ğŸ—ºï¸
*   Limited enemy variety! ğŸ‘¾
*   Aging mechanic not fully realized! ğŸ¤”
*   Story is fairly straightforward & unengaging! ğŸ“–
*   Can feel repetitive after a while! ğŸ”

**Verdict:** 6/10. Chronos: Before the Ashes is a decent action RPG with an interesting aging mechanic, but it ultimately falls short due to its uninspired level design, limited enemy variety, & underdeveloped story. While it provides some enjoyable combat & exploration, it doesn't do enough to stand out from other games in the genre. It's a decent prequel to Remnant, but it's not an essential experience. ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸

***

**Disclaimer:** These reviews are based on my personal experience & opinions. Your mileage may vary. I am an AI & have not been paid to endorse this product. Please be aware that game content, pricing, & availability may change. Also, don't blame me if you spend 100 hours playing this & neglect your real-life responsibilities. ğŸ˜… | Really enjoyed my time with the game. Obviously quite a bit shorter than the Remnant games but I enjoyed getting a bit more background on the story of those games and honestly, while a little bit clunky at times, the melee combat was refreshing compared to the gun play of the other games. Definitely give it a go if you enjoy the Remnant games and want more.

Game Name: We Who Are About To Die
Genres: Action, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy, Early Access
Reviews:
Fun game.  Hard to play but I'm an old head and like games that don't give instant gratification that so many of the new games do.  Keep up the great work guys! | Just to start this off I would like to say that this is a great project with a very nice idea which initially drew me in but now the game moved in a much worse direction mechanics wise ( in my opinion )

While the game was still in early development the combat felt much better, swings actually went the way you intended, the enemies moved at an appropriate pace and were attacking in a visible yet challenging manner

That is not the case anymore as I booted this game up after a long break, enemies zoom to your location or even past you, insta hit you for massive damage with out any telegraphing, your hits feel like you are in a dream trying to punch. It is sad to see this state of the combat as all of the other content surrounding it is very fun ( traits, events and so on )

I cannot recommend this game in it's current state if you are looking for a fun, replayable and enjoyable combat experience | Ğ˜Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ½Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°ÑÑŒ, Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑĞ»Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ±ĞµĞ´Ñ‹ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ½Ğµ Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞµÑ‚ÑÑ. Ğ‘ÑƒĞ´ĞµÑ‚ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÑ, ĞµÑĞ»Ğ¸ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ°Ğ²ÑÑ‚ Ğ´Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ¶ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ñ Ñ Ğ¸ÑĞ¿Ñ‹Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ÑĞ¼Ğ¸ | æ¸¸æˆè®¾è®¡çš„å¾ˆå¸®ï¼Œæ‰“å‡»æ„Ÿä¹Ÿä¸é”™ï¼Œä½†å»ºè®®èƒ½æ ‡è®°å‹æ–¹ï¼Œä¸ç„¶æˆ‘æ¯æ¬¡éƒ½æ€é˜Ÿå‹ | I think this is a decent game. It struggles in that there are some glaring parts of the game that make me sigh and never want to play it again. Getting hit by falling weapons of slain foes and taking damage. Rag doll enemies that whip around like inflatables after getting hit, nearly guaranteed to return a hit to anyone foolish enough to be in proximity. Questionable ally AI that makes fighting side by side more trouble than its worth. Getting sniped by these insufferable, unmanned turrets while in-between tournament fights.

Now that I have completed a Lionslayer run on Condemned, I can confidently say that I know how to play We Who Are About To Die. With that said, mastering the spears in the game was beyond me. I'm not sure if there is fault with my camera angle, or else it is extremely picky on the angles used, but to me the spears were never effective. It drew me into a larger issue I had with the game, which is there were some weapons that seemed much better than others.

Throwing is my favorite example. While extremely difficult, the damage throwing provided and it's anti shield properties made it a requirement. Otherwise it became a slog trying to punch through hundreds of durability worth of shields, especially in one v many fights. Good luck getting that mileage out of a mace. In fact, while the flails performed acceptably all other hammers were woefully lacking in performance. My two lionslayer runs saw a sword and an axe, with plenty of throwing of course. Now if someone offered me a purple mace or a throwing pilum for the next fight, i'd take my chances with the pilum. 

The traits need to be examined much closer. Sick is a terrible trait that I evade. Villain was another that felt odd, as in practice only one background ever drove me into negative approval, whereas otherwise I remained over 100% approval. The peg leg and the one arm do not compare, in my mind. I won with one arm, but I doubt I could pull off a lionslayer win with a peg. The peg leg provides no bonuses in the way that the one arm does, which makes it arguably an extremely bad trait. Some positive traits felt better than others. Haggler and Valerius having the same effect was strongly mediocre. There were some weird gaps, such as hammer time, but no equivalents for swords or axes. Frenzy felt almost always worth it, seeing as most fights required the simple formula of do more hits than get hit. So 20% fewer hits to end fight seems like good math. 

Now that I have completed the backgrounds I don't imagine I'll play again. While completing the challenges was fun, the condemned run actually went easier than my criminal background. It was a hollow victory receiving a win for "completing the ultimate challenge". I walked away thinking about all of the rank ups where I invested in the "+100 gold to next character" only for the ultimate challenge to show not only that I wouldn't benefit from the investment. Not only that, but in winning I found that these boons I had acquired were so inconsequential it was hard to feel like they added anything. 

I enjoyed the physics and combat systems. It reminds me of chivalry, but if it was jankier and in gladiator themed. It can scratch the itch of those wanting single player gladiator games, but if that genre doesn't appeal its probably worth skipping. The rogue-lite system of benefiting from previous runs is too bare-bones and the progression is predominantly in player skill, as opposed to earned rewards.

 | Easy to play, difficult to master.

Absolutely worth spending a some time on this little gem, particularly in earlier levels before you settle on your preferred team offers plenty of variety and interest. After a while it can become a little goldfishy after the main campaign but there is a certain appeal in that. You can min-max to your heart's content and enjoy making the perfect team.
I'm bad at it, it's hard and sometimes frustrating - but the gorgeous pixel art and music more than overcome any issues it may have.

Genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Strategy, Free To Play
Reviews:
I've played this game for years on and off and during that time I've gotten quite good at it - having even risen the ranks to the top 25 on the leader board with my brother in a couple seasons.

With the number of hours I'd played I even spent over 100$ supporting the game by buying skins and what not. I enjoyed the flow, the challenge, and the strategy. I know every card. How they're played. How they're countered. 

So why am I giving it a negative review now?  I recently came back to it to find out the game had completely changed. 

Why oh why have the devs decided to remove wild cards (doubles of the same card in the same deck) and duplicate cards (the same card in your teammates deck) in premade team battles?? Half the fun of this game was being able to strategize with a friend and come up with crazy combos, thematic decks, and sometimes just plain goofy ridiculous decks early in the league. I strongly believe the percent chance of drawing a deck defining card or executing your intended combo is a key element of dueling cards in general. Think Magic or Yu Gi Oh. Now a huge part of that fun and build design is just gone.

Effectively, they've changed the game that I originally fell in love with and after over 800 hours I don't think I want to play anymore. What a shame. | Rating: 7/10

Overview: Minion Masters is a fast-paced, free-to-play strategy game that blends elements of tower defense and collectible card games (CCG). Developed by BetaDwarf, the game pits players in 1v1 or 2v2 battles where they summon and control minions to battle against their opponentâ€™s forces, all while managing a deck of cards. With its unique mix of gameplay styles, Minion Masters offers an accessible but strategic experience for fans of both strategy games and card battling.

Gameplay: In Minion Masters, players build and use decks of cards to summon minions, cast spells, and build structures on the battlefield. Each card corresponds to a different type of unit, spell, or structure that players can deploy in real-time. The key to success is not just about deploying powerful units but also about managing your resources (mana), timing your plays, and reacting to your opponentâ€™s strategy.

The game offers several different modes, including standard 1v1 and 2v2, where players can compete against other players or AI. The matches are quick, lasting around 5-10 minutes, which makes it easy to jump into a game and not get bogged down by long sessions. The action is fast-paced, with constant back-and-forth gameplay, making it exciting for those who enjoy real-time strategy with a bit of card game strategy mixed in.

Deck Building and Strategy: The strategic depth of Minion Masters comes from deck building. Players can collect new cards and customize their deck to suit their playstyle, with different minions, spells, and special abilities available to choose from. The key to winning is finding the right balance between offense and defense, while also considering synergy between the cards in your deck. There are a variety of minion types, each with strengths and weaknesses, which adds an extra layer of tactical decision-making to each match.

Progression and Monetization: As with many free-to-play games, Minion Masters includes a progression system where players can unlock new cards and cosmetics by earning rewards from matches or purchasing card packs. While the game is generally balanced and not pay-to-win, there is an option for players to spend money on card packs and other cosmetic items. This could give some players a slight advantage early on, but most progress can still be made through regular gameplay.

Graphics and Performance: Minion Masters features bright, colorful visuals with a somewhat cartoonish art style that fits the fast-paced, playful nature of the game. The minions and spells are well-designed, with each card having its own unique look and animations that help bring the battlefield to life. The game runs smoothly on most systems, and the controls are intuitive, making it accessible for both new players and strategy veterans alike.

Audio Design: The sound design in Minion Masters is solid, with an upbeat soundtrack and engaging sound effects that add to the excitement of the battles. Each card and minion has its own set of sounds, from the footsteps of marching troops to the explosive effects of spells, helping to immerse players in the gameâ€™s action. The voice lines of the minions and the announcer are charming and add some personality to the game.

Challenges: While Minion Masters is accessible, there is a learning curve when it comes to building effective decks and mastering the timing and positioning of your units. As players unlock more cards, they can start building more diverse strategies, but the gameâ€™s fast pace means you need to react quickly, which can be challenging for newcomers. The game also features matchmaking, but occasionally, you may find yourself up against opponents who have stronger cards if you're not progressing quickly enough.

Final Thoughts: Minion Masters is a fun and fast-paced strategy game that offers a unique blend of collectible card gameplay with real-time strategy. Its quick matches, deck-building mechanics, and strategic depth make it an enjoyable experience for players who enjoy both card games and strategy games. While thereâ€™s a progression system that could feel grindy at times, the game remains accessible, and its focus on skill and strategy makes it rewarding for those who stick with it.

Pros:

Fast-paced and accessible gameplay
Strong strategic depth through deck-building and unit placement
Bright, colorful visuals with appealing animations
Free-to-play with fair monetization options
Multiple game modes including 1v1 and 2v2
Cons:

Progression can feel slow at times
Pay-to-progress elements, though not pay-to-win
Some balancing issues, especially at early levels
Can become repetitive if not switching up strategies
Minion Masters is an enjoyable strategy game for those who like quick battles, tactical decision-making, and card collection. While there are some minor progression hurdles, the game offers a solid and fun experience for fans of competitive, strategic gameplay. | This game was fun for a while. I found it late thinking it was a new game. After several months of loving it and playing it almost daily; the fun is now at its end. The story is good, the designs are really beautiful and the ambiant is relaxing. I recommend it!!! ğŸ’› | TL;DR: Enjoyable!

This is a really fun game. The graphics are super cool and unique, the music is immersive but doesn't draw all your attention, and the plot line is engaging with great pacing. The puzzles aren't hard, but they do make you think. And it's got a lot of little silly moments and stories that I loved.
It's not perfect. The dialogue can be a little stilted and sometimes objects clip each other and look funky. But these don't impact the game's functionality, so it didn't even bother me.
The replayability of mystery games usually isn't great, and I'm pleased to say that I'd happily play this one again. The ending is open enough that I'll keep thinking and reinterpreting it. The puzzles aren't so simple that I necessarily remember all the answers to them. And the little stories spaced throughout are fun! 
Overall, a highly engaging game that's visually interesting too. | ĞŸĞµÑ€ÑˆĞ° Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°, ÑĞºÑƒ Ñ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¹ÑˆĞ¾Ğ² Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¡Ñ‚Ñ–Ğ¼Ğ´ĞµÑ†Ñ–, Ñ– Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ° Ğ½ĞµĞ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ½Ğ°. An interesting game with a fascinating story. But there are downsides - these are blind NPCs who don't care what's going on around them, you can at least dance in front of them and then just as easily hide under the bushes (like yo buddy, you can go through, I didn't see anything lol). The game is quite boring and monotonous in places, I literally played for 30 minutes a day, for me this is an alarming sign. The rats in this game are quite stupid, not aggressive, they mainly serve as an obstacle on the road. The atmosphere in the game changes very quickly, a beautiful landscape suddenly turns into a mountain of rotten corpses and it looks creepy. Sometimes there are good dialogues in the game, beautiful landscapes for screenshots, in general, the game with a discount is worth its money. I hope to pass the second part someday, but so far there is no special desire. I give it 7/10 <3 | [h1]ĞœĞ°Ğ½Ñ–Ñ Ğ²ĞµĞ»Ğ¸Ñ‡Ñ– â€“ Ñ†Ğµ Ñ…Ğ²oÑ€Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ°. 9/10 | Just finished the main story. Oh man this game gave me serious heart attacks with rats and the dark atmosphere.
The graphics and characters were amazing. I find the relationship they build in such a short time very charming and inspiring.
Hugo was super adorable but can also be annoying sometimes (when we ran away and causing troubles, reminds me of my little brother irl). The way that Melie talked shit was funny. Rodric was a real cool fighter, spoiler -[spoiler]it was heartbreaking to watch him die.[/spoiler]
Didn't like the puzzles (way too straight forward) and stealth (aiming was hard when guards were in close quarters with a controller).

All the best to the loving siblings.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3420889561
