You can also just trurn off auto attack and run through 12 rounds in about 15min to watch everything. | ä¸€äºŒä¸‰ä»£ä¸­è¿™æ¬¾æœ€å¥½ç©ï¼Œç¬¬ä¸€æ¬¾è¿‡äºç²—ç³™ï¼Œç¬¬ä¸‰æ¬¾è¿‡äºç¹çï¼Œæœ€å¥½çš„å°±æ˜¯ç¬¬äºŒä»£ç©èµ·æ¥é¡ºæ‰‹ã€‚ | Its good for the price (discount), but the H-scene need more improvements | é€ƒè„±é€”ä¸­å®Œå…¨å¿˜äº†è¿™æ˜¯ä¸ªéœ€è¦æ¬£èµæˆ˜è´¥ CG çš„æ¸¸æˆã€‚

it was fun for a bit but updates are slow and no workshop so just get it on sale | This game has a lot of bugs that need to be fleshed out. The targeting/pathing for the allied soldiers is horrendous, especially when they are placed on walls or towers. When you issue a command they will get stuck or not come down from the tower. Alongside this, if you lose during the night there is no fast forward and you have to either sit around and wait for up to 5 mins or longer and wait for the night to end and kill the enemies or you will have to load a previous save. There is no fast forward button so everything is sluggishly show. If your stone quarry gets destroyed and you don't have the stone to rebuild it you have to destroy it and rebuild it otherwise you are soft locked from stone. The repair system inst great. Troops are wayyyy to expensive for the food cost. Food is very sparse even with the materials turned up. Game sound is extremely loud and i found that if i had the sound nearly off is the best to not having it blast my ears. This game has a lot of potential the bugs just need to be fleshed out. For things like troops, siege machines, and traps i believe these should have their own menu so that you don't have to search your whole kingdom to find these buildings just to create these things. Research cost for the most part is pretty solid, if not a hair to expensive, but i wouldn't focus to much on that. Losing vital building can almost be run ending if you start losing residents. It just becomes a downwards spiral that is not fun to fix. Overall I would give this game a 5/10 with potential of being a 8-9/10. Don't get me wrong this game was fun in the time i played it, but would be much better if there was a focus on polishing the game. | Its sad that I'm here but unfortunately I am. This game was really good for about a year or 2 but in the last year that has been no updates at all. Last thing was a news blog from Oct 29,2024 and that blog was an update of a previous blog from Apr 18. I understand this a Ukrainian and German studio so I know there are conflicts with the team being able to work. 

Since the last update (Dec 2023, over a year) they added seasons and I personally think the seasons needs to be toned down. Wither its lightning hitting all of your buildings and catching them on fire, hitting your little amount of units and killing them, or a winter that is brutal and can kill your whole base. Im not against the seasons but I do think they need some tweaking. 

Pathing has been an issue since release. They have worked on it some but it still has a long ways to go, Units get stuck, some get unresponsive and wont move, units will get bunched up and trapped on walls and towers, etc. Enemy units can be just as bad and will sometimes not even move when spawned.

Overall I have enjoyed this game and like many others say it is a fun escape from sweaty shooters for a while but sadly with the very slow updates and current bugs in the game, I cant recommend it. I hope the team hasnt abandoned the game and they can start releasing updates again soon because the potential is huge. | Combat macht kein SpaÃŸ weil das Gameplay schlichtweg verbuggt ist wie z.b. werden befehle gar nicht ausgefÃ¼hrt. | using this box to fill word limit. Game is great and i highly recommend it, also isnt a huge storage hog and for the size it is its comparable to games like rimworld for me in replayability

It's rare but every now and then you find one of those special games that you know will stay with you, and Stray was one of them for me. Man, I don't even know where to start. The game is truly beautiful, I had to keep stopping just to snap screenshots. The story is emotionally beautiful (I might say beautiful a lot but oh well, describes the game perfectly  Â¯\_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯) and it was just an enjoyable and beautiful experience from start to finish. 

No bugs or stutters, played perfectly on a middle of the road PC and you can tell there was so much love and care put into making this game. I'm not usually a fan of stealth but actually had fun with it in Stray when it came to those little stealth sections. This review is all over the place because I'm still emotional after finishing this BEAUTIFUL game.

Tired of looking through the steam library and feeling like there's nothing good to play? Well this game satisfied that feeling for me. Len's Island feels like playing a combination of Runescape/Diablo/The Forest. What a combo right? I never thought i'd find something like that, I also never thought i'd commit 200 hours to it but here I am. So when you're fed up with playing all the usual stuff and want something fresh, this is what you're going to play. It's made by an Australian Dev team too, so if you're Aussie reading this, just send it.

Seriously, great game. Super relaxing, heaps of content, cool mechanics, graphics aren't overly cooked, atmosphere is awesome, music slaps and it's just the right amount of difficulty, try it for yourself I don't need to waffle on anymore. | The TL;DR - Good game. It's a really nice place to visit.

Len's Island is a pretty good game even though it is an Early Access title. Right now in it's current state it is as good if not better than some other games that are considered "complete". At the time of this review I found this game to be well worth the cost for adding it to my game library.

I was sucked into the game and have to admit I became slightly addicted to playing it. Visually it appeals to me and I like the game soundtrack that loops in the background as you play. Len's Island is a world I enjoy living and exploring in. It's a place where it is OK to exercise your imagination.

There is something I feel many prospective players are not aware of and that is the game settings allow for players to make adjustments that have a real impact on their playtime experience.  If you want an easy time and just want to farm, fish and gather resources to build you can do that. If you want to almost punish yourself by making night time and dungeons more dangerous you can do that too. If you haven't watched the Flow Studio mode select video I recommend you do so.

Len's Island isn't perfect and it's not going to hit the same with everyone that plays it. I found several things that I wish had been done to better suit what I prefer but I find things similar in almost every game I play, even those that get pushed out by triple A studios with huge teams and big budgets.

One thing I am concerned about is how user friendly (or unfriendly) Len's Island will be for the aged or disabled gamer that want to play. I use a mouse and keyboard and at times I feet it is a challenge to get Len to do what I want.

Lastly the game ran well on my Win10 PC. The game did stop responding a couple times in my near 150 hour playtime and I had to kill the process and restart. Within a few moments I was back to playing and hadn't lost much thanks to the autosave system. The downside to the autosave is that at times it caused micro-pauses at inopportune times but all in all it was not too bad. | ê¸°ë³¸ì— ì¶©ì‹¤í•œ ìƒë‹¹íˆ ì¬ë¯¸ìˆëŠ” ê²Œì„ì´ë‹¤. íŒŒë°, ì‚¬ëƒ¥, í•˜ìš°ì§•ê³¼ ê°™ì€ ì»¨í…ì¸ ë¥¼ ëª¨ë‘ ì¦ê¸¸ ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤. ë˜í•œ í•œê¸€ íŒ¨ì¹˜ë¥¼ ì¶”ê°€í•´ì¤€ ë°°ë ¤ì— ê°ì‚¬í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ìµœì´ˆ í”Œë ˆì´ í–ˆì„ ë‹¹ì‹œë³´ë‹¤ ë§ì€ ì ì´ ê°œì„ ë˜ì—ˆë‹¤. ë‚œì´ë„ ì¡°ì ˆ, ì›í™œí•œ í”Œë ˆì´ë¥¼ ìœ„í•œ ì¸í„°í˜ì´ìŠ¤ ì •ëˆ, íŠœí† ë¦¬ì–¼, ë™ë£Œë“¤, ì´ì™¸ì—ë„ ë‹¤ì–‘í•œ ìš”ì†Œë“¤ì´ ì¶”ê°€ë˜ì–´ ë§¤ìš° ë§Œì¡±í•œë‹¤. ìš”ì¦˜ì€ ì–´ë–¤ê²ƒì´ ì£¼ì œì¸ì§€ ëª…í™•í•˜ì§€ ì•Šì€ ê²Œì„ë“¤ì´ ë§ì€ë°, ë‹¨ì—° ì¥ì ì´ ë‹ë³´ì´ëŠ” ë”± í•„ìš”í•œ ìš”ì†Œê°€ ëª¨ë‘ ìˆëŠ” ê²Œì„ë‹¤ìš´ ê²Œì„ì´ë‹¤. ë‹¤ë§Œ NPCë“¤ì´ ì¡°ê¸ˆ ë” ì•¡í‹°ë¸Œí•˜ê±°ë‚˜ (ê²Œì„ì„¸ê³„ì— ë” ì• ì°©ì„ ê°€ì§ˆ ìˆ˜ ìˆë„ë¡)ì´ˆë°˜ ëª°ì…ì„ ìœ„í•œ í¬ì¸íŠ¸ ìš”ì†Œê°€ ì¶”ê°€ë˜ë©´ ë”ìš± ì¬ë¯¸ìˆì„ê²ƒê°™ë‹¤. ì´ˆë°˜ ì§„í–‰ì„ ê¼­ í•´ì•¼ë§Œ í•˜ëŠ” ì´ìœ  (ìŠ¤í† ë¦¬ì ì¸ ê°€ì´ë“œ)ë¥¼ ë¶€ì—¬í•˜ë©´, ìŠ¤ìŠ¤ë¡œ í•  ì¼ì„ ì°¾ì„ ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” ëŠ¥ìˆ™í•œ RPG íŒ¬ë“¤ ë§ê³ ë„, ì´ˆë³´ì ì¸ ìœ ì €ë“¤ ë˜í•œ ë”ìš± ì¦ê¸¸ ìˆ˜ ìˆì„ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. | nice little indi game

currently about 20h contend to do almost everything
pro:
- simple and relaxing
- nice looks 
- fun to play

con:
- lack of end game contend
- islands a bit small for bigger base builds

technical stuff
- game seems not to be made for bigger base building when reaching a 3 floor i had issues with some stairs clipping to other floors also mobs spawn on it 
- sometimes in the underground you see bridges which you can build to get to the other side but sometimes this gaps can be bypassed by jumping closeby but again sometimes these points where you can cross by jumping are 1 sided so without mats you could get stuck foreever inside a cave its low odds for this to happen but possible and low odds x playercount is it may happens to some unlucky soul at somepoint and the game does auto save so... 
- when you die inside a dungeon you get asked to respawn at the entrance but you spawn outside of the entrance and not inside the dungeon which more then doubles the loading time while it doesnt need to:
first it needs to unload the dungeon
then it needs to load the outside world
and then you walk inside the dungeon again which makes you unload the outside and load the dungeon again while all that would need to be done is reset the dungeon which can be anoying when you play on a hdd | A great game that needs just a little more content to be amazing. 
It's one of those games that starts small and cute, and bit by bit you expand your world in a way that doesn't feel rushed or confusing. It doesn't frustrate you with complex crafting or assault you with tons of useless recipes or ingredients.

The downsides are:
1. the map is large, but it consists mostly of boring, empty ocean. The islands are too small and too few. 
2. the pet companions are pretty useless. Most of them collect raws from the field, but they don't do this reliably, so I end up still collecting my own materials. The other type of pet is supposed to help in combat, but once again they seem to mostly stare off into the distance instead of helping. 
3. building is fun and rewarding, but very quickly causes the game to stutter.

The upsides:
1. plenty to do
2. good building
3. easy to understand
4. game settings can be customised to make the experience suited to your needs/likes
5. developers are active and have already improved the game considerably since early access launched

First of all. the story feels like it's on rails for a good 90% of it -- that is, it doesn't *feel* like any of your choices matter, and according to the list of endings, only the last two choices affect the ending in a significant way.

I also found the story really uninspired, and the "where is this all headed" was pretty obvious from act 1.

It has a game breaking bug at chapter 2. I found this 21 HOURS IN! I pulled a lever before turning a furnace on first, and this caused my game to not give me the item the lever should have given. Now I am stuck, because I can't pull the level again. And there is no patch for 8 months, so I have given up waiting for a patch. The game is kinda nice, cryptic as all hell. I think it's cryptic as the original Hexen. But a game breaking bug like this just makes me want to quit. | This is a somewhat cautious recommended. Whilst it can be fun and more engaging than the glut of simplistic but oh so flashy indie shooters that seem to be the norm these days, it is a flawed product that can be irritating in places.

Graven is a first-person mixture of melee and ranged combat, with exploration, platforming and some mild puzzle elements.  Generally all of those things are done reasonably well, though it tends to stumble in enough little ways that it lessens the experience.

Your weapons can be enjoyable, particularly when the effects are explosive, but you tend to find there isn't much difference between them. I have four weapons that are all essentially the same: something that looks like a crossbow and can be upgraded to fire explosives, an actual crossbow that...fires explosives, and...uh..a different crossbow that fires...um...explosives. Then a final non-crossbow that fires....*can you guess what?* explosives.

The same can said for a melee staff versus using a sword (though that does let you block projectiles, to be fair), or using a flail. Nothing really differentiates them when it comes to bashing a monsters face in, so even though its fun bashing a monsters face in there is still the disappointment that every "new" weapon is rarely exciting to obtain.

And whoever designed this in a way that you have to wait as animations finish when switching weapons and items needs some sense knocking into them. As it can be annoyingly slow changing between them, and even better yet there isn't a weapons wheel when using a controller, so the whole thing is sluggish and fiddly.

Most of the time it isn't too bad, but when the action gets hectic it feels like a poor choice to have made. Which is a shame, as it's quite visceral and enjoyable upto a point. Boss-battles are simplistic sh*te, though there's only three of them, and in all fairness, I can't recall the last game of this type (be it a boomer shooter, or fantasy combat like this) that wasn't utterly crap in this regard.

Its not exactly an endorsement of this title that everyone else produces dog-sh*t when it comes to these supposedly "thrilling" encounters, but as I said: there's not that many of them, so I'll let it slide.  

Exploration is nice, as this isn't a linear title and it has pleasant secrets hidden about, or "cute" progression  compared to something where its just switch-hunting or finding keys. Like, you know, the bazillions of  simplistic boomer shooters that don't even have those two activities, never-mind anything even vaguely more sophisticated.

But then it doesn't give you a map, and any time you save out of an area you don't restart at the same place. Instead you go back to a hub area and have to make your way back. The game isn't exactly short, but the 30 hours I've clocked up so far is a lot of back-tracking, either because I missed something obscure, or because of quitting before a level was finished.

So far this sounds like I have more issues with it than positives, and it's true that you need patience to "enjoy" this, but it is still fun....mostly. Perhaps I'm just sick of dumb shooty-shooty-bang-bang, of which a blind person throwing a dart at titles on steam could hit, I dunno, a thousand of the same mind-numbingly dull DOOM Eternal wannabes with PS1 era graphics (thumbs down: not enough polygonal warbling or pop-in, and it has hi-res textures...disgusting in this day and age!!)

Something about Graven, despite its many issues, makes it more appealing than those kinds of games, but it is just "okay" and should have been better. This isn't Dishonored, Thief or Dark messiah of might and magic, but then again - what is these days? I'd really like to know of any title that comes even vaguely close to those games, because beyond the likes of them conventional shooters just bore me to tears.

This game will probably bore you to tears, or frustrate you, but it may not. I just appreciate that it has somewhat more depth than most, and there's slim pickings to be had in the genre so it will have to suffice. Maybe Avowed won't be too bad and will have fewer rough edges, but I won't hold my breath based on what I've seen of it so far (the game-play could be great, but the graphics are yucky, which is awkward..because they aren't even deliberately making it look crap and outdated)

In the meantime I wouldn't recommend this over Amid Evil (which is better than this in most ways, although the bosses are rubbish there too), or Hands of necromancy (great combat and exploration, but insipid woeful boss-battles...what a shock....),  but I did find it more appealing than the likes of Elderborn.

PS: The reviews mentioning soft-locks may have been correct at the time of release, but it was very stable for me so I think that has been fixed. The level design can make it SEEM like it has screwed you over, and I thought that a couple of times, but in the end they always do provide a means for alternate access.

You maybe get to an area by pulling a switch that activates a lift, and then that lever stops working. "The game is broke" you think, but no! The lever only stops working when you have completed that bit, and some other exit has opened up. It would be easy to say its bust, and maybe it was before, but now its just on you as the player for not figuring it out.

I'm in the last area of the game (act 3), so unless there is a massive f**k-up at the end - it's working fine when people are saying they couldn't get past act 1! | Broken game. With my first profile I got locked on act 1 library dungeon lift bug on 6th hour into the game. I liked the game enough to restart with a 2nd profile. I got locked again on act 2 boss not spawning on 24th hour. Game doesn't allow multiple saves so you can go back to a save that was before triggering a game breaking bug and retry. Don't buy it, don't invest your time on it. | [h1][b]Just treat Graven like a GF with psych issues and you may end up enjoying some of your time together.[/b][/h1]

I enjoy the concept this game tries to bring to life.  A retro immersive sim set in a gothic/medieval realm.  The atmosphere, sound effects and score as well as the movement animations and fluidity stand out among Graven's many triumphs.  Imagine what a remake of Hexen on the PS1 could play like and you might have some idea what to expect from this game.  Unfortunately, the downsides you will likely come across are SIGNIFICANT to say the least.  DO NOT BUY FOR ANYTHING LESS THAN A STEEP DISCOUNT.

The opening cutscene stuttered like a slideshow the entire time and made me wonder if DX12 shader caching could be even more poorly optimized than in many modern games or if there is some sort of compatibility issue at play.  In-game Graven runs smoothly on modern hardware but the game's "quirks" are not limited in scope.

Saves are limited to checkpoints unless you wish to dabble in the dark arts of Teh Haxxor trainers.  Getting to a checkpoint and using the save and quit feature will still end up loading you back in town although your progress seems to be saved more or less (notes found, items/gold collected, etc).  Sometimes you will reload your save and find you have no blue mana until you move around or enter the menus and return to game.  Sometimes your mana count may not match the one you had prior to your last checkpoint, save and quit.  Bugs such as the ol' "Completely Evaporating Inventory"â„¢ lies in wait so buyer beware.  Also, you lose your inventory on death and retrieving all of it may be a hit or miss endeavor.

I have yet to track Graven's wacky occurrences against a lunar calendar for signs of manic schizophrenia but I would not be surprised to find signs of the devil in it's tea leaves.

I can't strongly recommend to anyone unwilling to cope with its many issues but sometimes you just want to indulge a fantasy that the industry has largely abandoned.  Keep that trainer handy to replace what you may lose as best you are able and consider running a casual playthrough to limit frustration if you are willing to risk playing Graven. | Nice game, I like the style. Though it has some bugs and some players have a hard time with it, the game has room to grow. I hope the devs will work on fixing and improving this game. 7 out of 10

I enjoyed the actual game itself and the gameplay but I can't recommend the game currently based off of the lack of support and communication from the devs.  They still have multiplayer listed as a core feature of the game even though it has yet to be implemented.  It still shows on the roadmap that the FIRST update was going to be multiplayer.  There is still no multiplayer nor mention of when its coming.  There's also only a small amount of content in the game right now as the devs promise to add more chapters in future updates.  After 4 or 5 months of no communication, they finally announce that the Breach update (the story and map update that was supposed to come out AFTER multiplayer) will be SHOWN on March 11.  Not released, mind you, just shown in a showcase.  This is pretty unacceptable for the price that they charge and for the expectations they set at the games EA launch. At first the fact that every action can be done with only one key, (space) looks like a great approach, but given that -everything- is perfomed by that, very often unvanted actions occur/trigger, which is very annoying.
You should forget about this and use a proper key assignment layout like other decent games.

Also the item handling, splitting, etc. is very different from the already widely established scheme based on common sense.
On its own it would not be an issue. If it would work fine. But it is messy and don't have much logic.

In the mazes, the camera movement is quite unfortunate as the snapping or stationary camera is not a good idea when all of the other parts of the game use a camera fixed on the player.
As the camera stops on the border of rooms and only snaps to the next room when the player enters, it cannot be seen exactly what is on the other side of the door, even when open. So a situation when a player enters another room in the face of an enemy without seeing it, can happen and get attacked.
Which is silly.

Quite often we had desyncs and players dropped, which is also very annoying.
The last drop was when in a maze all of our progress got lost due to a disconnection/desync error.

Due to these and if a game produces this many bugs and is this unstable, then at least a usual rotating autosave feature would be nice, so users would have a way to restore the lost content and time.

I guess no devs will read this or will not give a damn anyway, but if you want to improve your game, then here you go.

A phenomenal puzzle game with a technically impressive and visually stunning main mechanic let down by an absolutely awful story. [u] I genuinely recommend playing with voice acting volume set to zero and subtitles off, you will be playing a better game. [/u]

The characters are uninteresting and voice acted poorly, but most importantly they don't give any of the game's stellar moments time to breathe. Whenever something cool happens, you have someone chiming in remarking on how cool it is before you have a moment to go "Damn, that was really cool!". To me, robbing the player of the agency to react to spectacle is a game design sin, and it really held me back from fully absorbing the game's best moments.

The story is also actively painful. The message it's trying to send is ham-fisted, and the world is absent any internal logic. [spoiler] The entire game takes place in a VR simulation, yet it seems people lived here, even ate here. People are conducting research here, but who on earth builds a machine in VR to prove it'll work in real life? It ends with you leaving the simulation with a physical object, which makes zero sense. [/spoiler] Trying to make sense of these paradoxes simply raises more questions, and I never found them resolving in a satisfying way.

Don't let all this negativity distract you from how good this game is, though. It is absolutely worth playing. But I do genuinely recommend turning of voice acting and subtitles - it'll turn the story from generic and eyerolling to mysterious and intriguing. | åŠ‡æƒ…è·Ÿç’°å¢ƒä¿è­·æœ‰é—œ é—œå¡éƒ½ä¸æœƒå¤ªé›£ è¦–è¦ºæ•ˆæœèˆ‡é‚è¼¯ä¹Ÿéƒ½åšå¾—å¾ˆå¥½ ç¾ä¸­ä¸è¶³å°±æ˜¯ç©åˆ°å„é—œå¡æœ‰è¶£çš„éƒ¨åˆ†æ™‚é‚£æ•´é—œä¹Ÿå°±å·®ä¸å¤šçµæŸäº† ä½†æ•´é«”é‚„æ˜¯å¾ˆä¸éŒ¯ å¾ˆå€¼å¾—é«”é©—ã€‚ | [h2]Gameplay[/h2]
Viewfinder has amazing and creative puzzle mechanics. New mechanics are introduced over time and it doesn't overstay its welcome. If you're a completionist or want a bit of exploration, take note there are some pictures you could explore and objects (not part of the puzzle) you could interact. For the most part, the puzzles are easy while a few others are either mildly challenging or require some unconventional approach.

It's worth to note this game also has lots of accessibility features. I never use either, but you could get hints and disable the timer on timed puzzles. Besides that, there are also features for subtitle and text size which are helpful since I use a monitor with big resolution.

[h2]Visual & Audio[/h2]
It goes without saying the visual looks great and clean. The animation/transition when interacting with the puzzle feels smooth and satisfying. Both SFX and BGM are just good enough to do their intended job, although voice acting doesn't help the poor story.

[h2]Story[/h2]
The story is simply bad, in the sense that I don't care about the story and characters. I barely sense any build-up or suspense & most of the characters feel one-dimensional. The problem isn't the story-telling approach (which combines exploration, hearing past conversations and reading notes/articles) either, when other games (such as Deliver Us The Moon) can deliver a good story while using similar approach.

[hr][/hr]
Viewfinder is an amazing puzzle game. But considering the bad story and gameplay duration, you probably want to wait for a discount. | Everything that the dialogue and voice acting achieve would be better achieved by their absence. | Ğ’ĞµĞ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ¾Ğ»ĞµĞ¿Ğ½Ğ°Ñ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°, Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ Ñ‡ĞµĞ¼ ÑĞ¾ Ğ²ÑĞµÑ… ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ½. The last section of the game feels a bit unpolished and anticlimactic. So don't expect there too much. I think the first third of the game was the most fun and afterwards it was still a pretty good game.

Recommend if you like:
- Decisions
- Skill Trees
- Tactical RPGs
- Dark Humor

Most annoying for me was the balancing of weapons. Some are good in early game but weak in late game and vice versa. So you really should spread out your options. | I haven't played the other Wastelands... but after getting back into tactical RPGs like Rogue Trader (loved it) and Baldur's Gate 3 (Awesome return to D&D), Wasteland 3 (mostly) satisfies that nostalgic Old School Fallout vibe/feel/itch. The tactical gameplay is fun and somewhat varied but some of the systems could have been polished and fleshed out more. Also the the variety of encounters could have been a little better since there was not much need for reevaluating strategies once you found one that worked. Also, initially I didn't understand how some of the attributes and skills actually affected gameplay and leveling. Figured it out but the game doesn't do a great job explaining everything. Some of the world and story could have been more open ended (though you can wander ish). Overall it was great though, with some interesting characters and a story that's serviceable enough to keep you mad maxxing across Colorado. An easy "yes" to purchase on sale. | A Masterpiece of Tactical RPG Storytelling

Wasteland 3 is an absolute triumph for fans of tactical RPGs and post-apocalyptic storytelling. From the moment you step into the frozen wastelands of Colorado, youâ€™re drawn into an immersive world filled with tough moral choices, deeply layered characters, and unforgettable encounters.

Gameplay
The combat in Wasteland 3 is a standout feature, blending classic turn-based strategy with modern mechanics. Every decision matters, from positioning your squad to selecting the right mix of abilities and gear. The battles are challenging but rewarding, encouraging creative strategies and clever use of your environment.

Storytelling
The narrative is where Wasteland 3 truly shines. The writing is sharp, witty, and emotionally engaging, with decisions that genuinely impact the world around you. Whether youâ€™re negotiating with strange cults, deciding the fate of a desperate town, or dealing with the consequences of your alliances, the game keeps you constantly invested in its branching storyline.

Atmosphere and World-Building
The frozen post-apocalypse of Colorado is beautifully crafted, with stunning environments and a hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack. Every location feels unique and packed with details that add depth to the world. The quirky characters and dark humor are perfectly balanced with the serious tones of survival and sacrifice.

Customizability
From building your squad to upgrading your base, Wasteland 3 offers a wealth of customization options. You can tailor your team to suit your playstyle, making every playthrough feel unique.

Co-Op
For those looking to share the experience, the co-op mode is a fantastic addition, allowing you to strategize and make tough decisions with a friend.

Conclusion
Wasteland 3 is a must-play for RPG enthusiasts and anyone who loves a game that challenges your mind and tugs at your emotions. InXile Entertainment has delivered a masterpiece that respects the legacy of the Wasteland series while modernizing it for a new generation of gamers. If you're ready for a journey filled with tough choices, tactical depth, and a world that feels alive, Wasteland 3 is the game for you.

I started a game and I was hooked. It was soooo difficult to keep going with Germany for instance, but came so close to maintaining office a few first times, that I knew I could do better. It's a massive puzzle game with a very simple interface that makes it easy to absorb the information and navigate the myriad of implications of your decisions. I'm still learning about the game, and wonder what the replayabillity is like once I figure out the massive puzzle, but so far it's very engaging and rewarding when I manage to continue as President in office. | Great game for people like me, who are chronically addicted to politics (it's not healthy). The game is definitely an improvement over Democracy 3. The UI, mod support and policy balance is improved. But the same old problem remains any politics addict with a strong ideological alingment. The game as a lib-left bend (although not as pronounced as in Democracy 4). Depending on your personal view, this might be a good or a bad thing. The game is harder with a free-market approach, although this can be balanced through mods. The game offers a lot of different countries to play in, but has a very american perspective on policy. 

I find myself resorting to my preferred political playstyle of free-market capitalism, but you can go ahead and experiment. I highly recommend this game. | Too expensive for what it is and a lot of the cause & effect makes very little sense - Why are the only contributing factors to environmental protests the state of the environment and how many environmentalists there are? Surely if Environmentalists are happy with my government they would be significantly less inclined to protest it? - meaning otherwise seemingly pointless policies need to be put in place like tear gas, water cannons, etc. that tank approval for literally no reason.

There's also too few positive situations and/or goals to achieve, which wouldn't be a huge deal if not for the fact that this being a simulation of democracy means there's no real endgame, it means a lot of the time unless you have something in mind to work towards there's not much impetus to play for very long at a time, no carrot on the end of the proverbial stick to keep encouraging you to work towards achieving it.

Worth a play if you see it at a significant discount during a sale, otherwise I would give it a miss. | I personally have had a lot of fun on this game! I like all the laws and such you can change. | This is a fun Game for those who like strategy, slow pace, and who like to govern. You can change policies to try winning an election or just to see what will happen if you start chipping people and freedom is taken. so many options. I enjoy it because I have 4 kids and 3 Dogs and a wife and a job so I can get up and walk away no pause needed. Per turn game.

The game has a lot of potential, however it is very strange that it has such a limited inventory management system. For a survival game, carfting a lot of things are essential, that means various type of materials need to be collected but in this game this is not possible cause of the very limited storage which becomes very fruastrating. 

Why the devs decided that this limitation is the way to go is beyond me, this game could have been very enjoyable had it not have the super limited inventory.

The sailing mechanic is very nice, the combat is needs some work but the real deal breaker is the inventory space.

Unfortunately I cannot recommend this game at this stage. | A game about sailing.

Windbound was not a perfect game by my expectations. However, was is still a very much enjoyable experience.
I could not shake the feeling of a missed potential in some parts though. Like there could be more
of the underwater world to explore. Then, it didn't feel like a much-needed content because
the game worked without such innovations.

I deem Windbound a well-designed but imperfectly produced game.

It taught me patience.

First, I played the Survivalist difficulty level. I'm no hardcore gaming enthusiast but I believe the Storyteller
difficulty wouldn't keep me as engaged in the narrative. Just like in Dark Souls there is a feeling of catharsis
after losing progress, same feeling applies here. Coming back all the way to chapter 1 while retaining
the knowledge of the previous iteration didn't spoil the experience. The maps of each chapter were procedurally
generated. An example of that just mentioned were the so called "bonus shrines" which you could interact with
and they granted bonuses. It was always a game of chance whether this time you would get extra health or stamina.
However, the problem of losing most of the progress (except for the "held" inventory items) slowed the pace
of the game significantly.

Immersive adaptive music.

Second, whether it be a change of weather from clear to stormy during sailing or an enemy attack
the sudden changes of ambience played a crucial role in immersion. The sound design was well
done where audio helped identify comfort from danger. Most prominently, each creature encountered
had its own specific track attached to it. It played whenever the creature was idly wandering around.
Namely, there were boars appearing from chapter 1 whose specific track was a nylon guitar.
It added to the feeling you could have a hunter's intuition as if being able to track and observe
patterns that led you to your prey.

The great physics bug.

On the other note, the game appeared to be rough around the edges because of the minor bugs
I experienced on my way through the story. Sometimes I would get stuck in the environment
during a fight and had to roll off away, then I would get struck with a debuff only to restart
the game and cleanse the effect. There were problems in the game that affected the way
I played, something like I had to accommodate, adapt my playstyle using some bugs to counter
other bugs. I also found one particular I'd call a major one that shouldn't be there.
It was when one of the creatures of the islands landed a hit on me and I was sent flying
like a superman. I landed in water outside the island and almost had the character lose
consciousness from swimming back.

To conclude, despite the ups and the downs I recommend playing the game. It was an interesting
blend of sailing mechanics, action-survival gameplay and an interesting story in itself.
The main metaphor I could make out of the story was that no problem can be solved if there
is no established dialog between people.
One more thing to note is that Windbound can also be interpreted as an essay on loneliness.
Everyone sails their own boat. We just do happen to sometimes reach the same island (a concept
of belonging). We also just so happen to part out ways later. Singleplayer experience is purposeful
here in reaching this feeling of solitude on everyone's personal journey. As if encircled by
a storm in a closed space with just your own thoughts... | A very fun and beautiful game | Seria um jogo bom, se a mecÃ¢nica de luta dele nÃ£o fosse uma merda!!!

Needs a more fleshed out character creator and magic added before I'd recommend buying. | ĞŸĞ¾Ñ‚ĞµĞ½Ñ†Ğ¸Ğ°Ğ» Ğ¸Ğ¼ĞµĞµÑ‚ÑÑ, ÑƒĞ¶Ğµ ĞºĞ¾Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµĞ½Ñ‚Ğ° Ğ½ĞµĞ¿Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ…Ğ¾Ğµ ĞºĞ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ‡ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ¾. Ğ Ğ¾Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¿ Ğ´ĞµĞ¹ÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ‚ĞµĞ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾ Ğ²Ğ¿ĞµÑ‡Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ»ÑĞµÑ‚, Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼Ñƒ Ğ¶Ğ´Ñ‘Ğ¼ | Good on the developer for listening to the playerbase.  As for the game, it reminds me of Stoneshard in many respects, including dying in the first 10 minutes of Prologue.  Worth a replay.

I can expound a bit on my first impressions about the game, in the context of the Hunter class. ğŸ¹ These are just my opinions.

Every build of a Hunter needs Athletics or there just isn't survivability, for me.  Again, just my opinion.  I am amused that Steam doesn't know what "survivability" is. ğŸ˜€

The character background should be presented to the player after the inventory is known, I think.  A Hunter's background talks about a bow, but he could start with a crossbow.  Sleeping on a crossbow is very uncomfortable, even in a forest. ğŸ˜„

Reroll should also cycle between the weapon types, instead of being random.  I rerolled one character build a total of nine times to get a bow.  That's not really worth recording on video except as a joke.

Finally out of the Prologue after six failed Hunter builds, I reflected on the progress thus far, trying my best not to chuckle.  The Hunter's starting mastery with a bow is indeed very low.  That's fine, but the background needs rewriting to accommodate.  Constructively, I could suggest a background like,

"Your father taught you how to use a <weapon> at a young age, and though you liked it, you weren't catching on quickly enough, so were eventually reassigned to <insert skill choice> and to practice a bit of <other skill>, during your time at the village.  Mostly, you cared for the village cats and disposed of the vermin they caught.  More recently, you found by the roadside another <weapon>.  It's not that great for quality, but picking it up, feeling its weight, <aiming down the bolt shaft/testing the bowstring>, that old instinct is definitely coming back to you." ğŸ¤” Probably too long---I'm always so long-winded with my thoughts! ğŸ¤£

This might better fit the bonuses the Hunter gets, with the mastery or lack there of, he actually has, without needing to make the player more capable of handling those 1-kilo iguanas and rattus critters. ğŸ€

My record so far for number of arrows pulled from a single iguana is 11.  Arrows act like tracer bullets, if you've ever fired multiple arrows at a single target in real life, where the more arrows you fire, the more you're able to correct the next shot's path.  Progressively decreasing the chance for a miss with more shots, would be part of that bow instinct.  Now, a crossbow, this can be a bit different since you may be putting your back into reloading it.  A lighter crossbow which can be rearmed with, well, the arms might see you training your eye on the target, each shot getting better but a serious crossbow is going to feature you using the stirrup with your foot, completely losing the target in the process of rearming it.

I was excited for the variety in arrows, although I actually saw no arrows for sale in the two towns I visited.  I didn't get far toward finding more towns before "Exhausted!" occurred.  This left my Hunter inexcusably naked with no arrows in an arrowless zone, getting teleported a wearisomely long distance away.  It was at this point that a Debug command to load one of the archer kits was considered, for the sake of sanity.

I did also level up the appropriate Masteries, and I used Cheat Engine ğŸ™„ to get every ability for Ranged and Archery---because level 27 for a weapon mastery is not necessarily enough to get all of its abilities.  I did this because they all would very neatly fit on the Neverwinter Nights sized toolbar, including Jump from Athletics.  Call it OCD, or whatever you like. ğŸ¤ª

Actually, NWN had 12 slots per toolbar, not the 10 we see in Doors of Trithius.  Either way, thanks to Debug Mode, things are much better and the game is playable, enjoyable, and makes me smile. ğŸ˜‰ My Hunter could even hit a rattus and one of those adorable sleeping snakes. ğŸ  I've not seen cuter serpent coils in a game.

As a final note, of course you see the thumbs up.  Doors of Trithius scratches vigorously that traditional roguelike itch.  I'm likely to cycle between it and Stoneshard, for awhile. ğŸ˜

Game Name: The Dark Side of the Moon: An Interactive FMV Thriller
Reviews:
Bonne surprise !
Un petit cotÃ© nanar sympathique mais accrochant ! 
Avec des possibilitÃ©s, des choix et des consÃ©quences diffÃ©rentes. Y compris la fin du jeu.
J'ai passÃ©e un bon moment dessus.
Pas de regrets.

I will start by saying, I love this game.
It's incredibly fun and immersive and hasn't gotten dull or boring after putting 70 hours into it the past few weeks.

The reason I can't recommend it is due to some pretty severe bugs that my friend and I have encountered.

Co-op is the reason I play the game, I wouldn't play it solo, its probably still fun solo, I just prefer playing with friends.
I am not sure if these game-breaking bugs are present in single player and I'm not keen on finding out.

There are some minor bugs here and there, NPCs roaming the map are invisible, the death animation for the two handed mace is backwards. These things I can look past.

The problem becomes when my friend and I spend over an hour clearing out a bandit camp and when we finally finish the fight, we get a black screen with no way to get out of it besides closing the game completely. This is a problem because then we have to go back to a previous save, which can sometimes be right outside the camp, within the battle, or sometimes we lose hours of progress. We have to be religious about saving the game because we have encountered this bug numerous times.

I can even look past this happening in bandit camps, because those are not necessary to the story. We can just skip them if the bug happens over and over. However, what I can't look past is when it happens in a story mission. My friend and I basically had to skip a whole region entirely because we were soft locked on a specific story mission in that area. We can't progress in the region without completing it, and no matter what we did, every time we fought the battle, it resulted in a black screen for both of us. After hours of trying to fix it we eventually cut our losses and moved to the next region. 

I am not sure if many other people experience this bug, I haven't seen much chatter about it online. But for me, It really takes the wind out of our sails after spending hours on a really tough fight, only for none of it to matter and have to go to an earlier save to attempt it again. All the while wondering if it will even work the next time.

I will change my review to recommended after this bug gets resolved, but until then I have to not recommend it, even though the game is great :(. |

Genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
Reviews:
Stay away from this game, Go join a game that doesn't try to dumps your wallet well over fifty dollars every month for misc items then just a Subscription.
-This game has an OK community
-The issue is the Devs, trying to dump hundreds of outfits to whales to sale to a very inflated market
-The Devs have also backstabbed several times the community
-Making a Gunslinger after stating they would NOT make a gun class(Nice)
-If you want to play this game, DO NOT SPEND MONEY.
-The community is mostly dying as less and less people fight world bosses on NA, it use to be an all server wide thing but now only a hand full. | DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME.

Developers are completely out of touch, servers as unstable as the Somalian economy. They make promises they never keep or if they keep them its years after they said they would do it. Really wish I could recommend it but I can't. | As fun as the gameplay is, that's like literally the only compliment i can give it outside of the game looking beautiful, it's a sadistic grindfest that is so unbelievably overwhelming for any player, i have 200 hours and i still have zero clue what im doing because i am being constantly bombarded with new items and systems that by the time i get a grasp on one thing, i have to learn 5 more new things. | I didn't really doing anything in the first 6 hours and ended up with a full inventory of stuff... just stuff. The combat early on seems pointless as you can be surrounded by 20 mobs and take no damage. The graphics in the game are quirky with a ton of lighting issues making the game look awful most of the time. The user interface is horrid with overlays overlaying other overlays upon more overlays... it's a mess visually. Why would I want to get notified of other players failing crafting when I am just starting the game? It's a UX/UI designers nightmare. Early story and quests are meh. If I were to summarize my new experience, I wouldn't say it was "bad", I would say it's "a turn off". | Black Desert Online has one of the best early and mid-game experiences. Progress feels rewarding, the world is vast and fun to explore, and there's a real sense of discovery. However, the late game is a completely different story.

Once you hit the late-game grind, progression slows down dramatically, taking anywhere from 20 to 100 hours just to see any improvement. Season characters are a great addition, but they also remove the early game entirely by handing out free PEN gear, which can feel like skipping one of the best parts of the game.

The biggest issue is how demanding the late game is, both in time and money. The game leans heavily into pay-to-win mechanicsâ€”you can buy Crons, making enhancement much less painful for those willing to spend money. While Black Desert has an incredible combat system and PvP is amazing, there's just not enough meaningful PvP content in the open world.

Overall, Black Desert isnâ€™t a terrible game, but the late-game grind and monetization model make it hard to recommend unless you're ready to sink an absurd amount of time (or money) into it.

es bueno un historia god y las deciones son muy buenas | While I get the moral of this game, the degree of which the game pushes against you for the choices you make can be infuriating at times. 

The game itself is a big guilt trip where you're targeted for every single choice that you make, regardless of what it is. While this has meaning behind it, there are many touches and details throughout the game that can bury that meaning under frustration. There were some points that made me feel insulted rather than stop and think like it wants you to:

- Any case where the narrator berated me for one decision, then berated me for the other after I switched choices.
- The dog, which would have been tolerable to bring up a few more times, if it weren't for the joke that the devs "saved the dog" and the achievement for saving the dog by simply leaving the question. (I get the best way to win the game is to not play, but come on).
- You have hardly any effect towards the story at all, yet the game wants to pretend that you do.

The whole game feels like this "fuck you for playing" that isn't my, nor many people's, cup of tea at all. It was meaningful, and I got the message, but I don't think it was worth it. | Delivers on the concept. Short but interesting. | Even if you've seen other people play this game, you are not prepared enough for the things thrown at you. | I got the game on sale for $2.19 USD and it STILL was not worth it.

I love the game but please be aware that at the time of this review, the game developers have essentially moved to just bug fixes and no new content. I'm not sure if it'll change back at some point. 
If you'd like to play a management sim based around blacksmithing then this is a really good game for it, but don't expect there to be more that what's in the game at the moment. | Anvil Saga is not a perfect game, and although I have quite a few issues with it, ultimately I believe (hesitantly) it is a game worth the play through if you want a cozy game about running your own smithy with light local politics. 

What I enjoyed:
Overall, I thought the story was enjoyable. It was fun to see the tug of war of the rival factions as they vied for control over the Province. I enjoyed the angle of having this rival who has the same love as you but also acts as a "boss" at the end of every act or chapter that you have to face off against. I felt that the Fair that occurred at the end of the Chapter really pushes you to focus on what roles you want your apprentices to fill, what equipment to use, what books to read, etc. You feel like you really need to adequately prepare for each competition even if you are going in semi-blind between the 3. I also enjoyed the diverging paths in the story where depending on where your current relationship with each faction in-game really pushed the narrative of the story, and the scenery in your village would reflect that as well. It felt like I was leaving some impact on the world to a degree. I also thought the hire system was kinda fun as well as the cameos that occurred throughout the story. Finally, I thought the game play loop was satisfactory. It was fun and kept me entertained for my 18 hour play through (might be quicker on easier difficulties). 

Neutral Thought(s):
Mostly, I thought the game was just a tad too easy. I played it on the hardest difficulty possible, and although it had a learning curve in the beginning with all of the different factions and how they worked when they stood in queue for your shop, once you understood this it was fairly easy to pick up. Once you picked up the game play loop and what needed to be done to your shop, it was just a matter of doing it all. Managing the relationships with the different factions was also fairly simple, and overall once you got in the "groove" of things, the game wasn't very difficult. That said, I know this is a cozier game, and can be picked up by just about anybody, so I'm not going to outright hold that against Anvil Saga, but I felt it was at the very least worth mentioning.

What I didn't care for:
I hope I don't contradict myself too hard. I really did enjoy the game or else I wouldn't have completed it, and even though I liked a particular aspect of the game throughout it's majority, I felt by act three that even it's best qualities were getting old. So, by that, I mean the game overstayed it's welcome a bit (for me at least). By act/chapter 3, I essentially had my forge fully upgraded, and my house expanded completely. Every room was fully upgraded, everyone had the best equipment for their role, I had a full staff of apprentices, I was at 100% or near 100% with nearly every single faction, and I also had my father's house fixed with someone in it (the guy who gets logs, I cannot remember his job atm and I'm too lazy to google it). With that well oiled of a machine, the game play loop got stale pretty fast, and it was already nearing that by the end of the second act. I know that the game does have story and environmental elements that help keep things fresh, but I found myself not really affected too harshly at that point in the game by negative environmental/societal forces. I also felt that aspects of the game were also forgettable at that point (see comment about "log man" above). When you've gotten along with the bandits or the witches for so long that you haven't paid your employees or taxes properly for a good 2/3 of the game, it made choosing who lived in your parent's old house significantly easier, and even then, once I chose the job of the person who lived there, I kinda forgot about that particular aspect as well. I said earlier that I liked the hire/fire element to the game, but I never really used the firing aspect. Everyone I hired I kept on. Why? Because they've been doing their job for days, why would I fire them -- especially when they essentially work for free due to the witches/bandits -- when the skill they have now is higher than anyone else on the perspective job market? It really didn't seem necessary to me at least. On the topic of paying employees, I kinda wonder what the point of payment is at all? Like, why do we pay them? Of course, it's because they are learning from us as the smith and we need to be provided a wage or else they will get upset and leave, but like there isn't much more to the game play than just "pay them or they will leave". It's not like the employees themselves used the wage I paid them for anything. They live, work, and eat under the same roof and never leave the shop unless I send them on a quest with one of the cameo characters. They really don't do anything with the money outside of affecting their overall mood and work ethic (I guess that answers the question I just posed, but hear me out). I think, personally, that it would have been a much more fun mechanic to have them work on "shifts". Maybe they still stay at the house, etc, but additionally, they might go out in the village to spend their paycheck and have a percentage chance of something happening to them:
      - it can be a good thing such as a new business venture or cameo character
      - it can be a bad thing like they get into a fight at the local tavern and now Arthur/We are faced with a dilemma of either 
         firing our apprentice and saving face with the faction that they got into an altercation with at the expense of 
         potentially upsetting other apprentices, or defending our apprentice at the cost of paying a fine and/or losing 
         reputation points with upset/offended faction
I think something like what I have above at least gives a more interesting way to interact with the village whilst also giving another in-game reason to why we pay the apprentices versus what is currently implemented in the game. I feel like the game play loop does feel mobile game-esque in regard to some other comments made in other reviews here, and although that didn't bother me too much; it did hurt the game in the third act when the game play loop was getting old. Finally, the bugs. I know every bad review talks about the bugs in this game, and although I didn't encounter too many through out my first run, the ones I did encounter were fairly annoying and did bump the difficulty spike briefly; whether it be me assisting a customer of a faction that didn't like me just to not get any points added despite me seeing the +1 or +2 above their head, or me completing an order correctly in a fair competition to still lose points. Regardless, instances like those were fairly frustrating but they were rare compared to other folks' reviews.

TL;DR
Anvil Saga does have some issues and is far from a perfect game; however, if you enjoy cozy games, you don't mind putting up with some quirks, or you think being a black smith sounds fun, then Anvil Saga is a game that you will have a good time with! I do recommend buying this on sale (unless you got some cash burning a hole in your pocket) as I believe $20 is a bit too steep of a price for the content, imo. | ĞÑ‡ĞµĞ½ÑŒ Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°Ñ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ½Ğ° 2-3 Ğ²ĞµÑ‡ĞµÑ€Ğ°.

It's very hard to decide whether to recommend the game or not. I really, really want to congratulate it on it's unique ideas, but the rest of the game just drags it all down.
The main premise of the game is very good and uniquely fun, creating the world from pieces is truly fun and basically caries the game on it's shoulders. Everything else about the game ranges from meh to offensively bad.  
- Character portraits have that aftertaste of generated slop, and even though I can't tell if it is, the fact that it's indistinguishable from the generated slop is telling enough. 
- I'm sorry to say it, but the writing and the story is soulwretchingly bad. Either it's generated, badly translated, or both, it's basically that placeholder story that designers put in the game at the beginning, with the intent to change for a real story later. The writing is one step above of lorem ipsum and gets somehow worse as the game progresses. 
- Probably the worst quality of the game design is it's primary gameplay loop that consists of holding a use button in the vicinity of an object, hold if for just enough time to get bored, but not enough to start getting distracted. Holding the button in boredom is basically 80% of the game and it's baaaaad. 
- Combat is somehow even worse, it's clunky, unresponsive, ranging from boring to annoying, I can't even tell what's worse, melee or ranged.

The fact that I finished the story despite all that is a testament to how fun the premise is. But for all the hours of my life that the game stole from me, making me hold the button down like it's some kind of illegal psychological experiment, I have to not recommend it afterall. | ĞĞµĞ¿Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ…Ğ°Ñ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ² ÑĞ²Ğ¾Ñ‘Ğ¼ Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ½Ñ€Ğµ, Ğ½ĞµĞ¾Ğ±Ñ‹Ñ‡Ğ½Ğ°Ñ Ğ¼ĞµÑ…Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ĞºĞ° ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¸Ñ‚ĞµĞ»ÑŒÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ° (Ğ½Ğ°Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ° Ğ¼Ğ½Ğµ Ğ½Ğ°ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒĞ½ÑƒÑ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñƒ ĞšĞ°Ñ€ĞºĞ°ÑĞ¾Ğ½).

First thing, this game is very very addictive, I'd give you that. Once you start a game you will find it very very hard to stop playing. My 227 hours play time should be evidence enough to prove my point. But sadly, among my 227 play time, 99% of it was solo play. I would dearly like to join a clan and play with some other players. But alas, although the game does support clan play, some feature of the game or should I say lack of it, made it very unfriendly for clan play.  

The one thing I hate about this game is that all members within a clan shares everything. And in everything, I mean freaking EVERYTHING. All you can do is to trust in your clan member's ethics and hope they won't rob you blind when you're not in the game. Even the stuff in your so-call personal strongbox can be access by your clan members. So what good is a personal strongbox if everyone can get the stuff you stashed in it. I mean, why put in a personal strongbox in the first place is its utterly useless. At least put in some permission settings for the owner to restrict access to their stuff. 

Another thing is the loot system. I once cleared a tier 2 rift boss when another player came in and took all my loot dropped from the boss. The player was not even a clan member, just another solo player who came in and ninja looted all my stuff. 

All of this BS is making it very hard for anyone to form and invite people into a clan unless all the clan members are also real life friends. No one likes to be betrayed and rob of their hard earn possessions when they are not looking.

The game plateaus very quickly though. Very little replayable value for me.  After a couple of hours it gets tedious.  Boring.  I regret buying this game. | The novel Dune was written during the Cold War, and this game has that aura.

Do not expect a standard RTS. This is a game about statecraft, about cold wars, about the balance of power, about paranoia. Warfare is a continuation of policy by other means- often an inevitable one, but more pursued to deny the enemy victory than to seize it. It's more about medieval-style raids & chevauchÃ©es than massive campaigns. The Landsraad and intelligence systems are brilliant. Expect assassinations to be a more common threat than sieges of enemy capitals are.

As an adaptation of the novel within the confines of a Civ-style game, it's excellent. The great dangers of Arrakis, the thirst & the worms, are of both strategic & tactical importance- by which I mean they will destroy your entire army if you slip up. So many of the little details of the world are here as well, down to the Fremen donkeys. The factions from the book are invoked wonderfully in gameplay too- the honor and "honor" of the Atreides, the drugged-up thuggery of the Harkonnen troops, the vicious, vampiric fanaticism of the Fremen, the Corrinos lurking aside, playing one House against another until they can throw down a fortress from orbit and seize the planet for themselves. The additional factions are flavorful too.

I'd recommend this game in particular to those who love the book & its cynical philosophy, and to those who like the idea of games like Civ but want something leaner, quicker, & smarter. 

Note that God created the single-player mode to train for the multiplayer mode. This review has assumed that it's the latter you'll be getting the game for. | Feels great. The environment is very dangerous but fair. Politics works, which is impressive for this kind of game. The factions have good differentiation- Harkonnens oppress their people and throw away their own people to feed the machine. Fremen move easily in the desert but they don't get to vote in politics. Atreides can be very effective politcally and can take villages peacefully. And whoever you are, there are the constant pressures of collecting the Spice. | It's too much like the game Civilization and not enough like DUNE 2000.  

It's not a bad game and i can even see how it could have become oddly addicting for many people but for me personally it doesn't really have what i want to satisfy me.  The biggest issue is the lack of strategy involved for how you set up your base/territories.  In fact there is very little actual decision making that goes into your base setup at all.  Instead it's a repetitive process of taking over preexisting villages, then haphazardly placing whatever structures you need around it for that given territory depending on which resources the territory has.  It makes zero strategic difference where you place your buildings because they're never attacked anyway.   It's only the Villages themselves that ever come under threat.. which by the way you defend by repetitively hiring militia for every annex'd village.  In this regard, the game is totally brainless and requires no strategic thinking for how you go about setting up your territories.  In DUNE 2000, for example, there was a very satisfying sense of accomplishment for the way you choose to build your base and design it's defenses.  Spice Wars just doesn't have that.

There is a lot more i could say both negatively and positively about the game but it's mostly the lack of strategy and satisfaction that comes with conquering territories that bothers me.

This game is cool! It has a clever way of bundling cards with car upgrades and allowing you to customize constantly.  The strategy is pretty solid.  It gets a tad repetative but it's lots of fun and I hope they add complexity via expansions and new game modes. | Yeah, this is an excellent game.

But it isn't without a few bumps and the occasional pothole.

The tutorial doesn't cover some fairly important mechanics and, whilst once you grok how to read the cards things get quite a bit easier, the presentation of the cars is a little lacking in that it isn't clear at first how priorities work, in what sequence certain things happen, and generally, there are quite a few moving parts under the bonnet (hood for our North American friends).

But once you get behind the wheel for a few runs, the handling starts to make sense, and you can put some pretty satisfying builds together. 

I'm a dabbler in deck builders but hardly a committed theory-crafter. I do get the impression that there is less variety of potential builds in this than in some other deckkies, but your mileage may vary. I'm probably not the best to make a definitive judgement on that front.

I'm judging the game purely on whether I enjoyed my time with it, and it's a definite yes.

It's a green light from me!





 | Cool deck builder with mechanics that match the theme, | Jeux sympa, reste quelques bugs malheureusement . | Macht SpaÃŸ!^^

TL;DR I would only recommend this for die-hard Borderlands fans.

The pre-endgame is exceedingly easy despite setting the difficulty to "Intense". I never struggled once up until the end game boss. The most difficult parts of earlier games were the burst damage some enemies did that was hard to overcome as a solo. While I am glad they scaled that back in this game, with no other challenge provided the core loop is reduced to holding down M1 until the enemy dies. To top it off, every quest was just "go here press E, go here shoot this, go here press E". It was a bit disappointing. 

Now admittedly this wouldn't be so egregious if there was a gripping story or moment-to-moment writing like Borderlands 2 had, but personally this game fell very flat in that regard. I listened to every dialogue line and did every side quest expecting at least some moments with the same charm as the previous games, but I didn't find any. Perhaps I have simply become jaded, but there were no hard-hitting lines nor engaging plot lines. I lightly chuckled twice the entire game. I never cringed or wondered what the writers were smoking as I did with BL3, but the Wonderlands plot was simply bland.

This isn't to say the entire game is horrible. I like much of the balance changes they made, the art style is charming, and the class system is interesting. The legendary drop rate is lowered in this game compared to BL3, which was desperately needed as they felt a dime-a-dozen in that game. This is balanced out by having your loot luck increase as you progress in the game which I felt fit very well. The new gun types, the few that aren't recycled from BL3 that is, are fun to play with and a welcome addition. And I appreciate the take on classes with a respeccable second class, although I think I still prefer the per-character system from the mainline games.

Should also be mentioned the end game is potentially the best in a Borderlands game so far: a set of repeatable trial chambers which tie closely into the "Chaos Level" system that increases enemy toughness and unlocks better tiers of gear. I have not completed all the Chaos Levels and won't pretend to have beaten each end game in all BL games, but I would like to say that this feels the most replayable and fair.

Overall a game with fun mechanics that falls entirely flat in the story department. | It's an alright game.

Basic borderlands looter shooter concept, but DnD themed.
Skill trees I feel are less impacting than previous iterations of the game.
You can do a dual class system which I like a lot.
The introduction of companions for most classes is cool, but I feel like they fall pretty short, even when trying to spec into them.
The weapons aren't that much different than other borderlands games. With a difference that you can different melee weapons, and a spell equipped. These are nice twists, and spells can be pretty fun with the variety of options.
The story is kind of dull to be honest. Very heavy in dialogue, which I understand it's a DnD game. But you start to tune out after a while.
The gameplay loop isn't really that exciting. The difficulty is pretty moderate with that you can clear most mobs easily, but then you have to play a little tactfully with others.

Overall I'd say it's worth a heavy discount. Definitely never worth the full asking price.

I loved what I saw in Early Access. I decided that this game would be best played with friends once it hit 1.0, so I put it down for Future Me, and Future Us, to experience together.

Early on, it was great. Weâ€™re all veterans of [i]Terraria[/i]. In particular, I enjoyed the automation of gathering nodes and sending them along back to base.

But once you crack that initial outer wall open, oh boy, does it get grindy right quick.

You need ten whatsits to create the thingamajig that lets you scan for the boss. Fine, OK. But then youâ€™re going to need 10 whozsamutsises to create the next boss scanning item, unless you want to explore the entirely-too-big map to find the boss on your own. So just adjust your playstyle and preferences accordingly, because you, son, are going to grind, and grind, and grind if you want to participate in this world.

I wasnâ€™t having fun. I felt bad that I recommended this game to my friend group, and when I floated the idea that maybe we should move on to something less grindy, they basically said, â€œOh, yeah, absolutely. We were only playing this because we thought you were really into it.â€ Admittedly, I was. At first.

The map needs to be smaller if this game is going for a boss-rush gameplay model. The grind needs to be lessened if you want people with lives and jobs to be interested. Thereâ€™s a lot to love about the first handful of hours played, but itâ€™s an absolute fumble after that point. Quite the disappointment. | å¤ªå¥½ç©äº†å¤ªå¥½ç©äº†å‘œå‘œå‘œï¼Œå³ä½¿ç¼åˆä¹Ÿç¼åˆçš„éå¸¸å¥½ï¼Œä¸€ç©èµ·æ¥æ ¹æœ¬åœä¸ä¸‹æ¥å•Šï¼Œæˆ‘è¦å€Ÿæˆ‘å¥½å…„å¼Ÿ20å¹´çš„å¯¿å‘½æ¥ç€ç©ï¼Œå¤ªå¥½ç©äº†å¤ªå¥½ç©äº†

One of the greatest turn-based strategy games of all time, remastered.  A few new heroes added, a few UI tweaks, graphics upgraded, hex-based terrain instead of grid-based.  All in all a complete win of an upgrade.  I bought the original for $50 in 1994 and played it for almost 30 years - now I have a replacement that's worth the name. | Apparently this game was released in 2022 but I've only just got it in 2025. So far so good, it's a solid rework of the original 1994 Master of Magic from Simtex. Pretty 3D graphics, overland and combat maps in hex format and improved UI. Some highlights that I've noted so far:

Pros

A sensible build queue for towns that can be allowed to run and then adjusted as necessary.
Itemised notification of micro-events.
New buildings for previously neglected races e.g. Orcs get the Amplifier (for Nodes) and Fisherman's Hut (Food source).
New races e.g. Goblins are available a Myrror race.
Improved Trading.
New traits to go alongside spellbooks.
New overland/city events with choices!
Spellcasting now results in a micro-event rather than forcing immediate casting.
Fixes for old MoM 'exploits' and 'bugs' such as Endurance extra effects, Cloak of Fear (it works), Floating Island (now flies over land and sea), Earth to Mud, Web et al.
Combat can be player-controlled or familiar-controlled (automatic) as required with percentage success chances provided upfront.
Combat changes to rock-hurling units e.g. Giants, Catapults add extra functionality.

Cons

Occasionally confusing L-click vs R-click inconsistency in UI, not a stopper but can lead to WTF?! moments in combat.
Spell research animations have, disappointingly, not been brought into the 2020's.
Inability to customise city names on founding (or I may have missed how to this).
Inability to customise hero names on summoning/hiring (or I may have missed how to this).
Wonky Diplomacy (something dodgy here).

I have yet to find any serious bugs although to be fair it's early days. What I have found is a solid, entertaining 4X game that builds on the legacy of the original. | Great remake with additional content and the original awesome gameplay. | I've been pretty disappointed with video game remakes in the past. Not this time, in fact I'd say it's the best remake.
Why?
1. It keeps the original mechanics of the game.
2. It has lots new mechanics that are OPTIONAL. But I've tried four different optional updates, including the 2 DLCs, and I gotta say, I loved them and felt they blended in seamlessly. 
3. Allows workshop content.
4. Not buggy. | the audio cuts out and it took almost 20 min to even start a game from booting the game up. it could be my potato of a PC but i have played other games with higher Requirements and it did not run this bad

This game has taught me that I'm absolutely amazing at organizing things. Wow, I feel great about myself. Thank you, devs! | a little to the left is a satisfying puzzle game with fun, creative ways to tidy up but the daily tidy is a drag. doing it for consecutive days gets boring and since it's required for 100% achievements, it ends up feeling more like a chore especially when the puzzles are underwhelming. great game, just wish the daily part wasnâ€™t such a hassle. | I found a lot of the later levels to be unclear as far as the intended sort order or objective.

To quote another reviewer who put it better than I could:

"The game started out strong and I felt satisfied after finishing each level. That wore out too quickly and I felt frustration for the rest of the game. The biggest drawback is the lack of visible anchor points. The game wants the player to pick up items and put them in exact spots to trigger level completion, but the player cannot see those anchor points."
