Genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Simulation, Early Access
Reviews:
I love this game, I really do.
Unfortunately, the performance of this game has gotten worse with each patch, not better.
So I can't recommend it to anyone as this has been a long standing issue, that I have not seen the devs acknowledge or try to fix. | This game isn't bad, but it's got a long way still to go it's basically raft in a blimp. could use some better tutorials and some quest markers maybe something you can turn off and on if you wanted. there isn't much to do once you've got the cure and the game is still in early access so honestly id say get the game on sale for like 15-20 bucks that's about right for what I got from it. out of 10 id say 5/10 nice middle ground but not enough happening in game for my liking also would be great to get a little polish to movement and some more diversity in environments and some world stuff everything just kinda ends up looking the same this is also true for the life pods if we came form space were's all the cool toys? if it sounds interesting to you check it out on sale but I can't say there's enough here for me to recommend
 it to others.  Oh and two last thing a booster back or something would be great in this game surprised they didn't put it in and some more enemies wouldn't hurt think there's like four in the entire game. | Wife and I are playing game. We have hard time finding good games for both of us. This is a great story and fun to play. It has a bit of everything crafting, searching, looting,  light building. Exploring. It is open world but has a story to follow. | Even in early access, this game is pretty good. The combat and survival systems are serviceable, with the story being unfinished pending the full release. Game atmosphere and base building aspects are fantastic.

Most of my nearly 80 hours in my first *two weeks* of playing was spent building and vibing in my ship. I was absolutely addicted to designing and rebuilding my ship every time I got a new building unlock. I also really enjoyed the game's take on a post-apocalypse Earth. Taking my newly rebuilt ship into the sky to admire the swirling dust below was a regular pastime.

I have exhausted nearly everything there is to do in game currently, so I am now eagerly awaiting the full release. In addition to concluding the story, my wishlist for 1.0 and beyond would be ship presets, cheaper paint, more POIs, and concave hull pieces to make proper airplane bodies. | This game is pretty meh.  It's a tedium simulator and in that regard it does it very well. 

If I was to compare it to other games it would be Raft crossed with Subnautica but without the sharks.  Therein lies the problem:  I miss the sharks.  Eventually you start coming across these Mantis things but combat with them is incredibly janky to the point that I just face tanked them with my knife.

If you enjoyed Subnautica but found that the creatures just got in the way of the story, you'll probably like this game.  If you're expecting a survival game with combat and threats, stay away.

Game Name: Age of Empires IV: Anniversary Edition
Reviews:
I was banned for "map hacking," even though I didnâ€™t cheatâ€”I was simply using the Imperial Spies ability from the Chinese civilization. During the match, I was dominating my opponent, and they started flaming me in chat before reporting me. Somehow, that led to me getting banned.

I submitted a ban appeal, but the response took so long that the ban is effectively over by the time they rejected it. When I asked for more information to understand what triggered the ban and how to avoid it in the future, they refused to provide any details, claiming it would "jeopardize the integrity of their moderation system." As a result, I have no idea what I did that caused the ban.

Itâ€™s hard to recommend a game where you can get banned simply because youâ€™re winning and other players report you out of spite. The slow appeal process and lack of transparency make it clear: play at your own risk.

Feel free to review my games if you think I'm lying: https://aoe4world.com/players/8767995-BunBun | æˆ‘ä¸€ä¸ªå•æœºç©å®¶ä½ æŠŠä¿®æ”¹å™¨ç»™å°äº†ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸æ˜¯æœ‰æ¯›ç—…ã€‚ä½ è¦å°å°±å°è”ç½‘ç©å®¶å°±è¡Œäº†ï¼Œä½ ç®¡æˆ‘ä»¬å•æœºç©å®¶å¼€ä¿®æ”¹å™¨å¹²å—ï¼Ÿæˆ‘ä¹°äº†è¿™æ¸¸æˆå°±æ˜¯å½“å•æœºæ¥æ‰“å‘æ—¶é—´çš„ï¼Œä½ ä¸å…è®¸å•æœºä½ æ—©è¯´å•Šã€‚ | When I heard about Age of Empires IV (AoEIV) I couldn't wait to play it, since playing all of the previous entries had gave me one of the most memorable experiences I had ever had in gaming. And here is what I have to say:

I love how AoEIV had taken the time and effort to bring us a historically-accurate stories that are tied to the gameplay. I really enjoyed the aesthetic of it; it certainly makes the game so unique with their colors, their sound design and the way you can experience the gameplay and the cinematics. I think this is the part that I love the most.

Each of the civilizations feel unique, although not as unique as in Age of Empires III (AoEIII), in my opinion, with exceptions, naturally. I think it a bit as a combination between Age of empires II (AoEII) and AoEIII, leaning a little bit towards AoEII, which, by the way, is my favorite Age of Empires due to several reasons. The strategies and battles are surely good and I enjoy having different kinds of the same group of units, each with different functions. The walls' mechanics are also a good addition and adds a lot in terms of strategies and siege.

I know for a fact that many of the updates have solved many of the issues that player the player base have experienced by now and I applaud this; it was actually the bugs that led me to abandon the game some time ago, hoping for it to get better after some updates. And it really happened, even releasing a DLC. Reading this DLC's reviews, which I won't buy at least for now, shows me that AoEIV may be in a limbo where instead of taking advantage of what it is, it is just a bit nervous about the steps they need to follow to earn new and old fans of the series.

One of the things I don't like at all is that there's too little focus on the single-player experience. What I loved about AoEII was the different heroes, scenarios and setting of the campaigns, and that is also one of the things that made AoEII so memorable for many people; the amount of content that you could experience on your own was tremendous and adding the multiplayer was just perfect for all types of players. AoEIV is lacking heavily on this side: there's only half the campaigns for each of the civilizations that you can play. This is, you can't have a designed single-player experience focused on each civilization, which I find upsetting. Even more: I believe that releasing a DLC with single-player DLC-civ's campaigns before having the base game civ's ones is unforgivable.

The game really wants to push you into multiplayer, which, of course, is a big part â€”maybe even the most important partâ€” of these types of game. And even though I understand why this has been done, I think that leaving the single-player experience ins such a small featuring is something that takes too big a hit on the experience.

Finally, I want to say that I played all the campaigns but I was not able to get one of the achievements due to a long-known bug. The game has been out for years by now and I think that having this bug, something so small, still lingering in the game after all the feedback is so embarrassing. 

With that being said, I think that the game is a good one and for the time I played it I had fun. It obviously had a new and good idea of what to do and what it wanted to be, but I think that the execution is a half-baked product that leaves aside a great portion of the players. I think that the game can continue with this fresh appearance and twist on the series, which I think is amazing, but it also has to take into consideration all of the accomplishments made by previous games to be better that the sum of its parts.

Solid game, but it still needs some work.

6/10 | You either are forced to play at a fast pace or lose. There is no longer a nice build up time, its all action nonstop. I miss my relaxed games and campaigns but devs decided to appeal to the zoomers 0.5s attention span and make the game feel rushed all the time. Going back to AoE2 and AoE3 for slower and relaxed games. | I've played RTS games for 18 years now (started when I was 4 with the original starcraft). I was always horrible at playing multiplayer. This is without the doubt the best RTS game to start playing multiplayer if you always wanted to give multiplayer a shot but were scared of being bad at it (like me!).

The players in ranked and quick matches are not some high level players! For the most part they are like me and you who just play this game for fun and not for being overly competitive. While the campaign is nothing really to write home about (though the cutscenes are pretty cool), I cannot recommend this game enough if you wanted to ever have a go at RTS multiplayer that is not overly sweaty!

But don't just take my word for it! Here is a very great video on the topic if you have some free time: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rl4myN8q_KM&t=3237s&ab_channel=CloudCuckooCountry

Cheers!

There is a big BUT in this review.......
Yes I would recommend it but there is definitely some misleading marketing happening.

THE GOOD:
This is a super easy to use, 3D mapping software with a very intuitive user interface, easy control system, and is over all pleasant to create with. Out of the box you have numerous options that allow you to build any map you like in nearly any setting you like. 

The software also comes with an export feature with allows you to export the map out of Dungeon Alchemist and into the more popular, if not many of the online VTT systems like Foundry VTT and Roll20. 

BUT BUT BUT BUT BUT

THE BAD: 
For all the power this software has, it cannot export 3D maps, meaning you can look at your amazing 3D map all you want in the Dungeon Alchemist software, but don't expect to get it out. Exports will 100% in 2D. I don't know how complex it would be to do this but for all this software does and all this amazing marketing footage....your 3D map is essentially stuck. 

I spoke to one of their Discord mods who said that some people do things with the 3D images to make handouts and other have used the interface as a VTT...but when you consider all of the automation and optimization in a platform like Foundry VTT offers, there is no way I would ever sacrifice all of that just to have a 3D environment. 

HOWEVER.........BACK TO THE GOOD NEWS

Exporting your 3D map into a 2D format does still save you tons of time as the 2D export comes with well placed wall and doors and it all setup for lighting. With the Dungeon Alchemist software having a much smoother and versatile interface then trying to build a map into Foundry VTT, this is still worth the price. 

TLDR: 
I like the software but the the marketing is very misleading. You cannot export 3D maps out of Dungeon Alchemist and all the hype about what it can do in their videos and Steam advertisement is locked to the software itself. The export feature only exports 2D maps. | Muito agradÃ¡vel, facilita demais a criaÃ§Ã£o de mapas de batalha e quando fica sem criatividade ele ajuda com a IA para geraÃ§Ã£o de decoraÃ§Ã£o das salas. Muito bom, recomendo para mestres de RPG. | a really good tabeltop map builder. quite worth the money.

I also saw someone mentioned the game was based on UK, and said the festival area is the main feature from a town :) thought that was cool. Happy gaming! <3

It's an expansion of the Stanley Parable; it includes all the original endings, as well as hours of new content. Overall, this game adds so much new content that you will have to keep playing in order to find and experience everything.

Genres: Adventure, Indie, RPG, Strategy, Early Access
Reviews:
A fantasy rpg meets HOMM, together they meet great writing and stunningly colorful pixelart and while not skiping on a lovely retro atmosphere, they all meet modern UX. What's there not to like about it? | I played for a bit over one hour and I want to share my positive initial impressions. 
The pixel art is a true joy for the eyes, I often stopped to just stare at the environment for entire minutes and enjoyed all the little details. I need to have this on my desktop as an animated wallpaper!
The beginning of the story is catchy, with good narrative enhanced by a great voice acting. That was a real surprise, it's rare to find full voice acting in indie games. It does a great deal for the immersion and I must compliment the devs and the actors.
I enjoyed the exploration and my first combat sessions, and I'm looking forward to see how the RPG elements develop.
The only -minor- issue I found is that a few UI elements seemed not in their intended position after changing resolution, as if they ended up slightly shifted. This didn't affect the experience at all and it's important to remember the game is in Early Access.
Now if you excuse me, I'll go back to Anchorage, adventure awaits! | Very solid foundations for the game. A bit of early access indie dev syndrome here and there with interactibles missing tooltips, or buildings claiming functionality that isn't implemented yet such as investing resources to upgrade your units. At least, if that's supposed to be implemented I haven't figured it out because the buildings are non-interactible once constructed and the corresponding landmarks don't seem to have any purpose.

But beyond that I feel like there's more to this game than advertised. I'm several hours in to the replayable campaign and frankly it doesn't seem that short to me as I've barely even left the first zone. A game of Jebus Cross in HoMM3 would've been done by now. It's also innovating a lot more on the HoMM formula than I expected, combining it with card and RPG mechanics in combat rather than stacks, and not having strategic turns like you're zooming around in your nwcnebuchadnezzar. An animation speed option for those lengthy cross-map treks would be nice though. | The core gameplay loop seems to be clicking past dialogue in order to be rewarded with more dialogue to click past

I didn't like the mix of Heroes combat with card-based combat. I think doing one or the other but not both would be better | Very cool game reminiscent of the original King's Bounty with a touch of HOMM, AOW, and Disciples 2. It's exploration and adventure based, with turn-based battles, with characters you can recruit during the story and add to your party.

The world is extremely fresh and creative and beautifully depicted in pixel art. What a cool new setting for a fantasy game at a time when most fantasy worlds are getting more and more samey and cookie cutter. Here you can play as humans/merfolk, wild nature based beasts, mysterious otherworldly cultists, or advanced techy cyborgs. All the factions are very creative, interesting, and distinct. The characters all have tons of personality and charm and you can role play your leader's background and personality and develop the story however you choose.

There are some bugs and jank but that is to be expected at this point in development. Super impressive entry from an indie developer and I'm very excited to see where this game goes during Early Access.
To say it clear: For me it is one of the best games of all times.

Not a hard game on any of its aspects, but it works and feels good, be it for mostly any of its features.

A fun distraction.

I just wish it would have been an easier setup (controls wise) on the Steam Deck. | It's good.  It has modular building, something I wish Starsector had.  Only gripe is that it's limited in how much content their is, I was really hoping it would have some sort of NG+ or Infinite Progression given the whole "Multiverse" thing that's going on with it.

Hope that's remedied in the future. | Top down space fighters are a dime a dozen.  This one separates itself from the pack.  Looks great, combat is great, ship building is great, exploration is great AND writing is great.  I really enjoyed the story and commentary by my crew.  I'd say 8/10. | Good, well balanced game. Length is fine, story is good, lore is exceptional | Fun game, would say this is a 30 hour title before you get tired of the gameplay loop.  This is much so a read for lore and where decisions have consequences.  If you like reading books and playing at your pace solo its a fun starship game.

What a neat game! One of my favourites from Sokpop, for sure! The map is very neat and I like the idea of there being this tiny fantasy world to have a tiny adventure in. The Lich glitched on one of my run and only started spawning tentacles once I lost a fight against it, getting later similarly stuck in another place. Other than that & some other glitches I had a great time. | I played this over and over again with my friend. Such a great RPG!

I have been looking for an RPG of this style for close to 8 years now. I have been going through a nostalgia kick lately and Castle of the Winds was one of my favorite older RPG's. The simplisic yet strategic fighting style was something very few games manage to incorporate correctly. I'm not a fan of the rogue-like where you continuously make new characters. I really would love to see a second game in the series or a completely different game with the rpg elements in Of Blades and Tails. Seriously great work I'm so happy with this purchase | Too much bugs, and not minor ones. It's just frustrating when you get stuck in combat without being able to do anything ( both you and enemies are frozen still and no items or actions can be used ), resulting in you having to restart the game and lose all the items as it counts as dying. Maybe think about adding a manual save option to somewhat bypass the completely broken game logic and design. | Game has a lot of potential. Can't wait to see if there is future content added. | It's a fun turn based RPG
No Reviews

Let me say this first: this was not my type of game. I did not enjoy the gameplay, the controls were a clunky sometimes and the ending was unsatisfying. It has a great story, great atmosphere, no scroll (moving forward screen by screen), it uses cinematics for deaths, ...

The puzzles are mostly easy, with a few exceptions. But, it's not a game only focused with puzzles, so they are not extremely relevant.

On the other hand, the character movement and her movement reactions are a bit slow, which is a bit frustrating when enemies are following you or you need to react quickly to avoid any danger.
 | A small sized cinematic platformer that you can finish in about 3 hours. It's incredibly on point when it comes to recreating the vibe of the 16bit wave of the genre. I think it could've gone for longer, specially since the last third of the game is when it starts introducing more original imagery and situations. It's consistently good, but nothing outstanding.

If the developers keep making cinematic platformers in this vein, I bet they could make a classic. They just need to cut down the time you spend in ventilation vents, focus more on dynamic/original situations, and double the length. As it is, Full Void is neat. A nice time. I would easily recommend it if you crave a game in the same gameplay and visual style as Flashback and company. Could've been more, but it's still really cool to get a game like this when Inside/Planet of Lana and other modern approaches are dominating the subgenre.

If you like Another world (out of this world) or Flashback, you will definitely like this one.......

Genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
Reviews:
I used to play this. A lot, as you can see from the playtime. Most of the time I spent in the game was in 2022-23. I had a good group of people I played with and the servers were full of great people. We didn't really know what we were getting into, however, and eventually we all started playing less and less. Mostly because we realized that this isn't really a game. It's a job that you can pay your employer for the privilege of playing. You either pay to skip the grind or you perform ridiculous amounts of fetch quests and spam the 'G' (interact) key. I'm not kidding when I'm saying there are things that you need to do hundreds to thousands and tens of thousand times. There is an 'island soul' that has a less than 1% chance to drop from a pouch that has a less than 1% chance to drop from a mob. I don't know what the math on that works out to exactly, but googling says in the thousands of hours.

Gear 'honing' has abysmal success rates and you lose materials on every attempt. The honing materials are tiered and each level requires a different material so all your old mats are virtually worthless when you move up a tier. Drop rates for 'collection' items are extremely low and many mobs, bosses, events, and/or islands only spawn once or twice a day/week, so collection can take hundreds of hours for a single item.

Every system in the game is designed to take as much time as possible, every single day, unless you pay. Even if you pay, the time gates and drop rates stay the same, so you still have to grind. Beyond the currency bloat, there are also 4+ XP systems you need to grind.

I stopped eventually because of the sheer grindiness and utterly ridiculous currency and loot box mechanics. I came back recently because I heard some of the newer updates reduced the grind and simplified the currency. I thought I'd take a look and see whether it was worth coming back to.

I should not have. The grind is all still there and, if anything, is worse. The currency has been simplified a bit but it is still ridiculous. There is still silver, gold, crystals, royal crystals, pirate coins, open seas coins, pheons, shards, fragments, and probably others that I've just forgotten. There are six different 'profession' currencies that you have to collect and each of them has multi tiered rarities. You can convert between all of these at awful (like 10 to 1) exchange rates. There are sinks for all of them everywhere.

Despite simplifying some things, they've added whole new systems to make things even more grindy and confusing. These systems have new fetch and farm quests and use different materials that you need to use that have low drop and conversion rates. It's just more of the same.

Trying to play content from before the endgame is hit or miss because people are simply not there and the content is not accessible by just one person. You can ask in chat and you might get lucky, but there is very little incentive for an end-game character to help out with content that they probably haven't touched in years. There is a 'solo' mode option for some pre-endgame content, which can be useful, but it's a little laughable having a 'solo' mode anything in an MMO.

I could try to find a guild and try out discord to get some older, wider content done, but that doesn't solve the grind and loot box issues this game has. I don't mind grinding for an item, but grinding for just a chance at an item is a special level of hell.

There are some nice people still playing and you might be able to connect with them in game or over discord and get some things done if you are new or returning, but if you value your time, money, and sanity, don't. Pick another MMO. | Quiero aclarar que el juego en si es muy bueno, el problema es que no recomendarÃ­a este juego a un jugador nuevo, ya que solo puedes jugar a este juego y disfrutarlo siendo nuevo jugador si tienes amigos que ya jueguen de antes y tengan personajes muy avanzados. Los jugadores nuevos son muy fÃ¡cilmente identificables, siendo muy difÃ­cil que te inviten a grupos para poder realizar el contenido final del juego. Por otro lado, es un juego extremadamente exigente respecto a las horas necesarias dedicadas al dÃ­a, por lo tanto, es necesaria una inversiÃ³n de horas extremadamente elevada para que puedas jugar de manera autÃ³noma, pudiendo ser frustrante para muchos jugadores nuevos. | This game suffers a major struggle as one that is developed by a Korean development company and published by an American company who pushes the game updates from KR to the western version of the game. The publisher has no power or will to transform the new (or current) player experience in a meaningful, permanent way that will help them ascend to the relative power levels of veteran players.

One of the best examples: Gearing a character in this game requires collections of 'cards' for card sets which are a huge component of damage or support power for players. As such, it requires too much time commitment and/or money for new players to get to a point where they are comfortably playing endgame content with veteran players or normal consistent raid lobbies at all due to this huge missing chunk of damage or support power.

Due to the nature of raid leaders being able to inspect the full range of gear for applicants to raid lobbies, many players will be rejected because of their lack in raid power. Due to the difficulty and dps checks of some raids, the lower power players will have a hard time clearing raid content with each other at all even if they do make their own lobbies.

The developers did make content called 'solo raids' which can be completed for some of the relevant gear materials, but due to the content release schedule of the game, players are never quite able to catch up because their rate of growth is too slow.

By the time a newer player is ready to play a newer raid, most of the population will have moved on to a newer raid, and a fresh player will not have an easy time finding a raid group in the Lobby Finder that will help them learn an older raid. The older raids are referred to as 'homework', and players are often expected to already have played and farmed the raid enough by that time, so as not to hold back the players who want to complete this 'homework' raid for their needed gold.

Speaking of gold, the Western version of the game is suffering from very high economic inflation due to the rampant and seemingly unstoppable plague of gold farming bots. Korea doesn't suffer from this issue because their game client requires a Korean SSN to verify identity. Steam has no such requirements, so bot accounts can be made in mass volumes to this day.
It's against the terms of service for players to purchase gold from these bots, but they continue to do so and purchase (from the Auction House) either large volumes of honing materials or high value gear which also happens to be in high demand from the general population.

Lost Ark at its core was such a cool game and I'm happy to have played it since launch, but as of Feb2025 it's not hard to see that this game's publisher (Amazon Game Studios) and/or developers (Smilegate) continue to betray its audience at large by not acknowledging core issues at all or addressing them in a timely manner.

There are other issues I'm sure I forgot to mention, but needless to say I can't recommend this game for any new or current players at this time. | i love the game, but management is  the worst you can get in MMO. 
IF you looking for developer or publisher communications, feedback review and improvements, addressing community needs and adapting to changing economy, meaningful monetization and much more, this is not a game for you to play! 
The only way to play it is wait for progression event -> choose the class you like -> do some solo content (raids). Rest of the game is completely out of touch with reality and will never be improved no matter how hard you wanted it to, User can never be heard! | Strongly do not recommend this game. If you are a returning player even with purchase of starter pack you will get falsely banned for botting. LEVEL 5 by the way the highest degree of cheating. My friend has max 20 hours on this game and has not logged on since 2022 so tell me how they botted? They have 10 gold to their name at most like please be for real?

When he submitted an appeal, it got denied within 3 minutes. So you're telling me someone actually took a look at his account and determined it as a denial IN 2 MINUTES? I really don't understand.

TambÃ©m tem missÃµes adicionais q vc pode fazer depois de votar no fantasma e fogem do padrÃ£o Phasmophobia. | I really wanted to like this, but after learning that AI is being used I cannot abide playing this literally at all. I've requested a refund, and it makes me really sad! I love Phasmophobia and wanted another immersive sort of game like it, and it really seemed like Demonologist would have been it - but it wasn't.

The graphics are pretty but that's literally where it begins and ends. The game is laggy as hell with frequent frame drops, despite the fact I have 48GB of ram and a 4080 Nvidia graphics card. I have a 1GB upload and download speed and experienced connectivity issues as well. 

I played for about an hour, everything is completely scripted and every time we'd go in to play, it was repetitive to the point I was desensitized by the second round. The customization is bare bones and everything felt like a cheap asset flip. I feel like I was scammed and is honestly an ugly rip off of Phasmophobia, designed to allure long-time players into buying the product in hopes of having a fresh but familiar experience. It wasn't. 

Everything about the game was incredibly unintuitive, to the point that we had to go to outside sources to even figure out what each object was and how to use it. There was no tutorial, or if there was - it's unintuitive enough to where I could not find it.

I genuinely do not mind the overused assets and animations, it doesn't really bother me! If it can be used well and I can have an enjoyable experience, then whatever! But the collected experience of everything that it did poorly and nothing done well (hell not even optimized) I cannot support this. 

I don't care if this is a one-man or small dev team. You can hire an artist to do the work that was generated by fugly ass AI. Honestly with it attempting to shamelessly ride the coattails of Phasmophobia instead of attempting to innovate, I should have known better! If you have any respect for uniqueness or creativity, then don't buy this.

Well, that was a 10/10. Highly recommended to puzzle amateurs.

++ right length and pacing
++ a touching story on the theme of the tower of Babel, with an optimistic twist. It's told in a minimalist way, mostly with environmental storytelling
+ puzzles are on the easy side, but still satisfying to solve.

I will definitely be replaying it, but it would be nice to somehow play it for the first time again. | Beautiful, smooth graphics and great puzzles! I got stuck on a non-linguistic puzzle here and there, but overall it was the perfect difficulty for a casual puzzle lover (I love puzzle games, but I'm usually not very good at the harder ones). I especially loved the parts where I got to translate/interpret between the cultures, and the fact that not just the characters/vocabulary changed between them, but also the grammar. | What a wonderful experience! I stood up and clapped as the end credits rolled.

[I]Chants of Sennaar[/I] is a somewhat challenging puzzle adventure game with very little hand-holding. There's much joy to be had in exploration, experimentation, and figuring things out for yourself. Most prominently, you must decipher foreign languages, specifically their orthography, grammar, and even meanings in translation. That might sound like a poor fit for a video game, but the mechanics for it are sensible and comprehensible.

The story is unveiled in layers (literally!) and is enticing from beginning to end. Every veneer you peel off reveals something new, interesting, and often delightful.

The presentation is simple but beautiful, comprising expressive animations, alluring color palettes, and wonderful music pieces.

If I have to complain about something, it's the controller interface. It can be a bit tedious to sort through the many orthographic symbols. Also, picking directions and objects can be finicky. I have a feeling that most playtesting was done with mouse and keyboard. But this blemish did not affect my pleasure, and I should emphasize that it's absolutely playable with a controller, even if it's not always ideal.

What a lovingly crafted and satisfying game! [I]Chants of Sennaar[/I] is an instant classic and a must-play for fans of puzzle adventure games.

really short and lacks the content, replay ability, and overall game play that all the other games had, wish I could recommend but there is no world were this serves to live up to the kingdom name, would have preferred if they worked more diligently on the games already released or the 4th traditional game in the series. For games that are infinitely repayable I would appreciate a focus on content than story, even so the story was very cookie cutter and disappointing at best and almost a joke at its best, this whole game seems like a half-hearted leap into new grounds and while I appreciate the effort none of them hit there marks and it ended up sacrificing a lot of what made kingdom so great. I look forward to seeing future releases but besides the amazing art and aesthetics this was a miss for me, | Good game if you've never played Kingdom before. Boring and basic if you have. Imho, Eighties is basically an episodic and linear story that has the gameplay of a stripped down, nearly naked Kingdom game. I'm recommending it because the game somewhat accomplishes what it advertised. I'm assuming most of us who are buying this are probably Kingdom fans though; if you are, change and reduce your expectations to have an enjoyable experience.

As a standalone, Eighties can be an okay purchase if you're looking to play a simple, story-forward game that you can definitely finish in less than 10 hours (in normal mode). Just buy it at a discount lol. It's for you if you enjoy a game with light plot, great aesthetics and soundtrack, and limited gameplay. Also, consider that there's not a lot of replayability. Once you've reached the end and have watched all of the cutscenes, the game is over. There's nothing left to do or explore. And even if you play it again, you don't make any active choices to change the course of the story so its not like you'll unlock a new type of ending. You either defeat the greed or restart at some level. And sure, even though all of the other Kingdom games are like this, the heavy emphasis on the story makes Eighties feel way more concluded and final once you get to the end. 

For Kingdom fans (especially Two Crowns fans who enjoy the other DLC), like no. There's no easy way to play Eighties and not compare its lack of features to previous iterations. Many of the unique features you'd find in Two Crowns like the pikemen/ninja/fishermen, farm/farmers, and certain structures (war horn, farm/stable, catapult, portals, etc) don't exist in Eighties and there are no good alternatives imo. I assume these reductions are because it doesn't work with the plot. Since the monarch is a teen in the eighties, there's no way you'd have a farmer or banker in your camp alongside the "workers/kids" you recruit (not without creative writing at least). My most critical note is that because there's not a lot to do, I got drowsy twice during my whole playthough and took a nap on both occasions. And to be super nitpicky, I so hate how the mounts move. So annoying to have to move back-and-forth numerous times just because the mount has an extended stop and doesn't fully stop moving once you literally lift your finger off the button. There are a few more nitpicky things butâ€¦.ugh.

Sigh. I really wanted to love it. I don't regret the purchase but I also won't be playing it again. As beautiful as it is, I bought Eighties for interesting new gameplay which it sort of delivered. I didn't buy it just to experience subpar Kingdom gameplay in a new skin. Oh well. | Kingdom VersiÃ³n: Adolescentes esclavizando niÃ±os.

æ­£å½“æˆ‘ä»¥ä¸ºå¦‚æ­¤æ­£ç¡®çš„æ¸¸æˆåº”è¯¥ç”±ä¸€ä¸ªååˆ†å¤šå…ƒåŒ–æ¸¸æˆå›¢é˜Ÿåˆ¶ä½œæ—¶ï¼Œæœ€åçš„åˆ¶ä½œäººå‘˜ç…§ç‰‡æ˜¾ç¤ºå…¨å‘˜ç™½äºº23333ï¼Œè¿‡äºå…¸äº†ã€‚ | In short: 4 hours taking it VERY slow and already completed. Utterly disappointing and cheap re-skin with 0 replay-ability.

- If you don't have Kingdom Two Crowns, definitely buy that one and have a much much better experience and feel like its totally worth your money. You can also enjoy playing with a friend which is a feature missing in this one.

- If you have Kingdom Two Crowns don't even bother. The game is very short and feels like a cheap cash grab. Graphics are splattered all over the place making it actually hard to see what you're doing, never mind the dumb story that you can easily miss out on. This game feels like they had an intern who was bored and re-skinned the first game in the series missing the better features of the later games. It's also extremely short and to easy with no replay-ability at all.

The game after this one will have to be VERY GOOD and return to form or else this developer will be something to forget. Such a shame after the hundreds of fun hours my wife and I had playing every DLC and challenge on the hardest difficulty in Two Crowns.

TL;DR: Don't bother with this "game" and save your money for something better.

Honestly, it comes across as a bit barebones for a game that, even on sale, I feel is a bit overpriced. I wanted to give it a try since I love zombies and I love turn-based combat, but nothing in the writing nor gameplay strikes me as particularly interesting. If the price was lowered substantially, I could see myself giving this a more fair go, but at 20 bucks (15 on sale when I tried it) I feel like the minimal amount of content and depth I experienced in the first couple hours just didn't make it worthwhile. The UI was a little finicky and wouldn't respond to my clicks pretty frequently, and some of the writing comes across as a bit amateurish (I mean this in the nicest way I can, since this is clearly a small team effort). 

Again, maybe for an incredibly deep sale (as in maybe 5-8 bucks) I would repurchase the game and give it another go, but from what I've seen, I don't think it's quite worth the purchase. | Relatively short game. Theoretically a game you could replay several times but its highly frustrating. Sometimes you get enemy zombies which are just to strong and wipe your team. And there are near to no possabilities to heal your team except the weird ones where you can hope that you have enough apples, otherwise you get fucket even harder because you dont have enough apples.

 | Refunded.
Well, I did just play it until a few fights after killing the dogmaster, and it was seriously boring, but that's on me.

Combat was good, very tactical, you could literally kill anything with statuses like bleed or poison, but then, it was linear as hell.
One thing I never liked on any game, you choose the lower path and that's it, no way to go back to the previous selection, no way to just "wait" where you're at, even if you're starved or don't have food/fuel. Maybe that's an option that opens up later in the game but it makes no sense to be that linear without that small part of agency on an RPG.

The permadeath is good, as expected but aside from that my main gripe is how linear it is, and all that in 30 minutes, YEAH.

Ğ§Ñ‚Ğ¾ ÑĞ°Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğµ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÑĞ½Ğ¾Ğµ, ĞµÑĞ»Ğ¸ ÑƒĞ±Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¿Ñ€ĞµĞ³Ñ€Ğ°Ğ¶Ğ´Ğ°ÑÑ‰ÑƒÑ Ñ„Ğ¸Ğ³ÑƒÑ€Ñƒ Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¹ Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ²Ğ°Ğ½ÑˆĞ¾Ñ‚ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ĞºĞ½ĞµÑ‚, Ğ½Ğ¾ Ñ Ğ²Ğ°Ğ¼ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ³Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ»... | This is exactly my kind of silliness. Shotgun King is a chess game except you only have your king left and he has a shotgun. If that makes you think "Wait a minute, that's not chess at all!" then you would be correct. The game only wears its chess influence only on the surface, the game actually is a turn-based strategy roguelike. You have to play through 12 rounds and defeat the final boss at the end. Each round your goal is to kill the white king. You can do this by firing your shotgun, each white piece have different amount of HP, pawns and knights have the lowest and the king has the most. Your shotgun has three main stats: firepower, range and firing arc. Firepower defines how many pellets your shotgun fires, each pellet dealing exactly one damage. Multiple pellets can hit the same target, can hit multiple targets or completely miss any target. There is some RNG involved here but the closer you stand to your target, the more likely you are to hit it. Range shows the maximum travel range of your pellets. Your firing arc shows the spread of your pellets, they will always be inside this arc. Shooting an enemy that stands directly before you will always make all pellets hit him. It's the same concept as in other shooting games, the shotgun is more powerful close range and loses its power the further you stand away. However, sometimes a wider spread might be beneficial to hit more pieces. There are some strategic decisions you can make here.
Shooting or moving will always pass your turn. White pieces will move on their turn and they can move multiple pieces at the same time. They have their own speed stat that defines how many turns they have to wait until they can move.
Moving will also reload your shotgun. This is important, so you can move outside of check and fire on your next turn.
Your shotgun has only limited ammo, which does regenerate but very slowly, so you don't want to kill every piece, you want to focus on the king but still deal with troublesome pieces.

After each floor you will come in contact with the roguelike mechanic of the game, the cards. You get a selection of two different black cards which help you for the rest of the run. These can be simple like more firepower, ammo or range but they also can give you completely new abilites like a melee attack that does not use ammo or grenades, that will hit multiple pieces but can also kill you.
Each black card is tied to a white card. These are upgrades for the white side. They can get more pieces, change how pieces move and give pieces more HP or speed. You will have to evaluate what upgrades you need but also what downsides you can endure in return. One white card that always appears is the white queen after floor 3. You can't escape her, she is everywhere.
Killing a non-pawn piece will give you an edge however. You get their "soul" which you can activate to move in the same pattern as the piece you killed. You can only store one soul but you can get black cards that allow you to store more or have some other synergy with it. These soul cards are best used to get out of check or close the distance to the white king.

The game is incredibly goofy with its concept but its also a challenging strategy game that will take you some time to master. And as you beat th egame, you will start to unlock new difficulty levels that add extra pieces at the start, improve the enemy AI and give the white king more HP. You can also unlock new shotguns that have different starting stats. There is a surprising amount of variety in this small game. The game still gets updates to this day, despite being almost three years old. It's funny, it's challening and it's the exact type of game to play at the evening after a long work day. | It was a great fun game with levels that get a little bit harder, and you can get different shotguns and after each round you pick a card that upgrades your side, and the enemy. The normal amount of turns in a round is maybe 20-30, and 9 rounds in the level and i think 8 levels. There is also endless and chase.
 | This game is a very fun strategy and roguelike game, i love the variety of cards for you and the enemy and the achievements have kept me playing for a bit now, definitely worth it for the price but would pick it up on a sale like I did. | Fun game, nice and easy but with just the right amount of strategy involved.

Ğ’Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ²ĞµÑ€Ğ½ÑƒÑÑŒ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¶Ğµ, Ğ½Ğµ Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞµÑ‚ÑÑ ÑĞ»ÑƒÑ‡Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¿ĞµÑ€ĞµĞ½Ğ°ÑÑ‹Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑÑ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ¹ ĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¹. | This game is a trip.

I thought I'd be on a fun little chart game experience, have a little story, have a little spooky (at least the game was advertised as such).

Turns out I was genuinely surprised by both the writing, the concept of looping and the (sometimes) disturbing psychological/ body/ cosmic horror that Slay the Princess has.

There isn't wrong choices just new perspectives.

ğŸ‘
-The art is genuinely awesome
-The story is full of twists and turns, getting the whole picture is very rewarding
-The music is awesome
-The protag is pretty cool uwu

ğŸ‘
-The 100% is very grindful and an achievement can glitch out once in awhile.
-I felt very sad about finishing the game :( 

TLDR: 100% would recommend! | Slay the Princess was really enjoyable to play from start to finish! This game reminds me of The Stanley Parable, with every choice you make having real consequences and a Narrator guiding you through... along with some other voices popping in too! The amount of content is insane, it took me 25 hours to see everything, and sometimes just when I thought I'd seen it all, another twist or surprise would show up. It's dark, funny, and even a little thought-provoking at times! I highly recommend it!

-you don't know either
-no one knows
-play for 2 hours and get blurred vision from reading the same things over and over again
-be covered in â€œphilosophicalâ€ drivel
-all the answers are like: â€œyou don't understand, it's hard to explain, I'm an entityâ€
-the game has no message
-"it's all conceptual, you don't understandâ€
-exactly the same as the characters
-nothing matters
-dying, killing, saving, everything leads to the same place, there's no happy or sad ending.
-there are several confused princesses, without any criteria, totally random and without personality
-you have zero interest in discovering more irrelevant endings 
-go to the support page to ask for a refund, discover that it's been more than 14 days since you bought the game and now there's no way to get your money back, you're stuck with a mentally fragmented entity in the form of a princess, an irrelevant narrator and yourself, apparently a bird that can't look at itself in the mirror. Where are we? What is the world? Who are we? Knowing these things makes absolutely no difference, there is no consolation or purpose, you will either cease to exist or live forever, in no scenario will these things matter. You'll want to erase your own memory over and over again in the hope that you won't get bored the next time you repeat the same story. Kill or save the princess, it doesn't matter, it's the same. Discover that they are entities, confused gods, building themselves and then destroying themselves, you don't know what they are, they don't know what they are, the author doesn't know what they are, nobody knows anything, it's all a mess, play until you get the picture, go to the refund page, but you bought it on 01/01/2025, it's been 14 days, there's no refund, you're stuck... A! I'm sorry, am I repeating the same things? That's exactly what the game does. It would be fine if it was interesting, but it's boring, it has no purpose, no message, there's a person before playing Slay the Princess and there's a person after playing Slay the Princess, they're exactly the same person.

It's a Twilight Imperium 4th edition knockoff. Don't get me wrong, great idea, TI4 is a fantastic game and Stellaris Nexus  (because that's what it was sold as all through EA and it changed less than a month before release) does a decent job of it. Sadly, whatever support it was  going to get was probably gutted when Paradox rug pulled the Stellaris theme from it, changed the name to that of a phone, pushed 1.0 release, and dropped it like a rock. It's highly doubtful it'll receive any additional updates or playable races, the potential for multiplayer outside known friend groups is slightly more lively than a cactus shop in the Sonora, and there are still some rather glaring bugs that will probably never be fixed. It's depressing really, you can tell the devs were really excited until they put out a completely bland corporate buzzword filled post about the name changing, EA ending, and a launch without any fanfare. Paradox kills another game that probably would have been good, this time because they couldn't figure out how to squeeze 50 DLCs from it. | Incroyable mini stellaris avec des mÃ©caniques fun et facile Ã  prendre en main. | Pretty good 4x game with a big emphasis on quick play. Certain mechanics can feel odd to get used to, but the moving pieces work well together. | Every match is different and has so much depth. Every class is unique and the abilities is different. One is a peaceful class and another one is focusing on fighting. There is a lot of playtime to invest to figure everything out. Campagne was also really fun. Only critic I have:

- implement more overviews like which research technology I am using 
- in the building menu I would like to see if I have the building already or not
- increase number of winning points or match modes like deathmatch (or at least an endless option to continue playing after meeting winning condition)

This game recommandation comes from hearth and is definitively a secret insider tip. | great 4x game and fast pace

It's a shame they chose such a terrible art style. The game was magical in the 90s with the highly detailed pixel art presenting pretty much the best possible realism at the time. They've ditched that to present a Cartoon Network reject style of art.

The game itself is good, follows the same storytelling tropes and puzzles. Just the art is horrible and whoever directed the art style should be exiled from game development. | There's a lot to like about this game, a lot that is done well and made for an enjoyable adventure. Avoiding spoilders, there's a few parts I felt were a misstep, one of which was genuinely upsetting early on in the game.

What kills this game for me is the ending. It's in line with Monkey Island 2, but doesn't have the luxury of being unexpected or the extra layers that make it seem more sinister. This just leans on unreliable narrator for its ending and feels more like a copout. They even give you a quiet moment to reflect, which just makes me certain that this game has to sit as my least favorite of the series. | If you're not stuck on a nostalgia trip looking for the childhood sense of wonder you had when playing M.I.1 and 2 then this is a great Point and Click adventure game. I love pixel art and could complain about the style and look, but the dialogue, puzzles, sound, world, story, all hit clean as ever. Not to keen on the ending but i had a lot of laughs getting there. | Turned out to be a nice and chill experience to play with controller on the couch. It has the Monkey Island humor I liked from the earlier games, lots of return characters and was fun in general. I picked easy difficulty, but might replay it in the future on hard. 

Only downer was the ending which felt a meh, but the ride to the end was cool, so still a positive in the end. | I really enjoyed this. Monkey Island 1 & 2 are always going to hold a special place in my heart since I played them as a child (I missed all the later versions), and this sequel does a really good job of capturing what was fun about those first games.

I randomly re-stumbled on this game in my library after forgetting about it and found myself having a lot of fun with it. If you are a fan of Vampire Survivors or similar roguelite games, then this should be on your Wishlist!

There is a lot of replayability and fun to be had by the large amount of unique characters (each with their unique Skill Tree) that you will experiment leveling up with each run. Only a few characters to choose from at the start, but you will unlock many characters with various hints in the selection screen about doing so. I was highly amused by the obvious homage to Vampire Survivors and the use of the Konami code as an old school gamer. | Great game! Unlocking new characters is cool specially the Contra cheat code ehehe | Very fun and well worth the money. You can jump in for a quick easy run, or spend hours unlocking everything. Love the artwork as well. This gets a definite Recommend from me. If I only got to say one thing, it'd be "give this a try." especially if you like Isometrics, Roguelikes, ARPGs or *Risk of Rain.*
I was surprised to see it not overwhelmingly positive so lets touch on that. 
"Runs take hours"- a player with 0.5 hours of playtime. No, No they don't. You can loop infinitely though if you choose.
"you can't save"- this is a roguelike. Your overall progress is automatically saved, and each run you start will be different and from scratch...just like every other roguelike.

Now to the obvious: Isometric Risk of Rain. Which is a GREAT thing. Yes there are differences but if that is ALL you have to go on, that is a huge win. Gameplay is smooth, all the characters are viable and can become extremely powerful, unlocking everything was a blast.
Difficulty: This seems to have people divided. There is a difficulty selector for a reason...Though I would say after unlocking everything, learning the mechanics and good builds, they could add something more challenging. 
Lastly: This is in early access! The current state is vastly different then the videos I watched to check it out 8 months ago. It will continue to develop, get content and get polished. I'm very excited to see where it goes. | ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ²Ğ¾ÑÑ…Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ğ°Ñ Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ñ„Ğ¸ĞºĞ°, Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ğ¹ Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½ Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÑĞ½Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ½Ğ°Ğ·Ğ²Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ°ĞºĞ¶Ğµ Ñ…Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÑĞ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ Ğ³ĞµĞ¹Ğ¼Ğ¿Ğ»ĞµĞ¹. Just wish there were more items and interesting ways of building characters. More interesting objectives or end goals in the end of a run. Every run with a given character will pretty much feel the same. 

Give it a year and it can rival Risk of Rain 2 in sheer funness and replayability?? | This game fixes several annoyances I had with Risk of Rain 2.
Here I no longer need to pause the game and look up what items do on my phone. Thank GOD! It also tells you what you need to do to unlock things. A couple I needed to look up but majority of them are straight forward.

Played exclusively on Steam Deck and it can usually hold 60fps but once it starts getting crazy with a lot of enemies and particle effects it will drop down to 40's or less so it definitely needs more optimization. Also one of the characters (Echo) is unplayable on controller right now but I read they already are fixing controller issues in the next big update. 

Overall, for a team of like 4 devs its a solid game with a lot of potential and I'm excited for the next update! | This is what ARPGs should be.  Fighting is fast paced but challenging, items are powerful, and the vibes are immaculate.

Every part of this works together harmoniously

About the only thing this game lacks is more planets, but hey, that's early access for you.

This review is a little biased because this is the first Harry Potter universe game Iâ€™ve fully completed and gotten 100% achievements in.  

First of all, Iâ€™m so glad this isnâ€™t another game where you just play as Harry Potter. Instead, you get to create your own character and fully experience the world of Hogwarts. That alone made it worth playing for me.  

 [h2]Gameplay[/h2]
The developers clearly put a lot of love into this game, and it shows. [b]Hogwarts Castle[/b] is absolutely stunning so much so that it actually made me tear up at times. Everything feels alive, from NPCs casually using magic to paint pictures or prank each other to weird potion experiments happening in the bathrooms. I could spend hours just listening to NPC conversations.  

The game has three main areas:  
- [b]Hogwarts Castle[/b] â€“ Easily the best part of the game, full of detail, personality, and magic everywhere.  
- [b]Hogsmeade[/b] â€“ A charming, lively village thatâ€™s fun to explore and next to the castle.
- [b]The Open World[/b] â€“ This was hit-or-miss for me. It has some interesting moments, but compared to Hogwarts, it feels less polished and emptier. It honestly felt like two different teams worked on these areasâ€”the castle is [b]bursting with life[/b], while the open world feels [b]weaker in quality[/b]. Most collectibles and side quests take place in the open world, which was fine, but I personally wouldâ€™ve loved more focus on the castle itself.  

That said, side missions were actually fun and never felt like a chore. The Forbidden Forest, while well-designed, didnâ€™t feel as scary as I imagined it would be.  
This game also has [b]a ton[/b] of collectibles and optional content for 100% completion. Unfortunately, three of the achievements require replaying the game three times up to a certain point, which felt like a grind and should honestly be removed.  
Spiders. Spiders everywhere. Every five minutes, the game throws you into another cave full of horrifying spiders. Thankfully, the devs included an [b]Arachnophobia Mode[/b] for those who canâ€™t handle them.  

[h2]Combat[/h2]
Iâ€™m absolutely in love with the combat. Itâ€™s even better on Hard difficulty, but Normal strikes a great balance between fun and challenge. Honestly, this game has ruined traditional mage/wizard combat for me nothing else feels as good after playing this. The spell combos, dodging, and enemy variety make every fight feel pretty dynamic.  
Although opinions on this are mixed, I personally really vibed with it.

[h2] Story[/h2]
The story was [b]okay[/b] nothing special. Itâ€™s your typical "kill the bad guy to save the world" kind of plot. The side quests and relationship quests were way more engaging than the main story, and I actually found myself more invested in those.  

[h2]âŒ Cons[/h2]

- [b]Major Lighting Issues in Interior Areas [/b] :
(As of new update on January 30th 2025)
Many caves and rooms are blindingly bright, like a flashbang directly to the eyesâ€”completely white screens that are painful to look at. If you have epilepsy, be careful. This is a weird bug since these areas are fully enclosed with no sunlight source, but the moment you step into certain spots, itâ€™s like staring directly into the sun.

- [b]Performance Issues[/b] : 
Iâ€™m running this game on an RTX 4060 at 1440p, and while it looks great, it has some serious issues:  

[b]Texture Pop-in / Loading Issues[/b] â€“ My biggest complaint. This is a well-known PC bug that happens even on the lowest settings. NPCs, grass, and objects suddenly pop into existence right in front of you, completely ruining immersion. Whatâ€™s frustrating is that the game used to run way better at launch, but the last update (around six months ago) broke a lot of things, and they never fixed it.  
Some examples of texture pop-in issues:  
- NPCs suddenly appearing a few steps away when I turn the camera.  
- Half-invisible cows in Hogsmeade.  
- Grass abruptly loading every time the camera angle changes during a conversation or cutscene.  
- Even opening the menu and returning to the game makes textures freak out.  
>[b]Edit[/b] : As of the new update on 30th January texture pop in issues is mostly fixed, its still here and there but nothing immersion breaking.

[b]Ray Tracing is a Mess[/b] â€“ Turning on RT causes micro-stutters and makes texture pop-in even worse. Itâ€™s simply not worth using in this game currently, it used to be way better before.
>[b]Edit[/b] : As of the new update on 30th January, they added ray reconstruction, DLSS 4 to this game. RT performance is a bit better but its still a mess in open world areas.

[b]Winter Season FPS Drops[/b] â€“ For some reason, when it snows, my FPS gets cut in half. Itâ€™s a massive bummer because winter in Hogwarts should feel magical, but instead, it just lags.  (I have not checked this in the new update)

- [b]Low Replayability[/b] â€“ While each house has an exclusive quest, replaying the whole game just for one extra mission isnâ€™t very appealing. However, the upcoming PC modding update should help with this issue.  I'm honestly depressed this game is over I want to experience it more :(
>[b]Edit[/b] : New mod update did not help with this but there's rumours about them adding possible new story content to the game, nothing concrete tho.

If they ever fix these issues, this game would be so much more enjoyable.  

[h2]Final Thoughts[/h2]
I just want to thank the devs for creating such an amazing game. It was one of the best gaming experiences Iâ€™ve had. Despite its flaws, I still highly recommend it. This game is worth picking up at full price and even more so at a discount! | With the latest update, the terms of service now include a section where they can, without notifying you, disclose your personal information (IP address, personal information, chat logs, payment information and other information) to third parties. 

When I tried to opt out of this, I got redirected to a page which informs you "The Warner Bros. Discovery Privacy Center is Not Available in Your Region."

I've sunk 80+ hours of time into this game, which is now being held hostage unless I agree to give them my person information. Very disappointing.

EDIT:

More info about the issue here
https://steamcommunity.com/app/990080/discussions/0/599643178892562658/

and here
https://steamcommunity.com/app/990080/discussions/0/599643178892569931/

After playing Civ 7 I was delighted to play a game where obvious attention and care went towards the interface.
Pleasant traditional roguelike with really nice interface+controls and a lot of DnD-esque flavor. Reminds me a bit of DCSS and Incursion. | dev:

maybe too late to add, but I really think a classic RPG interface with visual slots for weapons and so on would add so much to the game and let people instantly connect to it. (look at 'Caves of Qud' which just released last year and has an insanely well done UI for this now, even for characters with 4 arms or nearby floatables)

it feels like such an essential part of immersing yourself into the game... the lines of text may work as a nostalgia play, but scare off anyone who doesn't want to deal with a frankly incredibly clunky way of doing inventory and equipment.

I don't want to give it a bad rating, because the game essentially is exactly what it promises to be, but I simply can't enjoy games that force you to do min-maxy try-hard roguelike experience sans any fun, adventure, exploration and so on.
people already tend to min-max the fun out of games and if you force people into challenge modes that's all they're gonna do. 

if I could just save and reload, I could challenge myself, play more relaxed and not be annoyed when the only reason I died was because I didn't know that X -> bad idea.

I know that there are people that like that, a lot claim to like it, but very few in fact do.

what people do like is to play in this manner in a game they already mastered or understand really well. I play roguelike modes in games, or games with meta progression, i.e. rogueLITEs (capitalization for emphasis. it seems that term isn't used any more, but that's how people called it back then) 

a story mode, or normal RPG mode with just exploration and leveling and so on would have been amazing for this game.... 

I just wanna play *my* character, not do speedruns or no hit stuff or hardcore runs. this stuff is fun to watch others do, but it's just so boring to me because whenever I get attached to my character, I die. it just kills the game for me.

I can't criticize or downvote a game because it said "roguelike" and delivered that and I didn't enjoy it :D -- but if I played through in a normal save scum mode as most people do, I'd way way way more likely enjoy the roguelike experience.

if you only do a challenge mode game (which is what this essentially is), the best way to do these games is simply with heavy meta progression, but that is quite the headache in a genre like this, I suppose. how would you even scale this? I have no idea... but it would at least "sell me" on the idea that this is still "my character". restarting as the same character from 0 does not do that - for me at least.

you can always limit a game mode to be more challenging, or simply have several seemingly equal ways to play a game. limiting the ways you can play a game needlessly seems unwise, even if you yourself are purely interested in a roguelike experience.

the game's incredibly well executed. I like everything except that I can't shoot through people -- but that's kinda personal taste and I guess makes sense, but is a bit annoying when you play a ranged character with hirelings that constantly spawn in their pets and you barely get to fire an arrow.




-----------------

if you play on Linux and 4k, go to .local/share/Steam/steamapps/common/Zorbus/Data/Settings.txt 
and change the relevant lines to:

tile_size................ 64

tiles_64_horizontal...... 46
tiles_64_vertical........ 29

zoom..................... 175

otherwise the game will not scale well | Very nice, well modernized, traditional roguelike. If you like DCSS, you'll like this. | Doidera | Ye

Ğ‘ÑƒĞ´Ñƒ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¹ Ğ²Ğ°Ñ Ñ‚Ğ°Ğ¼ Ğ±Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ¸Ñ‚Ğ¸ :) | A very strong "meh" from me, with a very slight unbalance into the not recommended side.
I thought the first couple of hours were great, but it went stale very very fast.
Halfway through chapter 6 and I'm wondering if I should just not bother with the rest.

The closest comparison I can make here is a mix of 'Fantasy General' and 'Gwent: Thronebreaker'.... kind of. But this is more boring than both of those.
It's a pretty repetitive slog. The story could've been good as the world is interesting, but the storytelling is pretty lacklustre.
The gameplay is mostly surviving the same enemy waves coming again and again and again, while building your economy in the background so that you can curbstomp the enemy after a while.

The art is great tho. | Don't Buy this game.

I don't have an entire semester to explain to you how this game managed to go from from "Dude, you gotta play this!" to "I'm thinking of ending..this game's existence in my account". But what I will say, the Dev's went out of their way in Campaign to hamstring & ruin any fun you can have after chapter one.
How TF are you gonna reset each Hero's(Every hero is forgetable except Lorelai) army, City and World every other Paragraph. 
The game is pretty and the music and audio is excellent. Heck, even the "RTS" gameplay is good once you realize the only way to strategize is to Conquer 3 cities and sit and defend for 10 turns to actually build up a proper army.
Also, this isn't an RTS, it's a Combat-Autoclicker and a node-point miner(The cities are the nodes).
Anyways, getting to the End of the game, even the "Easy" mode where you can't lose(Fun Fact, yes you can) The Dev's go out of their way in what I hope was the final mission before I uninstalled this game, to force the player to use 2 seperate groups on the same team who have to share resources to fight 2 types of "Battles" where Team A has to stumble around, turn-by-turn, looking for a city that has F. U.C. K. you levels of monster's sitting there while you team can't earn reinforcement thanks to the F. U. C. K. awful low resource generation and reset armies. Team B has to "Defend" against an army that is 10 movement turns, but actually is like 5 depending on if the game decides the fully filled out enemy is going to ignore it's movement penalty for being filled with tier-3 level monsters and kill 3 cities in just as many turns. At this point, I thought, maybe it's bugged or I suck, but shocker, I opened the chapter back up in the hardest & balanced difficulties and the game still pulls this BS for no discernible reason.

I can see the makings of something fun and unique in this game but every time you start to have fun the chapter "Ends" or the story demands you to "Focus on Movement" or they force-kill a character that has strategic value for the sake of "Story". I'm to youtube to watch the end of the game and then forget this game exist. | [h1]True hidden Gem![/h1]

I went from being obsessed with the game to disappointed. Reasons: when I played the beta I played it on a desk top, the game seemed like a laid back game where there is lots to do but it was a beta so it obviously needed a bit a work, I wasnâ€™t worried about it. 

I bought the game and bought a steam deck along with it. While I played the game it was laggy and the characters eyes seemed to disappear. When you have quests they donâ€™t really show up on the map so for some quests it makes sense such as â€œ search and findâ€, but other quest like speak to â€œ â€œ it would have been nice for it to be indicated on the map. What Iâ€™m trying to say is that things on the map i personally wish were a lot more clear. 

To add when you play and gain an item if your bag is full it doesnâ€™t drop the item or ask you if you want to discard and old one to make room for the new one, the new item is just gone. So if you find cool armor or a weapon you automatically lose it. It was frustrating once I experienced it. The graphics are nice, it gives a cozy feel which I love, but what gets in the way is the lag I experience once playing. On pc it was less laggy, but still experienced occasional lag. i have played a lot of games, for a long time. many different genres, design sensiblities, and art styles, across several decades, on so many different systems. from NetHack to Hades II, from SpaceChem to Cookie Clicker, from DOOM (1993) to DOOM (2016).

this, for my money, might be the best game ever made.

intuitively simple; exquisitely complex and deep. i have every achievement and still cannot see a future where i don't play this anymore. arguably, this video game's existence is a testament to the undying creativity of the human spirit --- that we make works of dear significance and utter perfection almost by accident simply by following those pursuits we enjoy most.

furthermore, here i am, inspired to write all this pseudopoetic drivel about a video game next to meme reviews by accounts pretending to be Goku or whatever. but i wouldn't be sitting here calling it the best game ever made if it didn't also drive me to write "the undying creativity of the human spirit" in a steam review

Game Name: Wizardry: Proving Grounds of the Mad Overlord
Reviews:
This is not a game for everyone. It's a game from the 1980's even with a new coat of paint and a few balancing and QOL features, but it's still a tough, unforgiving dungeon crawler that is as much about preparation and patience as it is about learning to roll with the punches when the dice form a middle finger in your face. 

Despite all of this, I found this game very gripping and captivating. Every victory felt earned and you start feeling attached to your guys whom have no given personality. The graphics feel like it's an updated old school game like the Sega AGES games back in the day and the atmosphere can be tense. It's a game that I, once I got over the frustrations and accepted that I usually should keep a party of people that you can send to carry your bones for revival out, made even easier by the recruitment system. Really I feel money is the issue in this game where the most issues are. You either have barely a coin to spare or you are flushed with gold that it kinda feels meaningless.

I found the game super engaging and captivating. If you wanna see what was one of the three great progenitors of Roleplaying video games and a piece of important video game history, I would say this game is worth experiencing! Just don't try to 100% achievements, those 40 hours of searching every enemy to complete the bestiary were carried by my lizard brain liking the sight of levels going up.

... So when is the Knight of Diamonds scenario coming out? | I am a fan of the Wizardry series, so it's nature that I would recommend this game. However, it is not for everyone because the core mechanism of the game is developed 40 years ago. My personal opinion is that Wizardry 7 is the best of the series and you can play Wizardry 7 instead of this one. However, if you like the conventional dungeon-crawler game, this one is a classic. 
Below is the breakdown list  of the features you should be aware of in this game, if you don't like it, don't play it.
1. The choice of gears and loots in this game is very limited. For example, there is no ranged weapon in this game so you need to rely on spells, which are quite few in the early phase of the game.
2. The character's development is also limited. There is no perk, feat, skill tree, etc; no, there is no such thing. When you level up, you only get attribute points, hit points and spells. You can tolerate this in Wizardry 7 because the diversity and versatility of the spells and the multiclass mechanism, but this is not the case in this game.
3. The so-called multiclass in this game is actually re-edit you character to level 1, where you only keep your hit points and spells, while your hard-earned attributes and abilities are lost. 
4. The character may be permanently lost; for example, a fail in resurrect (the chance depends on your vitality) may cause your beloved character forever gone. Yes, he/she is gone "forever". 
5. The same as above, you need to accept that all your team members are replaceable. When your team is wiped out, it is usually a better idea to fully re-create your whole team rather than to rescue them. It means, the bonds between you and your characters are poor. 
6. No automapping. No. You need to repeatedly cast a level 1 mage spell to do that, but with very few information on the map. I know this is a claimed "fun" feature of the series. However, from the standpoint of modern gaming, this may not be necessary. 
7. No manual save-load. The game is auto-saved; so it is very hard to use the save-load scum. You need to quit the game during the process and re-enter the game to load. However, you may regard that everything in this game is probably irreversible.
8. There is only ONE town. You need to go everytime back to town to level up, rest, sell/buy gears and etc. And there is no auto-comparison to your currently equipped items when you buy gears. 
9. The inventory slots are very limited. 

So, in summary, this game is very focused. If you can attach yourself to the very core of the dungeon-crawler game, then this game is simple but good, actually a classic. If not, try other modern CRPG games. | Wizï¼‘ã‚’ãƒ•ã‚¡ãƒŸã‚³ãƒ³ã‚„88/98ç­‰ã§éŠã‚“ã äº‹ãŒã‚ã‚‹äººã«å‘ã‘ã¦ã®ãƒ¬ãƒ“ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã‹ã‚‚

After finishing it, I can conclude that Dragon's Dogma 2 might be the biggest disappointment I've ever experienced in gaming. I could go on for paragraphs about all the things that are bad about it, but I'll just summarize because I've already spent over 100 hours playing this when I could have been doing something else, like plucking my asshole hairs individually.

First and foremost, Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen exists. In a world where DDDA didn't exist, this game would stand about where DDDA was - blatantly unfinished, didn't live up to it's potential, lot's of contemplating on how it could be better, but essentially just the skeleton of something great with pretty decent gameplay. [i]However[/i].

DDDA exists. Not only does it exist, Dragon's Dogma 2 is a marked downgrade in nearly every single metric already established by the prior game twelve years ago. Eleven if you want to be generous for the addition of Dark Arisen. There is less enemy variety, there are less vocations, equipment variety is worse, the story is worse, there are both less major characters and they have infinitely less screen time/importance/value, the music is just... nothing. I could keep going. The only measure DD2 is a genuine improvement and not just a side grade is in the graphics department, and this comes at a cost of the game being complete dog ass to run on your average PC. Sure you'll probably get 30-60fps consistently but it will chug randomly for no reason all over the place. Ignore Capcom's nonsense about it being NPCs in town, I was getting 18fps just loading the model in my inventory. Something about REengine or Denuvo has this game in a complete stranglehold and unfortunately it'll probably never get fixed.

If DDDA didn't exist, Dragon's Dogma 2 would just be a kind of stupid action RPG with good gameplay. But instead it's an abysmal sequel to a game with an already kind of stupid plot with better gameplay, and it manages to take that original idea and basically photocopy it with a scanner that was pretty low on ink. This game is so frustratingly undercooked. Let's just use an example. 

In the original game, you took damage and you lost HP and your "loss gauge" increased. This missing HP couldn't be healed for free with Anodyne, so you could either go to an inn or use healing items. Healing items had weight and were limited, and though you'd eventually be swimming in them, the healing your loss gauge meant you wanted to have them just in case. In DD2, you take damage and your loss gauge builds up, and... healing items don't do anything different than Anodyne. Okay, so this immediately makes healing items fucking worthless since they're still making you heavier (and slower) but they do the same thing as Anodyne, which mages can cast for free, all the time. In fact you'd only not have a mage with anodyne because you specifically chose to have no mage in your party. In exchange, you now have to go camping. Camping is so... fucking... NOTHING. It's just completely devoid of anything. Find one of the spots all over the map, use your tent item which can break but not only will this basically never happen you find tents constantly - all so you can cook meat and get an actual video of someone grilling a steak on a pan in real life, and get a buff. You have the same one line of dialogue with your pawn at the camp site and go to sleep. But keep in mind you can only cook meat - not fish, not fruit, not potatoes, and you certainly can't make meals or anything fancy. In fact there are 8 types of meat you can cook for the entire game and they're all just variations of two types of meat, Scrag and Beast Steak. Combining them makes Dried whatever meat and if you let it rot you get Rotten whatever meat (which you can still cook and your pawns will say it's delicious because their canned yummy yummy response is also completely fucking nothing).

This is DD2. It's just so empty. It builds on nothing from DDDA. It's got a bigger world except it's almost exclusively just roads and cliffs that make traveling at night more annoying, and lots and lots of fighting fodder enemies. Which is fun! In fact, the first 20-30 hours of this game are spectacular. But the more you play it, the more and more obviously unfinished it is. Until the final sequence where the credits are rolling and some NPC I maybe met twice in 80 hours and don't care about is literally explaining to me what the Dragon's Dogma is. Holy shit.

I want to live in a world where this game never came out, because at least before I could hope about what Dragon's Dogma 2 could be. Now it's out, and it's too late. We'll never have that, just like we didn't get to have the Dragon's Dogma 1 that "we were supposed to".

At least I got to kill thousands of Goblins. Do not recommend. | Game hasnt been updated in months (sept) Really feels abandoned and needs optimizations badly.
