æ€ª

å¦‚æœä½ æ˜¯ï¼šçœ‹ææ€–ç”µå½±ç©ææ€–æ¸¸æˆèº«è¾¹çš„äººåœ¨ä¹±å«ï¼Œè€Œä½ å› ä¸ºç”»é¢å¤ªå¿«å¤ªæš—è§‚å¯ŸåŠ›ä¸æ•é”åå°„å¼§å¤ªé•¿ç­‰é”™è¿‡äº†æƒŠå“ç‚¹çš„äººï¼Œé‚£è¿™ä¸ªæ¸¸æˆæ¯«æ— ä¹è¶£ï¼Œä½†æœ‰å‚¬çœ ä»·å€¼ã€‚ | When it comes to the liminality phenomenon there are two major genres on Steam: the backrooms and those games with anomalies. [i]Exit 8[/i] belongs to the latter.

These software feature a relatively small playable area and our job is to simply pass it. We can find games taking place in hotel corridors, an office area, a small street or - as it is in this case - an underground passage.

The concept is always the same: go through the area but only in case you haven't found anything unusual. The first couple of times we go through it are considered the tutorial: we have the opportunity to carefully observe everything in our path. There are lamps, posters on the walls, doors, an expatriate walking towards us and even the painting on the floor is important. Not to mention the cameras and the signs.

In case we notice anything odd compared to the original state, we immediately need to turn back. Overall, we need to pass the underground passage 8 times (as in the title) but the final session must be without anomalies as we need to reach the staircase leading up to the surface.

There are over 30 anomalies and following our first completion the game puts up a sign with the number. As we find new anomalies this will decrease. The 2nd achievement is tied to finding everything. Now, finding means actually noticing the anomaly and turning back. 

But what if we make a mistake? That we go through the passage where an anomaly is present? Then we start from the beginning. Just before entering the long corridor, a huge sign shows what level we are on and should we make a mistake we are back to zero. In certain cases failure to react in time can result in death. If you see something fast coming towards you, I suggest you immediately turn back and run.

Due to the concept of liminality (that we are against such supernatural phenomena alone) this can be considered a horror game and some anomalies further justify this. In general, I find these games quite the niche on Steam and the only problem I have with them is that they are short. Still, I recommend this one as it is fun for an hour or so. | ã‚²ãƒ¼ãƒ ã®è¡¨ç¾ã¨éŠã³æ–¹ã®é‰±è„ˆã¯ã¾ã ã¾ã åº•ãŒãªã„ã“ã¨ã‚’å®Ÿè¨¼ã™ã‚‹ã‚ˆã†ãªã€ç´ æ™´ã‚‰ã—ã„ãƒ›ãƒ©ãƒ¼ã‚²ãƒ¼ãƒ ã€‚ã“ã®å”¯ä¸€ç„¡äºŒã®ãƒ—ãƒ¬ã‚¤æ„Ÿã¯ã€æ™‚ã«ç›¸åã™ã‚‹è¤‡æ•°ã®æ„Ÿæƒ…ã®åŒæ™‚æä¾›ã¨ãã®çµ¶å¦™ãªãƒãƒ©ãƒ³ã‚¹ã«ã‚ã‚‹ã€‚

Great game. Absolutely worth the price, even without a sale.  That said, probably won't be adding any more time into it unless more levels are added later.  

The controls take some getting used to, but after a couple hours you don't really think about it.  It's very satisfying creating small optimizations.

I would really like if there were a sandbox mode, or just unlimited budget versions of levels.  I really wanted to see how high the score could go.  Btw, if the dev is reading, one of the levels has a number of people who managed a maximum score, and then some hacker sitting at the very top with a score of like 6000.  It kind of felt like it de-legitimized the whole global scoreboard for the rest of the game. | the cars don't yield, they stop in the middle of a crossing, they try to cross 4 lanes of traffic to make a turn coming up within 12 feet, everyone driving down single lane roads with like 10 times more traffic than during rush hour
its just like real life



its fun but real life solutions only work if people follow basic rules | Nice too see cars collide then decipher the problem I managed to solve all left and right with 3 stars | itt dooeeessssnnnnn'tttttt woorrrkkkk! | Really nice puzzle game.

Genres: Adventure, Indie, RPG, Strategy, Early Access
Reviews:
The more I play this game the less I like it. "Every run is viable" is 100% nonsense. Half the roster is useless, and the other half will continue to be nerfed until they are useless too.  Save yourself a headache and play a game that doesn't think endless horde ambushes is peak level design. | In my opinion, this is one of the best modern rogue likes. It has a very arcade-y feel which I like. I do have one warning. In my 19 hours I have had probably 5 crashes. Be prepared to lose a run or two. | This is a great addition to my list of favorite modern traditional roguelikes (ToME, DCSS, Brogue, CoQ). This game just looks and sounds great. Abundant of QoL features take the friction out of exploration and discovery, and just enough information is presented to make important decisions without overwhelming you with a wall of numbers and stats.

That being said, I would like to see a combat log in the future (which the developer is currently working on). Great game, and a great dev. Looking forward to more updates soon. | amazing game honestly

Fun little spooky puzzler, takes about an hour to beat.

Most of the game amounts to reading a book and looking for clues to figure out a substitution cipher, while nervously checking to make sure a monster hasn't snuck up on you.

Does have some jump scares.

æœŸå¾…äº†å¾ˆä¹…çš„ç‹¬ç«‹æ¸¸æˆã€‚ä¹‹å‰è¿˜è”ç³»äº†åˆ¶ä½œç»„å°è¯•å¸®åŠ©ä¸­æ–‡æ±‰åŒ–ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯åˆ¶ä½œç»„å‡†å¤‡å‘å”®åæ‰¾ç¿»è¯‘å…¬å¸å®Œæˆæ‰€æœ‰å…¶ä»–è¯­è¨€çš„ç¿»è¯‘å·¥ä½œï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å› ä¸ºä¸­æ–‡é—®é¢˜è¿˜åœ¨çŠ¹è±«çš„å…„å¼Ÿä»¬å¯ä»¥ç­‰æ±‰åŒ–å‘å¸ƒäº†å†å…¥æ‰‹ã€‚é¦–å‘åˆ¶ä½œç»„å‡†å¤‡ä¹æŠ˜ä¼˜æƒ çš„ç»“æœå¤ªæ¿€åŠ¨å¿˜è®°äº†ä¹Ÿç€å®éš¾ç»·ï¼Œä½†ä¸å¦¨ç¢è¿˜æ˜¯ç›®å‰ä¸ºæ­¢ä»Šå¹´æœ€æ»¡æ„çš„ç‹¬ç«‹æ¸¸æˆäº†ã€‚ | If you're a Millennial, this game is a time capsule of your own memories, an actual drive down memory lane. It took me a couple playthroughs to understand why the setting is so vague - the currency symbol is fake, the town names are an amalgamation of Northern and Western Europe, so you could be anywhere from the west coast of Canada to England to Germany to Scandinavia - no setting is defined. Even the names of the people you meet are not names but descriptions, eg. The Kid, The Bride, etc. I found this clever little obfuscation allowing me to imprint my own experiences onto the game, with memories people and places I haven't thought of in 20 years all flooding back. The generality of everything allows a huge audience with a common lived experience to connect with the game on an extremely personal level. 

As for gameplay, nothing is groundbreaking and you've likely seen most of the mechanics before, but the game exists as a canvas for you to paint your own memories onto. It's really an extraordinary masterpiece. The strongest piece of the design is the freedom afforded to the player - you are given goals, but you don't need to complete them. You set off originally to get to a festival within a month, but the game lasts for 3 months and if you don't want to go to the festival then you don't have to. Nothing is forced, everything is at your discretion. Do drugs, or don't. Buy guns, or don't. Pick up hitchhikers, or don't. You won't be punished for anything except careless driving - but maybe don't get pulled over by the cops when you're drunk, that's a pretty tricky combat. 

Special mention for the soundtrack, absolutely incredible. Honestly the price of the game is worth it for the music, I have no idea how to developers found all this great obscure music, most of the songs in this game have less than 10,000 plays on Spotify. Cruising around in your car listening to this soundtrack is a distinct pleasure. 

Overall, 10/10. Even 11/10. If you get the vibes in this game you will have an extraordinary experience. | â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… (10/10)

Played the Demo of it for many hours and hyped to see the release. This is how to launch a game! Was even so brazen to E-Mail the devs if there's an opportunity to buy it earlier than the release date. Surprisingly got an answer back, telling me politely that it unfortunately isn't possible, but telling me there is a spotify playlist of the games soundtrack and gave me a link to it. Loved that response!

Keep Driving is a gem in the indie game scene an experience that's as cozy as a road trip at sunset with your favorite playlist on repeat.

Pros: (Spoiler: There are only pros)

- Zero Bugs: Flawlessly smooth. Not once did I encounter any crashes, glitches, or game-breaking issues.
- Stunning Graphics: The visuals are vibrant and charming, capturing the beauty of endless roads and scenic horizons in an incredibly cozy art style.
- Amazing Soundtrack: The music elevates the entire experience. It's chill, captivating, and fitting for the vibe. Bonus points for having the soundtrack as a Spotify playlist!
- Simple Yet Addictive Gameplay: It just clicks â€” easy to pick up but hard to put down. There's a satisfying rhythm that makes you want to keep driving (pun intended).
- Endless Replayability: Plenty of content to keep you entertained for countless hours.

If you're looking for a chill, feel-good game with polished gameplay and relaxing vibes, this oneâ€™s a no-brainer. Buckle up and hit the road, you won't regret it. | - Play for the emergent narrative game play
- Stay for the best-in-class soundtrack
- Run it back because there is *so* much to see and experience.

This feels like Oregon Trail mixed with a modern rogue-like.

The less you know, the better, IMO. | Wow. Honestly, just wow.

Please do not let the 17.99 price tag deter you, Keep Driving is a great game. 

I've currently only experienced two endings so far, but I can tell that there is so much to love about this game. I'm not entirely sure how much replay value there is outside of experiencing every single ending, as I haven't gotten there yet, but with how many endings there are and how long each run lasts, if you try to keep your game purchases around $1/hr you'll easily get your moneys worth out of this one. 

Edit: After doubling my time since review I still think this is amazing. Found a lot of cocaine on one of my runs, decided I'd maybe get some rehab, decided to party and have sex instead. 10/10.

MÅ‚odzi nawet na to nie zerknÄ…, a jeÅ›li juÅ¼ to bardzo szybko siÄ™ odbijÄ…. Mechaniki stare jak ja sam :). Oj dawno czegoÅ› takiego nie byÅ‚o na rynku. Ot, takie maÅ‚e cudeÅ„ko. | This game is fantastic. The art style isn't even a needed gimmick. It would be a very solid RPG were it using a more modern art style. I thoroughly enjoyed it. | Insane, dense Lovecraftian atmosphere, enjoyable combat mechanics and very captivating storyline - I enjoyed it a lot highly recommended. Didn't expect to like it as much as I did | I was so excited to play this game. A retro RPG with turn-based combat, pixelated graphics, and Lovecraftian horror theme! Count me in!

It started wonderfully. I restarted a few times to try different characters (hence my 15 hours), then settled on one and started playing. The game was very fun, engaging, and like a breath of fresh air among all other modern "RPG" games.

Then why the negative vote? Simple: It has bugs so severe that you are locked out of progressing in the game. Here be spoilers:  [spoiler]A quest asks you to find food for refugees. You have two options: buy food from smugglers, or take some farmer's goats. The leader of smugglers didn't even present the first option to me, so I went with the second option. I convinced the farmer through diplomacy to hand over his goats, but the game didn't register it! So I took his goats by force and brought them to the camp, but then the questgiver didn't present me the option to complete the quest! So here I was, being locked out from progressing the game. I had the same problem with a side quest but I had moved on, but this was the final nail in the coffin for me.[/spoiler]

So try this game at your own risk. You can enjoy it for hours, only then to get locked out of progressing. | This is a good game ruined by a bad combat system.

Thematically and aesthetically this game is fantastic. It tells a genuinely dark and gripping story. But the fights just aren't fun because the combat system lets this game down.

Basically this game uses grid based tactical fights, but there is one giant problem with them: You cannot move or attack diagonally and every time you kill an enemy in melee the attacking character advances into the space the enemy previously occupied. It creates an absolutely absurd system where nothing is intuitive to what it looks like on the screen.

For example, forming a line of fighters is a terrible strategy, because since you cannot attack diagonally what you're actually doing is ensuring that only one of your characters can attack that enemy. There are circumstances where you can spend several turns just trying to maneuver characters into a position where the can make useful attacks without getting screwed over if the enemy dies and they are forced to advance into its space. 

It's not that this system is impossible to master, but it's such a far flung abstraction from what you want out of a simulation of small group skirmish combat that it puts a stink on the whole game. It makes you feel like every enemy you encounter forces you to solve a puzzle rather than win a fight.

Genres: Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Early Access
Reviews:
I'd give this game a 7/10. This game is a blast from the past. I likely won't play it much more, but if you're looking for a 2000s style RPG that's unforgiving, has poor graphics, and doesn't hold your hand this is absolutely perfect for you. Unfortunately, once the nostalgia wore off, I realized that isn't actually what I enjoy anymore. I will say I think the price is a bit high for the simplicity of the game. About $20 would be more fair considering there's not much novel or complex here, and it's early access with some systems remaining to be implemented. | Im testing Ashes of Creation Alpha Phase 2, but bought this to play during downtimes. Funny that. This is the game I was looking for. AoC and its social engineering is great for some, but Im old and dont care about youtube drama. This game has the community and style of game I can get down with. Ive stashed that launcher and am going full steam ahead into Pantheon. | As a former Everquest player, I was easily talked into getting this from a buddy.  Started playing and couldn't stop.  My older boys watched me play a bit, asked some questions about it.  I more or less let them know this is a game from my generation and they probably wouldn't like it.  

After a short time, they got it anyway.  I suspected they wouldn't last, this fortnite / rocket league generation has much different expectations of games these days.  I couldn't have been more wrong.

50+ hours later both of them can't stop playing.  They appreciate the difficulty, consequences, and rewarding feeling of progress for the increased effort required for their time.  The 3 of us haven't been into the same game at the same time for a while, but Pantheon definitely had the hook for all of us.

Highly recommended.  Highly recommend recommending it to others you may not think would enjoy it, also.  Looking forward to the completion of this amazing project and hoping to have it around for decades to come. | Fantastic MMO! Only 15 hours in but my god do I want to not stop playing. This is the refresh the genre needed, going back to what made it so good before we all hopped onto the themepark ride. The no map makes you learn the map and not want to venture too deep and the mix of strong monsters and death penalty make you want to play in a group. This then forces you to play the way that makes MMO's the best genre, you play in a group and you explore on edge. Think WOW classic/EQ1 vibes. 

Don't be put off b how it looks as they will improve that but once in game you really don't care as you are having too much fun. 

This one is for heavy MMO fans or feel the genre lost what it once had, well it's back. | UPDATE:
The GMs have replied to the situation I mention below and have refused any accountability, despite the multiple types of proof, including their own staff confirming it, and are trying to sweep it under the rug. VR will never get any support, or references, from me until they rectify the situation. And for an EA game that is likely to be EOS within a year, that is something they should work to avoid.

-------


Original:

I initially enjoyed Pantheon, as it evoked a sense of nostalgia reminiscent of my time with EverQuest. Many of the gameâ€™s characteristicsâ€”such as long leveling grinds, a strong emphasis on group play, and static mob campingâ€”felt familiar and engaging.

Despite having invested 130 (120-ish of which were active hours) into the game and being an avid MMO enthusiast, I ultimately cannot recommend it. There are several key reasons for this.

First, the game leans too heavily on EverQuest-inspired mechanics without incorporating modern quality-of-life improvements or common enhancements seen in contemporary MMOs - I loved EQ. But if I wanted EQ, I'd go play EQ. Additionally, the community is moderated by individuals who appear more interested in wielding authority than fostering a positive and welcoming environment (It is a cesspool, which honestly most gaming Discords are). This has led to a rather toxic atmosphere. Furthermore, critical game updates and information are disseminated almost exclusively through Twitch streams, with little effort made to provide written summaries or official updatesâ€”something that should be standard practice, even with a small development team.

Under normal circumstances, I would still consider supporting and amplifying the game in its Early Access phase, as I generally appreciate the iterative development process. However, recent revelations regarding certain Game Masters (GMs) summoning rare spawns for a specific guildâ€”under the pretense of benefiting "elite testers"â€”have raised serious concerns. Initially, these actions were denied (Directly by the guilty party), only to later be acknowledged (AFTER all the proof came out). The game director stated that such practices "should not be happening," yet other GM and community manager comments suggest that this behavior has been normalized.

What is most troubling is that, despite the implications of favoritism within a live environment that includes a functioning economy and competitive progression, the developers have shown no remorse. There has been no formal apology or transparent explanation regarding how this situation arose and how they plan to address it moving forward. Given that Pantheon is already a niche title with a relatively small player base, maintaining trust and fairness should be a top priority. And to get ahead of the 'knights', it being EA doesn't matter. It being wiped in 2 years, does not matter. The concept of "We should have a test server" is baked into service games 101. They chose to incentivize testers.

While I do not regret my initial investment in the game, I will not continue to engage with it unless the developers take full accountability, provide a clear explanation of what transpired, and take meaningful steps to rebuild trust within the community.

Genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Early Access

Mit 50 Jahren noch ein Spiel zu entdecken, das einen fesselt, motiviert, zum Ãœberlegen anregt und einfach begeistert , ist wirklich schÃ¶n - DANKE DAFÃœR! | Please fix the crash that results in a total hardware reset. The game is great, but currently unplayable for those that don't wish to damage their computers. | This is a really good game. I'm a newcomer to PoE, having only briefly tried the first game a few years back. I consider myself a fairly casual ARPG player, but I love RPGs in general. This game is very much worth the cost of admission.

This game's combat feels satisfying in a way that no other modern ARPG has quite managed for me. The character progression and build variety have been the real highlights, though. The various systems for managing skills, stats and gear are really enjoyable and easily understandable. The best part is you'll actually have to use these systems since the game isn't afraid to provide a challenge.

The amount of mechanical depth on offer here is really impressive for how intuitive everything is at a glance, you can tell the devs really put a great amount of thought and care into how everything is presented. There are some rough edges, but overall the game is really good in this regard.

I strongly dislike using guides, so I've gone in as blind as possible. I highly recommend taking this approach, despite what some players might say. Using a guide is not necessary, and overpowered builds will likely get nerfed. If you use a guide you are doing yourself a genuine disservice and ignoring the most interesting aspects of the game. That's just my two cents though, play the game however you like.

I don't have many complaints. I think endgame would be more fun if the player could return to an area after dying. The XP loss is a good mechanic in my opinion, but I don't like having to restart from scratch AND use another waystone in order to do so. It's tedious and requires too much attention. The game currently doesn't attempt to accommodate more casual players at endgame. I think more options and a less restrictive structure would help a lot. As it stands now, the campaign is the most enjoyable part of the game.
